			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #107 / July 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
									</h1>
				<h3></h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/1172-2/" title="">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-2-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-2-1.png 884w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-2-1-250x167.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-2-1-768x513.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-2-1-700x467.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-2-1-120x80.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 884px) 100vw, 884px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							FAZIOLIGATE							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div>Dear All,</p>
<p>It seems that there are a number of crowdfunding campaigns being set up by some fans to buy me a Fazioli. While this is incredibly thoughtful and I really appreciate the lengths people are going to to secure me this lovely instrument, it is entirely unnecessary. As Mike from Birmingham says, “Why don’t you just buy your own fucking piano, you cheap c**t.” Mike is right, God bless him, I really should just buy my own piano.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p></div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-1164" class="post-1164 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #107 / July 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
									</h1>
				<h3></h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/no-more-mails-to-fazioli/" title="">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-4.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-4.png 846w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-4-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-4-250x250.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-4-768x768.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-4-700x700.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-4-120x120.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 846px) 100vw, 846px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div>
<p>Dear All,</p>
</div>
<div>
<p>It seems that some of my fans have reacted a little enthusiastically to my last Red Hand File and have contacted Fazioli ‘encouraging’ them to gift me a piano. While I appreciate the gesture, my post was a light-hearted piece and not to be taken seriously. The phone dialogue between my manager and the ‘woman from Fazioli’ was more than a little embellished for comic effect.</p>
<p>The tsunami of mail has left our friends at Fazioli a little shaken, so while I love you all &#8211; no more mails to Fazioli please! They are wonderful people.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->

height="0" width="0" style="display:none;visibility:hidden"></iframe></noscript>
<!-- End Google Tag Manager (noscript) -->

		<div class="wrapper">

			<!-- header -->
			<header class="header clear" role="banner">

					<!-- logo -->
					<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com"  class="logo">
						<!-- svg logo - toddmotto.com/mastering-svg-use-for-a-retina-web-fallbacks-with-png-script -->
						<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/themes/red-hand-files/dist/img/logo.svg" alt="Logo" class="logo__img">
						<span>The Red Hand Files</span>
					</a>
					<!-- /logo -->

					<!-- nav -->
					<nav class="nav" role="navigation">
						<a href="#" class="nav__burger"></a>

<li id="menu-item-12" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-12"><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/ask-a-question/">Ask a Question</a></li>

					<!-- /nav -->

			</header>
			<!-- /header -->

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-1157" class="post-1157 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #107 / July 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					The piano you played for Idiot Prayer was magnificent. Was it a personal instrument, or is this just the kind of thing people put in front of one when they go places?				</h1>
				<h3>ANDREW, BELLINGHAM, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/piano-you-played-for-idiot-prayer/" title="The piano you played for Idiot Prayer was magnificent. Was it a personal instrument, or is this just the kind of thing people put in front of one when they go places?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Lead-portrait-Nick-Cave-by-Joel-Ryan1.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Lead-portrait-Nick-Cave-by-Joel-Ryan1.jpg 2048w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Lead-portrait-Nick-Cave-by-Joel-Ryan1-250x231.jpg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Lead-portrait-Nick-Cave-by-Joel-Ryan1-768x710.jpg 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Lead-portrait-Nick-Cave-by-Joel-Ryan1-700x648.jpg 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Lead-portrait-Nick-Cave-by-Joel-Ryan1-120x111.jpg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 2048px) 100vw, 2048px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div>
<p>Dear Andrew,</p>
<p>The piano I played at Alexandra Palace was a Fazioli. There were limited pianos I could access during lockdown. There was, however, a Fazioli. I had never played one before but Dom Monks, the guy who recorded the Alexandra Palace performance, highly recommended this piano. The moment I sat down at the Fazioli, its warm, soft, nuanced sound spoke to me like no piano had spoken to me before. I was swept away by its extraordinary tonal range. It whispered to me. It roared at me. It was the most beautiful instrument I had ever played.</p>
<p>On a Zoom call to my manager I mentioned how much I loved the Fazioli. I reminded him that I still have the same nasty little Chinese upright I have had for over thirty years. I explained that I was sixty-three years old and suggested that perhaps it was time I got a nice piano. I said to my manager — I just love that Fazioli.</p>
<p>Now, one of the things you may or may not know about being a famous musician is that companies give you shit for free. The more famous you are, the more shit you get — you just have to wear one of their t-shirts or a branded cap or something. Being the principled individual that I am, of course, I have never sponsored a musical instrument (in that respect, I am virtually alone in my field) but I just loved that Fazioli.</p>
<p>So I said to my manager — Time to sell my soul. Time to make a call and get me a Fazioli.</p>
<p>My manager said — Consider it done!</p>
<p>So, the next day my manager rings up Fazioli, who have their headquarters in Sacile, in the Province of Pordenone, near Venice and an Italian woman answers the phone.</p>
<p>My manager says — I represent the great artist Nick Cave and I am wondering if I could get a free Fazioli (or something like that).</p>
<p>The Italian woman says — L’acttore?</p>
<p>My manager says — What?</p>
<p>She says — The actor?</p>
<p>My manager says — No, Cave. <em>Cave.</em></p>
<p>And she says — Nick what?</p>
<p>My manager says — Nick Cave.</p>
<p>She says — Nick Cave? Who issa Nick Cave?</p>
<p>My manager says — Well, he is arguably the greatest songwriter of his time. He is one of the cornerstones of modern music. He is a national treasure. He is adored by millions. <em>Italians</em> love him.</p>
<p>She says — Who are you? What you want?</p>
<p>My manager says — Um, a free piano.</p>
<p>And she hangs up.</p>
</div>
<div style="text-align: center;">
<p>* * * *</p>
</div>
<div>
<p>A couple of days later I’m on another Zoom call with my manager, and he is looking a bit cagey and I say — How did it go with Fazioli? Did you get me a free Fazioli?</p>
<p>And my manager says — Well, it seems like they have a rather inflexible policy around giving away £200,000 pianos to people they’ve never heard of.</p>
<p>And I say — Dude, are you my fucking manager or what? I just love that Fazioli!</p>
<p>So the next day my manager rings back Fazioli and the same woman answers the phone and my manager says — Look it’s Nick Cave’s manager again, can I speak to Mr Fazioli.</p>
<p>And the woman says — No.</p>
<p>And my manager says — Listen, my fucking <em>job’s</em> on the line here.</p>
<p>And she hangs up.</p>
<div>
<p style="text-align: center;">* * * *</p>
</div>
</div>
<div>
<p>So, Andrew, I agree — the Fazioli is a glorious piano. Magnificent, as you say. As Herbie Hancock said about <em>his </em>Fazioli — that ‘one note announces the celebration of the freedom and creativity of the human spirit’. This is true. The Fazioli is warm and delicate and remarkably subtle, but has a deep, strong heart. It is full of angel tears and <em>il sangue dei santi</em> and encompasses the universe. It is a dream piano.And yet I wait for the day a giant removal van will pull up outside my house, my manager hanging out the passenger window, wearing a t-shirt with a piano on it, and a big smile on his face, screaming ‘Fazioli!’</p>
<p>Until then my little Chinese upright grins at me from the corner of my room. I walk over and sit down and I begin to play.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<title>Nick Cave - The Red Hand Files - Issue #106 - I lost someone in the last year. It&#039;s unknown and unspoken territory to me. I thought it was fine. I thought it was fine. It was a gentle passing. Now shapes and echoes resound. I feel a presence that comes and goes - a comforting presence, gentle and protective. I don&#039;t understand it. I don&#039;t believe in a god that sits above. I feel a presence in all things - something mysterious and miraculous. Sometimes I gaze gently at birds and trees and am deeply moved by the life that hums in them. For I love birds and trees especially the sparrows and tall trees with wide branches. It&#039;s strange to feel so connected and yet have a feeling of being so disconnected. At times I&#039;m fine - more than fine as they are here and I forget I lost them and my memories hold the space of all things we shared. My question is I don&#039;t know how to understand the experience of loss. It&#039;s not something I could negotiate with. I hope this makes some sense. : The Red Hand Files</title>

Now shapes and echoes resound. I feel a presence that comes and goes &#8211; a comforting presence, gentle and protective. I don&#8217;t understand it. I don&#8217;t believe in a god that sits above. I feel a presence in all things &#8211; something mysterious and miraculous. Sometimes I gaze gently at birds and trees and am deeply moved by the life that hums in them. For I love birds and trees especially the sparrows and tall trees with wide branches.  It&#8217;s strange to feel so connected and yet have a feeling of being so disconnected. At times I&#8217;m fine &#8211; more than fine as they are here and I forget I lost them and my memories hold the space of all things we shared.  My question is I don&#8217;t know how to understand the experience of loss. It&#8217;s not something I could negotiate with. I hope this makes some sense.",
                "image": "https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-3.png"
            }
        }
    ]
}</script>

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-1151" class="post-1151 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #106 / July 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I lost someone in the last year. It&#8217;s unknown and unspoken territory to me. I thought it was fine. I thought it was fine. It was a gentle passing. Now shapes and echoes resound. I feel a presence that comes and goes &#8211; a comforting presence, gentle and protective. <br/>I don&#8217;t understand it. I don&#8217;t believe in a god that sits above. I feel a presence in all things &#8211; something mysterious and miraculous. Sometimes I gaze gently at birds and trees and am deeply moved by the life that hums in them. For I love birds and trees especially the sparrows and tall trees with wide branches. <br/> It&#8217;s strange to feel so connected and yet have a feeling of being so disconnected. At times I&#8217;m fine &#8211; more than fine as they are here and I forget I lost them and my memories hold the space of all things we shared.  My question is I don&#8217;t know how to understand the experience of loss. It&#8217;s not something I could negotiate with. I hope this makes some sense.				</h1>
				<h3>ROSE, MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/how-to-understand-experience-of-loss/" title="I lost someone in the last year. It&#8217;s unknown and unspoken territory to me. I thought it was fine. I thought it was fine. It was a gentle passing. Now shapes and echoes resound. I feel a presence that comes and goes &#8211; a comforting presence, gentle and protective. I don&#8217;t understand it. I don&#8217;t believe in a god that sits above. I feel a presence in all things &#8211; something mysterious and miraculous. Sometimes I gaze gently at birds and trees and am deeply moved by the life that hums in them. For I love birds and trees especially the sparrows and tall trees with wide branches.  It&#8217;s strange to feel so connected and yet have a feeling of being so disconnected. At times I&#8217;m fine &#8211; more than fine as they are here and I forget I lost them and my memories hold the space of all things we shared.  My question is I don&#8217;t know how to understand the experience of loss. It&#8217;s not something I could negotiate with. I hope this makes some sense.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-3.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-3.png 830w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-3-250x198.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-3-768x609.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-3-700x555.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-3-120x95.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 830px) 100vw, 830px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p><span lang="EN-US">Dear Rose, </span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">I have printed your letter in full as it describes very beautifully the experience of inhabiting the uncanny and disorientating realm of loss. Thank you for taking such care with it.</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">The paradoxical effect of losing a loved one is that their sudden absence can become a feverish comment on <em>that which remains</em>. That which remains rises in time from the dark with a burning physicality — a luminous super-presence — as we acquaint ourselves with this new </span><span lang="EN-US">and different world</span><span lang="EN-US">. In loss things &#8211; both animate and inanimate &#8211; take on an added intensity and meaning. </span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">I love your line —</span><br />
<em><span lang="EN-US">‘Sometimes I gaze gently at birds and trees and am deeply moved by the life that hums in them</span></em><span lang="EN-US">.’</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">I think this feeling you describe, of alertness to the inner-spirit of things — this humming — comes from a hard-earned understanding of the impermanence of things and, indeed, our own impermanence. This lesson ultimately animates and illuminates our lives. We become witnesses to the thrilling emergency of the present — a series of exquisite and burning moments, each extinguished as the next arises. These magical moments are the bright jewels of loss to which we cling. They are your <em>‘sparrows and tall trees with wide branches.’</em></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">For there is, of course, another side where we lose our resolve — we drop our guard, or just grow tired and descend into that other, darker, less-lovely world, as we disconnect and retreat deep into ourselves.</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">Rose, these revolving feelings of connection and disconnection you describe so well are the opposing forces of loss that define our lived experience. Letters like yours make a great difference because many of us inhabit this uncanny realm of loss — and <em>all </em>of us will find our way there in time.</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">Love, Nick</span></p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-1139 single-format-standard do-you-ever-collaborate-with-susie">
      <!-- Google Tag Manager (noscript) -->

height="0" width="0" style="display:none;visibility:hidden"></iframe></noscript>
<!-- End Google Tag Manager (noscript) -->
		<!-- wrapper -->
		<div class="wrapper">

			<!-- header -->
			<header class="header clear" role="banner">

					<!-- logo -->
					<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com"  class="logo">
						<!-- svg logo - toddmotto.com/mastering-svg-use-for-a-retina-web-fallbacks-with-png-script -->
						<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/themes/red-hand-files/dist/img/logo.svg" alt="Logo" class="logo__img">
						<span>The Red Hand Files</span>

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-1139" class="post-1139 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #105 / July 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Do you ever collaborate with Susie?				</h1>
				<h3>LAYLA, DUBAI</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/do-you-ever-collaborate-with-susie/" title="Do you ever collaborate with Susie?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-2.png 830w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-2-250x299.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-2-768x920.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-2-700x838.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-2-120x144.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 830px) 100vw, 830px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							'WIFE ON THE MOON #15' 3rd OCTOBER 2018							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p class="Body">Dear Layla,</p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Much of my creative energy comes from a focused exchange of ideas with other people — I would call that the </span><em><span lang="IT">collaborative spirit</span></em><span lang="EN-US">. The collaborative spirit is essentially a strategy for responding to the world. In this respect <em>The Red Hand Files </em>are a collaboration, and it is the received energy from the ever-growing number of questions that brings me back each week to this place of acknowledgement and gratitude. It feels like a shared project. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">So it is with Susie. I have been married to her for over twenty years, and our marriage itself is an ever-evolving alliance or collaboration. The work that we do — Susie with <em>The Vampire</em></span><em><span dir="RTL" lang="AR-SA">’</span></em><em><span lang="DE">s Wife,</span></em><span lang="EN-US"> and me with my own work — is a form of self-actualising that emerges from the energy of our relationship. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">It is not that I discuss my lyrics with her, rather my lyrics radiate from a life lived together. My words are not just a way of making sense of our relationship, they also participate in it, magnify it, and enhance it. It is the same with Susie</span><span dir="RTL" lang="AR-SA">’</span><span lang="EN-US">s dresses. They are ghost-like articulations of the mysterious and preternatural part of her nature, as seen through our relationship. The designing and creating of these dresses, like the writing of my words, emerge out of our shared experience; and these creative endeavours, these songs and dresses, in turn, </span><em>imagine</em><span lang="EN-US"> our relationship alive — and around and around it goes, each dreaming up the other.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">These days, there is little I do that is not done in the spirit of collaboration. We are drawn together at the behest of the world to attend to its needs. This world itself is our communal experiment — all of ours — a shared project of extraordinary complexity in which we are all participating, and through which each of our actions resound through time. We each impact upon the other, and are each in service of the other. </span><span lang="EN-US">This is the true energy of the collaborative spirit.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
<div><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1140" src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-2-250x299.png" alt="" width="250" height="299" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-2-250x299.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-2-768x920.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-2-700x838.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-2-120x144.png 120w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-2.png 830w" sizes="(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px" /></div>
<div></div>
<div style="text-align: center;">&#8216;WIFE ON THE MOON #88&#8217; 23rd MARCH 2019</div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<div></div>
<div></div>
<div><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1141" src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-3-250x299.png" alt="" width="250" height="299" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-3-250x299.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-3-768x920.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-3-700x838.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-3-120x144.png 120w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-3.png 830w" sizes="(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px" /></div>
<div></div>
<div style="text-align: center;">&#8216;WIFE ON THE MOON #236&#8217; 14th APRIL 2020</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

					<!-- nav -->
					<nav class="nav" role="navigation">
						<a href="#" class="nav__burger"></a>
						<ul><li id="menu-item-11" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-11"><a href="http://theredhandfiles.com">The Files</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-12" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-12"><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/ask-a-question/">Ask a Question</a></li>

</ul>					</nav>
					<!-- /nav -->

			</header>
			<!-- /header -->

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-1130" class="post-1130 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #104 / July 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					To further augment JP&#8217;s (Issue #102) question about political songs &#8211; is there a protest song out there that you greatly admire for the way it was written or arranged?				</h1>
				<h3>DAMIAN, MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/protest-song-that-you-greatly-admire/" title="To further augment JP&#8217;s (Issue #102) question about political songs &#8211; is there a protest song out there that you greatly admire for the way it was written or arranged?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-1.png 828w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-1-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-1-250x250.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-1-768x768.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-1-700x700.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Picture-1-1-120x120.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 828px) 100vw, 828px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Damian,</p>
<p>In 1972 Nina Simone released a live album entitled Emergency Ward! that was, by her own admission, her oppositional response to the Vietnam War. This record begins with an eighteen-minute rendition of ‘My Sweet Lord’, that could well be her greatest musical achievement. Nina Simone’s interpretation of George Harrison’s gentle cosmic entreaty ends up, in her hands, as a howl of spiritual abandonment and accusation.</p>
<p>The song begins with a thirty-second chant of —</p>
<p><em>We want Nina!</em></p>
<p><em>We want Nina!</em></p>
<p>before the band launches into a raucous reanimation of the George Harrison classic. Nina’s entry couldn’t be more casual, inside the manic energy of the song —</p>
<p><em>Oh my Lord</em></p>
<p><em>My sweet Lord</em></p>
<p>This rendition is a gospel thrill ride, with mantras, wild syncopated handclaps and weird background whoops, courtesy of the Bethany Baptist Church Junior Choir of South Jamaica, New York. The Hare Krishna chant has been removed and more ‘Hallelujahs’ have been added as Nina reaches back to her Methodist roots and proclaims —</p>
<p><em>I really want to see you, Lord</em></p>
<p><em>But it takes so long</em></p>
<p>And further on —</p>
<p><em>The world is looking for you</em></p>
<p><em>Won’t you show yourself, Lord?</em></p>
<p>then surges back in, each time with increased abandon. At around six minutes there is an exquisite breakdown and Nina’s plea grows more pressing —</p>
<p><em>I really want to see you</em></p>
<p><em>I really need to see you</em></p>
<p><em>But everything today is a killer</em></p>
<p><em>Today is a killer</em></p>
<p><em>Today is a killer</em></p>
<p><em>How am I gonna see you?</em></p>
<p><em>Nobody has taught us any patience, Lord</em></p>
<p><em>And now it is too late, too late, my Lord</em></p>
<p>And yet again the song storms back in, the sense of cosmic desertion growing stronger and stronger. Each breakdown, each entreaty, each surge becomes more fraught, as if the whole world is fracturing and collapsing around Nina’s petitions.</p>
<p>At twelve minutes Nina incorporates a poem by David Nelson of The Last Poets and the song falls into a kind of weird reverie —</p>
<p><em>I often sit there in the sea</em></p>
<p><em>And dream dreams</em></p>
<p><em>And hope hopes</em></p>
<p><em>And wish wishes</em></p>
<p><em>And I listen to the wind song</em></p>
<p><em>As it dances a beautiful dance for me</em></p>
<p><em>But these moments never last long…</em></p>
<p>And there is a further rupturing of the narrative as Nina drags us into the sudden horror of the historical moment, with lines like —</p>
<p><em>Comes the reality of today</em></p>
<p><em>Grinning its all-knowing, fiendish grin</em></p>
<p><em>Pressing his ugly face against mine</em></p>
<p><em>Staring at me with lifeless eyes</em></p>
<p><em>Crumbling away all memories of yesterday’s dreams</em></p>
<p><em>Because today is a killer</em></p>
<p><em>And only you can save us, Lord</em></p>
<p>Nina still beseeching, still calling into the vacuum —</p>
<p><em>I certainly never hoped</em></p>
<p><em>That one day I&#8217;d be screaming</em></p>
<p><em>Something my mother told me I needed</em></p>
<p><em>In the beginning</em></p>
<p><em>In the beginning</em></p>
<p><em>In the beginning</em></p>
<p>and then a long held note, an ululation cast into the roaring void, as her meditation turns finally, to condemn the indifferent heavens and her ‘sweet Lord’ for his ultimate betrayal —</p>
<p><em>Today, where are you, Lord?</em></p>
<p><strong><em>YOU ARE A KILLER!</em></strong></p>
<p>The great Nina Simone was a living grievance machine — her race, her gender, her misused talents (she wanted to be a classical pianist) — and this rage infused all her work, and is what makes it so multi-layered. Even her most beautiful love songs, which I count as some of the most incandescent works of art ever recorded, were marinated in a sense of resentment and contempt for the workings of the world. It is this exhilarating collision of opposing forces — love and scorn — that makes Nina Simone’s existential and political protestations so compelling.</p>
<p>In this extraordinarily bold statement, Nina Simone stands defiant in the face of spiritual oblivion, and a world (and God) that so readily allows war and senseless carnage to occur. It is a protest song par excellence that serves as a form of transport, a vehicle that takes us on a complex and nuanced journey into transcendent rage. The song itself becomes a forge of fury, where Nina Simone stands conflicted and defiant and, in the final lines, pulls the heavens crashing down around our ears.</p>
<p>Perhaps, this is the voice of protest we need right now — intelligent, questing, transcendent, raging and thrillingly complex —</p>
<p><em>We want Nina!</em></p>
<p><em>We want Nina!</em></p>
<p>Indeed.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

					<!-- logo -->
					<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com"  class="logo">
						<!-- svg logo - toddmotto.com/mastering-svg-use-for-a-retina-web-fallbacks-with-png-script -->

						<span>The Red Hand Files</span>

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-1122" class="post-1122 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #103 / July 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					If you feel that he is beside you&#8230; and within you, why would you need to look for him? (This is not a challenge, there is no aggression in this question; I simply want you to think about it and elucidate).				</h1>
				<h3>TOM, MANCHESTER, UK</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/if-he-is-beside-you/" title="If you feel that he is beside you&#8230; and within you, why would you need to look for him? (This is not a challenge, there is no aggression in this question; I simply want you to think about it and elucidate).">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Unknown.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Unknown.png 652w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Unknown-250x378.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Unknown-120x181.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 652px) 100vw, 652px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							PHOTOGRAPH BY HENRI SENDERS							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">What is love for you?</h1>
<h3>PABLO, GUARDAMA DEL SEGURA, SPAIN</h3>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<p>Dear Tom and Pablo,</p>
<p>The voice in ‘Ghosteen Speaks’ is not my own. It is the emergent expression of an invisible, migratory spirit — the <em>Ghosteen</em>. It is the spirit of love and mercy. Throughout the song, the Ghosteen announces its presence — <em>I am beside you. Look for me.</em></p>
<p>It says — <em>I am invisible, but I am here. Search for me, and you will find me.</em></p>
<p>It calls to the compassionate act of witnessing — of seeing.</p>
<p>Love has something to do with the notion of being seen — the opposite of invisibility. The invisible, the unwitnessed, the unacknowledged, the isolated, the lonely — these are the unloved. Loving attention illuminates the unseen, escorting them from the frontiers of lovelessness into the observed world. To truly see someone — anyone — is an act that acknowledges and forgives our common and imperfect humanity. Love enacts a kind of vigilant perception — whether it is to a partner, a child, a co-worker, a neighbour, a fellow citizen, or any other person one may encounter in this life. Love says softly — <em>I see you. I recognise you. You are human, as am I.</em></p>
<p>To pay witness to another, in an alert and loving manner, is essentially an act of forgiveness for it is to acknowledge with compassion our mutual human capacity for <em>all</em> things, both good and evil.</p>
<p>When we reduce each other to symbols or representations, rather than see each other as the complex, flawed human beings that we are, we engage in the very antithesis of mercy — heartlessness, condemnation and sanctimoniousness. Within this baleful clamour the luminous spirits of compassion retreat.</p>
<p><em>I am beside you. Look for me </em>— call the windswept voices of love, to all that have the forbearance to hear.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-1117" class="post-1117 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #102 / June 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I love your music and its ability to relate common suffering, as you have discussed in the past. Do you ever look back at your anthology and wish you had been more overtly politically outspoken &#8211; referring to activism rather than politics per se &#8211; in your art?				</h1>
				<h3>JP, AUCKLAND, NEW ZEALAND</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/do-wish-more-politically-outspoken/" title="I love your music and its ability to relate common suffering, as you have discussed in the past. Do you ever look back at your anthology and wish you had been more overtly politically outspoken &#8211; referring to activism rather than politics per se &#8211; in your art?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-2.png 830w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-2-250x166.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-2-768x509.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-2-700x464.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-2-120x80.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 830px) 100vw, 830px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							PHOTO BY GOSHA RUBCHINSKIY							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div>
<p>Dear JP,</p>
<p>Perhaps the thing you enjoy about my songs is that they are conflicted, and often deal in uncertainties and ambiguities. My better songs seem to be engaged in an interior struggle between opposing outlooks or states of mind. They rarely settle on anything. My songs sit in that liminal space between decided points of view.</p>
<p>Songs with political agendas inhabit a different space. They have little patience for nuance, neutrality or impartiality. Their aim is to get the message across in as clear and persuasive a manner as possible. There can be great value in these sorts of songs, but they are usually born from a particular combination of rigidity and zealousness, which I personally do not possess. My songs seem to be resistant to fixed, inflexible points of view. They have, as you say, a concern for common, non-hierarchical suffering. They are not in the business of saving the world; rather they are in the business of saving <em>the soul</em> of the world.</p>
<p>Sometimes my songs speak into the current situation and sometimes they do not. I am mostly happy with that. I am happy that people can come to my songs and — even though they may be challenging or confronting — they do not preach and do not divide, and are offered to everyone, without exception.</p>
<p>I have very little control over what songs I write. They are constructed, incrementally, in the smallest of ways, the greater meaning revealing itself after the fact. They are often slippery, amorphous things, with unclear trajectories — position-free attempts at understanding the mysteries of the heart. I guess I could write a protest song, but I think I would, in the end, feel compromised in doing so, not because there aren’t things I am fundamentally opposed to — there are — but because I would be using my particular talents to deal with something I consider to be morally obvious. Personally, I have little inclination to do that. It’s just not what I do.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-1113" class="post-1113 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #101 / June 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Would you consider compiling a list of 40 books you love?				</h1>
				<h3>VICTORIA, KENILWORTH, WARWICKSHIRE, UK</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/would-you-consider-compiling-a-list-of-40-books-you-love/" title="Would you consider compiling a list of 40 books you love?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-1.png 828w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-1-250x356.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-1-768x1093.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-1-700x996.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-1-120x171.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 828px) 100vw, 828px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							ATTAR OF NISHAPUR							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Victoria,</p>
<p>Normally, to answer this question I would simply go to my bookshelves and choose forty books. However, my bookshelves are completely empty. The 5000+ books I have accumulated over the years have been shipped to the Royal Danish Library in Copenhagen. They are now part of the completely mind-blowing, heart-stopping Stranger Than Kindness exhibition. Without my library in front of me it is a little difficult to assemble a comprehensive list of my forty most loved books. The best I can do is throw together a rather formless and incoherent grab bag of titles that come to mind at this moment that, for one reason or another, I have loved over the years. I think I got carried away. I think there are fifty — in no particular order.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>American Dreams</strong> – Sapphire</p>
<p><strong>Break, Blow, Burn</strong> – Camille Paglia</p>
<p><strong>The Largesse of the Sea Maiden</strong> – Denis Johnson</p>
<p><strong>The Collected Poems of Langston Hughes</strong></p>
<p><strong>A Good Man is Hard to Find</strong> – Flannery O&#8217;Connor</p>
<p><strong>I and Thou</strong> – Martin Buber</p>
<p><strong>Straight Life</strong> – Art Pepper</p>
<p><strong>The Bible</strong> – King James Edition</p>
<p><strong>Things Fall Apart</strong> – Chinua Achebe</p>
<p><strong>High Windows</strong> – Philip Larkin</p>
<p><strong>The Conference of Birds</strong> – Attar of Nishapur</p>
<p><strong>My Promised Land</strong> – Ari Shavit</p>
<p><strong>The Christ at Chartres</strong> – Denis Saurat</p>
<p><strong>King Leopold&#8217;s Ghost</strong> – Adam Hochschild</p>
<p><strong>America a Prophecy</strong> – Jerome Rothenberg</p>
<p><strong>Ariel</strong> – Sylvia Plath</p>
<p><strong>The Book of Ebenezer Le Page</strong> – Gerald Basil Edwards</p>
<p><strong>The English and Scottish Popular Ballads </strong></p>
<p><strong>The Collected Poems</strong> <strong>of Emily Dickinson</strong></p>
<p><strong>Shaking the Pumpkin </strong> – Jerome Rothenberg</p>
<p><strong>The Killer Inside Me </strong>– Jim Thompson</p>
<p><strong>The Collected Works of Saint Teresa of Avila</strong></p>
<p><strong>Moby Dick</strong> – Herman Melville</p>
<p><strong>The Mayor of Casterbridge </strong> – Thomas Hardy</p>
<p><strong>Mid-American Chants</strong> – Sherwood Anderson</p>
<p><strong>Collected Works of Billy the Kid </strong>– Michael Ondaatje</p>
<p><strong>American Murder Ballads</strong> <strong>and Their Stories </strong>– Olive Woolley Burt</p>
<p><strong>Poems of W. B. Yeats</strong> – Selected by Seamus Heaney</p>
<p><strong>The Good Lord Bird</strong> – James McBride</p>
<p><strong>Consolations </strong>– David Whyte</p>
<p><strong>Roget’s Thesaurus</strong> – Peter Mark Roget</p>
<p><strong>Here I Am</strong> – Jonathan Safran Foer</p>
<p><strong>Lives of the Saints </strong>– Alban Butler</p>
<p><strong>Inferno/From an Occult Diary</strong> – August Strindberg</p>
<p><strong>Poems 1959-2009</strong> – Frederick Seidel</p>
<p><strong>S.C.U.M Manifesto </strong>– Valerie Solanas</p>
<p><strong>Complete Poems of E. E. Cummings</strong></p>
<p><strong>The Anatomy of Melancholy</strong> – Robert Burton</p>
<p><strong>Dave Robicheaux Novels</strong> – James Lee Burke</p>
<p><strong>Victory</strong> – Joseph Conrad</p>
<p><strong>A Flower Book for the Pocket</strong> – Macgregor Skene</p>
<p><strong>The Informers</strong> – Bret Easton Ellis</p>
<p><strong>The Frog Prince</strong> – Stevie Smith</p>
<p><strong>Pale Fire </strong>– Vladimir Nabokov</p>
<p><strong>Sanctuary</strong> – William Faulkner</p>
<p><strong>Short Stories of Anton Chekhov</strong></p>
<p><strong>The Factory Series</strong> – Derek Raymond</p>
<p><strong>The Dream Songs</strong> – John Berryman</p>
<p><strong>Man’s Search for Meaning </strong>– Viktor Frankl</p>
<p><strong>Walkabout</strong> – James Vance Marshall</p>

As a recovering heroin addict, I am having difficulty getting into the Narcotics Anonymous scene. I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA? 			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #100 / June 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					[ ] My question today is on a personal note, if you would have a gold ring made that your son would inherit one day, what would you have engraved inside the ring? (I am currently having a ring made that I want my son to have after my day).				</h1>
				<h3>HAJALTI, REYKJAVIK, ICELAND</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/engraved-inside-the-ring/" title="[ ] My question today is on a personal note, if you would have a gold ring made that your son would inherit one day, what would you have engraved inside the ring? (I am currently having a ring made that I want my son to have after my day).">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1.png 830w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-250x299.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-768x920.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-700x838.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Picture-1-120x144.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 830px) 100vw, 830px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Dear Hajalti,</p>
<p>I would have inscribed</p>
<p><span style="font-size: 20px;"><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-family: apple chancery,georgia,times new roman,serif;"><strong>I am beside you</strong></span></span></span></p>
<p>inside the ring.</p>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
<p>PS Thank you all for staying with me as we reach the hundredth Red Hand File.</p>
</div>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>

          <h5><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-do-you-think-about-na/" title="What do you think about NA? As a recovering heroin addict, I am having difficulty getting into the Narcotics Anonymous scene. I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA? As a recovering heroin addict, I am having difficulty getting into the Narcotics Anonymous scene. I see how it can help but I feel ...’</a></h5>
        </li>
              </ul>

      </div>
		</div>

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-1092" class="post-1092 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #99 / May 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I feel that our identity is a patchwork of desires, choices, affiliation, eccentricity. [ ] I found that, sometimes, those identities that inhabit me are in conflict and it is hard to cope with this lack of coherence. Do you have any thoughts on how to make our inner selves &#8220;coherent&#8221; or how to let all the bits fit together? Do you think that is necessary?				</h1>
				<h3>ELEONORA, BRUSSELS, BELGIUM</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/identity-coherent-fit-together/" title="I feel that our identity is a patchwork of desires, choices, affiliation, eccentricity. [ ] I found that, sometimes, those identities that inhabit me are in conflict and it is hard to cope with this lack of coherence. Do you have any thoughts on how to make our inner selves &#8220;coherent&#8221; or how to let all the bits fit together? Do you think that is necessary?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-4.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-4.png 830w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-4-250x375.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-4-768x1151.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-4-700x1049.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-4-120x180.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 830px) 100vw, 830px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">What do you personally look for in an artist?</h1>
<h3>MAX, HAMBURG, GERMANY</h3>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<p><span lang="EN-US">Dear Eleonora and Max,</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">I think that for some of us it is almost impossible to have a cohesive identity or, rather, there are some whose inconsistent and conflicted sense of self <em>is </em>their identity. There are those who have an identity that is contrary and evolving and forever at war with itself. It is perpetually in the process of challenging its own best ideas. Once an idea of self — a stance, a point of view, an identity — is settled upon, this inner subversive begins the business of dismantling it. Yet, this resistance to a fixed identity could be our greatest strength.</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">Perhaps I inherited this tendency from my father, who had, to say the least, a perverse and contrary view of the world, or maybe it is because I was born between star signs, or it could just be the old boomer in me that continues to have a nostalgic fondness for disruption and chaos, but I have forever felt a horror of being boxed in by an identity and an inflexible opinion, for this allegiance to a single personae can be the very death of creativity.</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">Maybe, Eleonora, there is some advantage in not having those ‘bits fit together’. This lack of cohesion prevents us from being enslaved by absolutes — what is true and what is not true, what is the right way to be and what is the wrong way to be — and affords us the ability to embrace contradictory ideas at the same time. </span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">For an artist, particularly a songwriter, this ability to be open to influence, to discard personae, gives us the freedom to express ourselves in contrasting ways. When I think about the artists who have had the greatest impact on me, this fluctuating and disordered identity, and necessity to reinvent themselves, is common to most of them. I think this is what I look for in an artist — the ability to change, and to grow, and to confound.</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">Love, Nick</span></p>
</div>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA? 				<h2>Issue #98 / May 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Sometimes in the morning in order to rouse my spirits, I need to plug into my amp and play very distorted guitar and drown my world in sound. However, the cat that sleeps in my room is very put out by this, and I don&#8217;t want to disturb him. How do I resolve this conundrum?				</h1>
				<h3>JONATHAN, CALIFORNIA, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/the-cat-is-very-put-out/" title="Sometimes in the morning in order to rouse my spirits, I need to plug into my amp and play very distorted guitar and drown my world in sound. 		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-1078" class="post-1078 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #97 / May 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I recently stumbled across your interview in GQ magazine &#8220;The love and terror of Nick Cave&#8221; and was impressed by your brutal honesty when answering such personal questions. Are you that honest with yourself?				</h1>
				<h3>MARK, MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/are-you-honest-with-yourself/" title="I recently stumbled across your interview in GQ magazine &#8220;The love and terror of Nick Cave&#8221; and was impressed by your brutal honesty when answering such personal questions. Are you that honest with yourself?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-2.png 830w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-2-250x332.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-2-768x1020.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-2-700x929.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-2-120x159.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 830px) 100vw, 830px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							CLEARING IN THE FOREST BY CASPAR DAVID FRIEDRICH							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">How many Red Hand File questions do you get a week and how do you choose which to respond to?</h1>
<h3>PAUL, PORTLAND, USA</h3>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Mark and Paul,</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">The poet David Whyte wrote, </span>“<span lang="EN-US">The fear of loss is the motivator behind all conscious and unconscious dishonesties.</span>” <span lang="EN-US">I found there to be so much truth in these words. After my son died and I eventually stepped from the darkness back into the world, I brought with me a gift that I feel I am only beginning to understand. </span>“<span lang="EN-US">The gauntlet with a gift in it,</span>” <span lang="EN-US">as Elizabeth Barrett Browning so beautifully wrote. I felt that my family and I had been tested and that we had survived, and this gift that I carried was the freedom to be honest with myself and with others — as there was nothing left to conceal. The protective shell that I had constructed around myself, my old life, had been torn away. I had been exposed, and I had nothing left to defend. The gift in the gauntlet was a new and raw honesty toward myself and toward the world.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Because, you see, the world had done its worst. What harm was left to be done? What remained to fear? What was left to lose that I could not survive? I felt extraordinarily liberated by this, protected by the calamity itself and perversely invincible within my own vulnerability. Deception, artifice and keeping up appearances took up too much energy — I didn</span>’<span lang="EN-US">t have the stamina for my own pretence and little patience for it in others.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Honesty is simply a declaration of one</span>’<span lang="EN-US">s own vulnerability — it is its keen, bright edge — and my own vulnerability and the vulnerability of others became, in the end, a kind of shared armour. I learned that, ultimately, our own truth and sense of self is all any of us have. We are enough, if we could only allow ourselves to be.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">This is the great value of </span><em><span lang="DE">The Red Hand Files</span></em><span lang="EN-US">. The questions that come in, so often naked and damaged and honest, offer me a form of salvation. I am the only one who accesses these questions, as I enter a sequestered world of mutual need. I read the questions each day, maybe fifty or so, sometimes more. It is like reading weird, brutal subterranean poetry, and like poetry they need to be read closely and with care. This exercise has become an essential part of my daily work. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">The ones I feel I can answer I put into a file. Then when the time comes to write something I choose a question that feels in need of a response. The particular question always leaps out at me, as if waiting its turn to be answered. I feel at home among these questions, exalted and protected by them. It is an absolute honour to be a part of this undertaking, whatever it is and wherever it may lead. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
<div></div>
</div>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->

I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA? <link rel='dns-prefetch' href='//s.w.org' />

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-1071" class="post-1071 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #96 / May 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Last evening I spent some time watching the mesmerizing Bad Seed TeeVee and I learned that the Night Raid line &#8220;I slid my little songs out from under you&#8221; was actually written years before. I think this line can paint the complete portrait of a man and tell his lifetime story in a handful of words. Could you write something more about its origin and how it found its way into this particular song?				</h1>
				<h3>NATASHA, CASTELLO D'ARGILE, ITALY</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/i-slid-my-little-songs-out-from-under-you/" title="Last evening I spent some time watching the mesmerizing Bad Seed TeeVee and I learned that the Night Raid line &#8220;I slid my little songs out from under you&#8221; was actually written years before. I think this line can paint the complete portrait of a man and tell his lifetime story in a handful of words. Could you write something more about its origin and how it found its way into this particular song?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-1.png 828w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-1-250x352.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-1-768x1082.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-1-700x986.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-1-120x169.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 828px) 100vw, 828px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							PAINTING BY ALEKSANDRA WALISZEWSKA							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">I don&#8217;t mean to be morbid, [ ] but what do you want written on your gravestone?</h1>
<h3>FRANK, DETROIT, USA</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">Bad Seed TeeVee. Thank you, thank you,<br />
thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you,<br />
thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you,<br />
thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you,<br />
thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you, thank you,<br />
thank you. Do you appreciate how much joy you have brought to your fans with this wonderful and most generous gift?</h1>
<h3>ANJA, HARWICK, ESSEX, UK</h3>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<p>Dear Natasha, Frank and Anja.</p>
<p>I wrote the line &#8211;</p>
<p>I slide my little songs out from under you</p>
<p>on the evening of the 5th of July 2014.</p>
<p>I know this because I refer to it in the Portland section of The Sick Bag Song, the epic poem I composed chronicling The Bad Seeds 2014 North American tour. I wrote &#8211;</p>
<p>‘Tonight I wrote down this line in the alley<br />
Behind the Arlene Schnitzer Concert Hall<br />
In Portland, Oregon<br />
Where I smoked and sat,<br />
I slide my little songs out from under you<br />
And I was very happy with that.’</p>
<p>What I meant by ‘very happy with that’ was that I felt a blissful pulse of prophecy calling from the future, that this line, written in an alley, in Portland, had an ulterior destiny that would in time reveal itself.</p>
<p>It appeared again in the Los Angeles section of The Sick Bag Song &#8211;</p>
<p>‘I cast a giant shadow against the sky.<br />
Like a miniature deity I gaze into the brown water.<br />
I slide my little songs out from under you.<br />
I am a small god crawling around a giant world,<br />
Becoming an engorged god crawling around a small world.’</p>
<p>But happy as I was with the line, and indeed the whole of The Sick Bag Song, I felt that I needed to position it within an actual song, so I spent the next six years trying to do just that. This became increasingly difficult, as every song I tried to put it in rejected it. It was just too good, I guess, and the other lines knew it. I remember one mercifully aborted song lyric went something like &#8211;</p>
<p>‘Praise be your za-zen legs and kundalini stew<br />
I slide my little songs out from under you’</p>
<p>Looking through my notebook I see it even tried its luck in an early version of ‘Rings of Saturn’ &#8211;</p>
<p>‘As she jumps up with her leaping brain<br />
I slide my little songs out from under her<br />
Stepping over piles of sleeping children’</p>
<p>But ‘Rings of Saturn’ would have none of it and the line was (thankfully) shunned and, once again, sent into exile.</p>
<p>Then it turned up on a potential B-side from the Skeleton Tree sessions called ‘Life Per Se’, which you saw me trying to teach the band on the 40 minute jam in One More Time With Feeling &#8211;</p>
<p>‘What then to do? What then to do?<br />
I slide my little songs out from under you’</p>
<p>But this song, beautiful though it was, didn’t end up on an actual record, so the line still had no place to lay its head.</p>
<p>The line seemed, as you pointed out, Natasha, to sum up everything &#8211; a life’s work, a credo, an ideology. I felt the line struck at the heart of the matter &#8211; that my songs were small studies in a larger project &#8211; the glorification of the ones I love.</p>
<p>In the end it found its way into ‘Night Raid’ from Ghosteen &#8211;</p>
<p>‘Sitting on the edge of the bed clicking your shoes<br />
I slid my little songs out from under you’</p>
<p>A near perfect place for it really, as ‘Night Raid’ is concerned mostly with the act of impregnation, of conception, of genesis, and the line &#8211;</p>
<p>‘I slid my little songs out from under you’</p>
<p>felt like the feminine counterweight to the overwrought masculinity of &#8211;</p>
<p>‘The spurting font of creativity, yeah I know’</p>
<p>This lovely line allowed the yang seed to fertilise the yin egg, up in Room 33, and birth what, in my opinion, may be the most beautiful and joyful song on the album.</p>
<p>But even so, I am still not completely sure the line has found its final resting place. It feels that it was created for a grander purpose, to be chiselled in granite, in a Luminari font, maybe; so, if it comes down to it, Frank, this is what I want on my gravestone &#8211;</p>
<p><span style="font-size: 20px;"><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-family: luminari,georgia,times new roman,serif;"><strong>I SLIDE MY LITTLE SONGS OUT FROM UNDER YOU</strong></span></span></span></p>
<p>unless, of course, I think of a better line in the meantime.</p>
<p>Which brings me to Bad Seed TeeVee &#8211; thanks to all of you who have written in about it. Bad Seed TeeVee is in its infant stages, and now the project is up and running, mountains of new footage is flooding in from everywhere. We are besieged! In time, perhaps we will invite fans to send in interesting stuff they have shot on their phones while they were supposed to have been watching the concert. We want Bad Seed TeeVee to become a vast, ever-mutating monster &#8211; full of the bold, the beautiful, the berserk and the completely absurd. Thank you all so much for tuning in &#8211; at last we all have a place to go!</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
</div>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

Like my son, never one to be told what to do, I found it comforting and consoling but am still struggling with a reason to continue in this mostly beautiful yet, too often, painful world. How have you and your family been able to create meaning through such devastation? : The Red Hand Files</title>

<meta name="description" content="Dear Carol and Luna, Susie and I have learned much about the nature of grief over recent years. We have come to see that grief is not something you pass..."/>

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-1063" class="post-1063 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #95 / May 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					After the sudden and tragic death of our beautiful son, Dominic, my brother recommended for me not to listen to &#8216;Ghosteen&#8217;. Like my son, never one to be told what to do, I found it comforting and consoling but am still struggling with a reason to continue in this mostly beautiful yet, too often, painful world. How have you and your family been able to create meaning through such devastation?				</h1>
				<h3>CAROL, STOCKTON-ON-TEES, UK</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/create-meaning-through-devastation/" title="After the sudden and tragic death of our beautiful son, Dominic, my brother recommended for me not to listen to &#8216;Ghosteen&#8217;. Like my son, never one to be told what to do, I found it comforting and consoling but am still struggling with a reason to continue in this mostly beautiful yet, too often, painful world. How have you and your family been able to create meaning through such devastation?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1.png 830w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-250x224.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-768x688.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-700x627.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Picture-1-120x108.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 830px) 100vw, 830px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">I am 16 weeks and three days in at losing my child, and although I have found solace in your last three albums, I am a truth seeker in the depths of grief. Aside from moving furniture, how did Susie and yourself find peace with your agonising grief?</h1>
<h3>LUNA, AUCKLAND, NEW ZEALAND</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p>Dear Carol and Luna,</p>
<p>Susie and I have learned much about the nature of grief over recent years. We have come to see that grief is not something you pass through, as there is no other side. For us, grief became a way of life, an approach to living, where we learned to yield to the uncertainty of the world, whilst maintaining a stance of defiance to its indifference. We surrendered to something over which we had no control, but which we refused to take lying down. Grief became both an act of submission and of resistance — a place of acute vulnerability where, over time, we developed a heightened sense of the brittleness of existence. Eventually, this awareness of life’s fragility led us back to the world, transformed.</p>
<p>We discovered that grief was much more than just despair. We found grief contained many things — happiness, empathy, commonality, sorrow, fury, joy, forgiveness, combativeness, gratitude, awe, and even a certain peace. For us, grief became an attitude, a belief system, a doctrine — a conscious inhabiting of our vulnerable selves, protected and enriched by the absence of the one we loved and that we lost.</p>
<p>In the end, grief is an entirety. It is doing the dishes, watching Netflix, reading a book, Zooming friends, sitting alone or, indeed, shifting furniture around. Grief is all things reimagined through the ever emerging wounds of the world. It revealed to us that we had no control over events, and as we confronted our powerlessness, we came to see this powerlessness as a kind of spiritual freedom.</p>
<p>Susie’s grief has become part of her chemistry, it moves through her bloodstream like a force, and though she often inhabits the liminal space at the edge of dreams, she remains strong in her powerlessness and obstinately awed by the workings of the world.</p>
<p>Susie says to tell you she is very sorry to hear of your losses, very sorry, and looking at her now, I can only say to you both, that in time, <em>there is a way,</em> not out of grief, but deep within it.</p>
<p>With love to you both, Nick</p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA? I&#039;m not sure what that says about Rising Signs, but it made me wonder - [ ] Is originality in music sometimes hard to obtain? : The Red Hand Files</title>
