	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-941" class="post-941 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #80 / January 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					It&#8217;s fucking hard to write to Nick Cave. I&#8217;m currently (and have been for the past 9 years) emulating your rock n&#8217; roll persona in a Nick Cave tribute band. I dress up like you (a cheap version, no stylist, can&#8217;t find a shirt like yours) and in a shamanistic way recreate your live performances, sometimes succeeding to trick the audience into a feeling of being nearer to you. I&#8217;m sorry if you feel I am a vampire sucking on you, but I&#8217;m not ready to &#8220;do my own thing&#8221;. In the name of the Cave Dogs (the tribute band from Serbia, not the power pop band from Boston) I have to ask you if you know of us, and what do you think of us?				</h1>
				<h3>NIK, BELGRADE, SERBIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/cave-dogs-know-of-us/" title="It&#8217;s fucking hard to write to Nick Cave. I&#8217;m currently (and have been for the past 9 years) emulating your rock n&#8217; roll persona in a Nick Cave tribute band. I dress up like you (a cheap version, no stylist, can&#8217;t find a shirt like yours) and in a shamanistic way recreate your live performances, sometimes succeeding to trick the audience into a feeling of being nearer to you. I&#8217;m sorry if you feel I am a vampire sucking on you, but I&#8217;m not ready to &#8220;do my own thing&#8221;. In the name of the Cave Dogs (the tribute band from Serbia, not the power pop band from Boston) I have to ask you if you know of us, and what do you think of us?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-2.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-2-250x299.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-2-768x918.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-2-700x837.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-2-120x143.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							NIK, CAVE DOGS							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">Watch <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aBS5PwMoW9Q"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">here</span>.</a></h1>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<p>Dear Nik,</p>
<p>I was not familiar with the Cave Dogs, I am afraid, but having watched you on YouTube, I have this to say — you sound fucking <em>terrifyingly</em> like me. You have even perfected my peculiar relationship with the Gods of Intonation. In fact, when I was playing it Susie, my wife, walked in the room with her arms full of dresses and fabric swatches and said, “Wo! Babe, you’re sounding good.” And I’m like, “Thanks. It’s not me. It’s a Serbian imposter.” And she says, “Oh, sorry,” and walks out again. So, you are obviously doing something right. But you are also correct to suggest you don’t have the right shirt. If you send me your email address, I’ll send you one of my old ones and a suit — I have many — or a hit squad. I’m not sure which.</p>
<p>Love, the other Nick</p>
</div>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

        </li>

          <h4><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/pet-theory-your-creativity-flourish/">Issue #121</a><br>-</h4>

As a recovering heroin addict, I am having difficulty getting into the Narcotics Anonymous scene. I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA? 							<div class="content__gdpr">

									<label class="checkbox subfield" for="gdpr_13"><input type="checkbox" id="gdpr_13" name="gdpr[13]" value="Y" class="av-checkbox " checked><span>Email</span> </label> </label>
								</fieldset>
							</div>

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-934" class="post-934 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #79 / January 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					With your new sound, you don&#8217;t fear losing old fans?				</h1>
				<h3>MATH, BORDEAUX, FRANCE</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/fear-losing-old-fans/" title="With your new sound, you don&#8217;t fear losing old fans?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-1.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-1-250x164.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-1-768x505.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-1-700x460.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-1-120x79.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							PHOTO BY GOSHA RUBCHINSKIY							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">Do you like Kanye?</h1>
<h3>NAJA, LOS ANGELES, USA</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Math and Naja,</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">We love and respect our fans, both past and present, but, of course, they are free to come and go as they please. What The Bad Seeds are trying to do is to nurture our listeners, to challenge and confront them, to make records that create some kind of dissonance, and perhaps even disturb them, but hopefully ultimately move them. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Losing fans is the collateral damage that comes from engaging in music from an artistic perspective, rather than a commercial one. Making music specifically to please fans can be patronising and exploitative. Challenging music, by its very nature, alienates some fans whilst inspiring others, but without that dissonance, there is no conversation, there is no risk, there are no tears and there are no smiles, and <em>nobody</em> is moved and <em>nobody</em> is affected!</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">For some of us, moments of genuine emotional resonance are rare; we are besieged by insincere forces and have become cynical and suspicious of the world. Many letters to <em>The Red Hand Files</em> signal a despair and anger toward the way the world operates, but they also display a deep love of beauty and a need for meaning. We want to make records that do not add to the hollow clamour that surrounds us but instead challenge people and guide them toward meaning. As I’ve said before, how we achieve this is, to an extent, out of our hands. As a band, we can only move toward what stirs us and this generally exists within the unfamiliar and unconventional. In this place, we are challenged, even unnerved, but ultimately rewarded and we hope that our fans are too. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">With each new record, almost inevitably some fans will move on. I can only say that I am truly grateful to have been a part of their journey, and </span><span lang="EN-US">that </span><span lang="EN-US">they have been part of ours. In the end, to challenge our fans is to love them, even if it means losing them. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA" style="text-align: center;"><span lang="EN-US">***  </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Making art is a form of madness &#8211; we slip deep within our own singular vision and become lost to it. There is no musician on Earth that is as committed to their own derangement as Kanye, and in this respect, at this point in time, he is our greatest artist.  </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-925" class="post-925 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #78 / January 2020</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Please tell us everything you can about the song &#8216;Hollywood&#8217;. It&#8217;s one of the most powerful pieces of music I&#8217;ve ever heard, and I want to know everything you can tell me.				</h1>
				<h3>JON, OSLO, NORWAY</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/tell-us-everything-about-hollywood/" title="Please tell us everything you can about the song &#8216;Hollywood&#8217;. It&#8217;s one of the most powerful pieces of music I&#8217;ve ever heard, and I want to know everything you can tell me.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-250x166.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-768x511.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-700x466.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-1-120x80.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">Do you think that your songs tell the future?</h1>
<h3>SUSAN, AUSTIN, USA</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Jon and Susan,</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">At around 8</span>’ 30’’ <span lang="EN-US">into the song </span>‘<span lang="DA">Hollywood</span>’ <span lang="EN-US">the narrator stands on the beach, looking out to sea. Malibu is on fire and the animals have been driven down from the hills to the shore. A sea serpent rises out of the ocean. A small boy drops his bucket and spade and climbs into the sun. Jon, this series of images came to me while in the back of a car driving around your city of Oslo on the last Bad Seeds’</span><span lang="FR"> tour</span><span lang="EN-US">,</span> <span lang="EN-US">and was the first step toward the writing of </span><em>Ghosteen</em><span lang="EN-US">. Within this sudden vision the whole of the album presented itself. It is rare in songwriting to be given such a rich and sustaining gift.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Some months later I wrote what would become the second verse of </span>‘<span lang="DA">Hollywood</span>’ &#8211; <span lang="EN-US">the image of my wife, as a white cougar with </span>‘<span lang="EN-US">a terrible engine of wrath for a heart</span>’<span lang="EN-US">, roaming the Hollywood Hills. This single image of rage-filled, carnivorous grief sat in my notebook waiting for a home.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">The Buddhist story of Kisa and the Mustard Seed, that would eventually be the final part of </span>‘<span lang="DA">Hollywood</span>’<span lang="EN-US">, had been of great significance and comfort to me for years and at some point I jotted it down in verse form, completely independent of anything else, and with no intention of it being a song.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: center;">***</p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Early in 2018, at the initial </span>‘<span lang="IT">improv</span>’ <span lang="EN-US">recording sessions in Brighton, Warren threw down the driving </span>‘<span lang="DA">Hollywood</span>’ <span lang="EN-US">loop and at the same time played the beautiful circular synth chords. Meanwhile, I sat jamming at the piano and dumping lyrics onto it. I had all these disparate images rolling around in my head, unmoored and desperate for a home &#8211; Malibu on fire, the cougar roaming the hills, the terrified animals on the shore, the breaching leviathan, the kid and the sun, Kisa and her baby &#8211; and the restless propulsion of the loop allowed me to just spill them out. I didn</span>’<span lang="EN-US">t at the time know what they meant, or how they connected to each other. We played non-stop for hours, lost to it. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Listening back, in the studio a week or so later, most of the extended jam was unusable, but there was a fifteen minute section, towards the end, that was mysterious and compelling and so we edited it out and kept it. It included within it the cougar scene, the beach and the fire, and the Kisa story. The remainder of the lyrics were there as well, extemporized yet complete. We added some strings, backing vocals, Tommy</span>’<span lang="EN-US">s beautiful drumming, tidied up the vocal a bit and it became </span>‘<span lang="DA">Hollywood.</span>’ <span lang="EN-US">It was effortless and enigmatic and it spoke to us from another place, crying from the future whilst calling</span> <span lang="EN-US">from the past.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: center;">***</p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">In the song </span>‘Ghosteen’<span lang="EN-US">, a man is saying goodbye to a sleeping woman &#8211; he is leaving, heading somewhere, we don</span>’<span lang="EN-US">t know where. </span>‘<span lang="DA">Hollywood</span>’ <span lang="EN-US">is a continuation of this song. It is the leaving, the driving away, heading out of LA, along the Pacific Coast to Malibu. Malibu is on fire. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">We recorded most of the record at Woodshed Studios, in Malibu, later in 2018,</span> <span lang="EN-US">in a single recording room surrounded by an Eden-like garden. The control desk was inside the room, so visiting musicians, friends and dogs all sat in the same room in which we recorded. Warren and I stayed at the house attached to the studio, perched on the valley hill, and it was an extraordinarily intense and magical time for both of us. A few weeks after we left the studio, the Malibu fires swept through the area. The studio itself remained mysteriously unharmed, but the house, the beautiful garden, and the surrounding homes</span> <span lang="EN-US">were incinerated. It was devastating for us all. The studio is now back up and running and will always hold a very special place in our hearts.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: center;">***</p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Susan, the idea that songs are prophetic is the kind of magical thinking which</span> <span lang="EN-US">I would normally reject, but there has been too much coincidence, too often, not to feel that some songs perhaps hold a certain unsettling knowledge, beyond the understanding of their creators. I suspect we all have intimations or intuitions, that are holding conversations with the future, but that we tend to disregard, perhaps at our peril. As songwriters we are given scraps of information &#8211; </span><span lang="FR">images, visions, projections, divination &#8211; </span><span lang="EN-US">that become the building blocks for songs; these uncanny hunches are the stuff we work with, the material with which we create, so the songs end up feeling elastic, stretching themselves forward in time and back into the past. They can feel like preternatural witnesses to things yet to come, signallers calling urgently from an emergency &#8211; the future &#8211; while haunted by what has gone before. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">And now, as we watch Australia burn, no such indicators are necessary. As Carl from Belgium says, in a lette</span><span lang="EN-US">r to ‘</span><span lang="EN-US">The Red Hand Files’ </span><span lang="EN-US">“</span><span lang="EN-US">the Australian fires are a global torch illuminating the human condition. Nature, on its knees, is a dangerous beast”.  The future, it seems, is here. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Sending love, Nick </span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-926" src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-2-250x161.png" alt="" width="250" height="161" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-2-250x161.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-2-768x496.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-2-700x452.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-2-120x78.png 120w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture-2.png 864w" sizes="(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;">ZUMA BEACH, MALIBU</p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

			<div class="subscribe-form__bg"></div>
		</div>

		<script type='text/javascript' src='https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-includes/js/wp-embed.min.js?ver=4.9.15'></script>

			var $grid

					itemSelector: '.posts__article'
				});
				console.log("Ajax Load More Complete!");
				$grid.imagesLoaded().progress( function() {
					$grid.masonry('layout');
				});
				$grid.masonry('reloadItems')

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-915" class="post-915 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #77 / December 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					What is your feeling about Christmas?				</h1>
				<h3>TIM, FRANKFURT, GERMANY</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/your-feeling-about-christmas/" title="What is your feeling about Christmas?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture-1.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture-1-250x183.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture-1-768x561.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture-1-700x511.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture-1-120x88.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">How do you celebrate Christmas?</h1>
<h3>JOSHUA, BERLIN, GERMANY</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">I read today that when a photon is born in the Sun, it take it 1,000,000 years to come to the Sun&#8217;s surface (it&#8217;s colliding with other particles and constantly changes its direction). And then a further few minutes to reach the Earth. Something that is so ordinary as the sunlight appears to have its own, very ancient history. &#8220;We are photons released from a dying star&#8221;. It&#8217;s so great we&#8217;ve got the chance to take part in this cosmic spectacle and that we can consciously contemplate it, don&#8217;t you think?</h1>
<h3>M, WARSAW, POLAND</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Tim, Joshua and M,</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Christmas to me is the remnant of an evaporating culture to which I once belonged.</span> <span lang="EN-US">I am not a Christian, yet I am attached to its culture, personally, nostalgically and sentimentally. It is not the only culture available, there are others, equally valid or invalid, both religious and secular. But, for me, as someone who grew up in an Anglican home, sang in the cathedral choir, and has an enduring fascination with the Christian scriptures, the Christian story, in all its quaintness and implausibility, holds great meaning. Christ continues to move through my imagination, a vaporous ghost beckoning from the shadows, and his story affects me deeply. Jesus is an absurdity that rises eerily from my yearning for spiritual comfort, within a cosmos I cannot begin to understand. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">And M, I can</span>’<span lang="EN-US">t agree with you more. The fascination of the universe is a wonder so monumental that we are left dizzy with awe as we attempt to contemplate it. Infinity lives on the far side of language, touching only the fringes of our understanding, and I admire those who devote their lives to the investigation of this impossibility.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">As stars are born and die, the phenomena of suffering and love are projected onto Earth to play out in the seeming inconsequentiality of our human lives. We are the broken metaphors of a cosmos that is beyond our comprehension.  </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Christ is a symbol of our imperfect and limited attempt at understanding</span> <span lang="EN-US">eternity, and addresses the vulnerability of humanity itself. Perhaps we</span> <span lang="EN-US">should not look </span>at <span lang="EN-US">the Christian story as a symbol of our naivety or</span> <span lang="EN-US">ignorance, but instead cherish it as our attempt to</span> <span lang="EN-US">comprehend the incomprehensible.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">So, Tim and Joshua, as Christianity retreats back into the churches and cathedrals, as all conspicuous notions of Christ fade from our culture, and Christmas becomes the sole province of a roly-poly man in a Coca-Cola red suit (whose days may also be numbered) I will visit a church this Christmas; I will kneel before the fading vestiges of an outmoded idea called spiritual transcendence and our beautiful and moving attempt to humanise the ecstatic cosmic drama, and I will pray.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-907" class="post-907 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #76 / December 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					What, oh, what is Ku Klux furniture?				</h1>
				<h3>SERGE, PROVINCETOWN, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-oh-what-is-ku-klux-furniture/" title="What, oh, what is Ku Klux furniture?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture-2.png 902w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture-2-250x308.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture-2-768x947.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture-2-700x863.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture-2-120x148.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 902px) 100vw, 902px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							DEANNA BY BILL HENSON							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">Have you ever reached the same highs when sober as when you were on some sort of lovely substance?</h1>
<h3>CRAIG, LEEDS, UK</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Serge and Craig,</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">My song ‘Deanna’ is a collision of dissonant imagery, beautiful transgressions, reckless theatrics, secret admissions, impossible lusts, erroneous politics and fuck you</span> <span lang="EN-US">swaggering, that ultimately resolves itself into a pure expression of the monstrous rapture of youth.</span> <span lang="EN-US">It represents a time of joyful and wilful abandon, into drugs, into music, into danger, into love, into life itself. Like love, the song cannot be broken down into its respective parts without doing a grave injustice to its mystery and its glory. ‘</span><span lang="IT">Deanna</span><span lang="EN-US">’ is a capsule of incautious adoration that alerts us to the futility of judging the actions of our past through the lens of what we have become, no matter how much wiser, more aware and insightful we think we are. As an old guy, I probably have no right to sing it, yet I do</span> <span lang="EN-US">as ‘Deanna’ holds a special place in my heart and it propels me back to a fearless and less fractured time. It remains “a song that yearns to be sung.”</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US"> </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">No carpet on the floor</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">And the winding cloth holds many moths</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">Around your Ku Klux furniture</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">I come a death’s head in your frock</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US"> </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">As for your question, Serge, </span><span lang="IT">Deanna</span><span lang="EN-US">’s mother was American and each Christmas she would leave Melbourne and head back to the U.S. for the holidays, leaving her maverick daughter in charge of the house that sat high up on the south bank of the Yarra River. Perhaps anticipating our behaviour, her mother covered the furniture in the living room with protective white sheets—the Ku Klux furniture, we called it. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">What happened to Deanna? I’m not really sure. She went to live in the States, and we lost touch. But for me she lives inside the song, imprisoned there, just as <em>I</em> am in all my songs, and that is the melancholy beauty of them; songs become a form of entrapment—you write one and then throw away the key. </span></p>
<p class="BodyAA"><span lang="EN-US">Craig, I’m not sure if I have quite reached the same highs as those times while sober, but then again I also haven’t reached the kind of lows that eventually came with taking those ‘lovely substances’— bashed up in police stations, dehumanised in rehabs, near-death experiences, suicidal thoughts, routine overdoses, reduced motivation, broken bones, being ripped off, liking Charles Bukowski, social and physical anhedonia, herd mentality, dead friends, fucked up relationships, abscesses, car accidents, psychosis, reading The Hobbit,</span> <span lang="EN-US">malnutrition, creative impotence, </span><span lang="IT">epic </span><span lang="EN-US">time-wasting, singing flat (still working on that), talking shit (still working on that too), life-threatening diseases, and not ringing my mother on her birthday.</span></p>
<p class="BodyAA"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick </span></p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

As a recovering heroin addict, I am having difficulty getting into the Narcotics Anonymous scene. I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA? 		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-895" class="post-895 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #75 / December 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					You are one of the funniest writers out there. Would you say humour is an important aspect of your writing? Who has inspired your humour?				</h1>
				<h3>CHRIS, BEIJING, CHINA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/funniest-writers-out-there/" title="You are one of the funniest writers out there. Would you say humour is an important aspect of your writing? Who has inspired your humour?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3495.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3495.jpg 576w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3495-250x240.jpg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3495-120x115.jpg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 576px) 100vw, 576px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">I&#8217;ve always seen you as something of an underrated humourist. Do you see comedy as an essential art form?</h1>
<h3>LUKE, MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">How important is humour to you in your art?</h1>
<h3>ALEX, BATON ROUGE, USA</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">Who in your band is the funniest?</h1>
<h3>BRADLEY, BALTIMORE, USA</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p>Dear Chris, Luke, Alex and Bradley,</p>
<p>There is nothing on this earth that is so serious that it cannot be elevated by humour. Humour is not lack of gravity and it is not frivolity. Rather, it is the merciful oxygen that can envelop seriousness and prevent it from becoming a grim contagion that infects ourselves and those around us. True humour is the antidote to dogmatism and fanaticism, and we must be cautious of the humourless and those who cannot take a joke.</p>
<p>Humour is the way in which we manoeuvre ourselves through the things that are difficult to talk about, that require subtlety of thought, that are counter-intuitive, uncertain and mysterious. Humour is a way of exploring the uncomfortable without fully committing ourselves, testing and pushing at the boundaries of acceptability, always able to retreat back into the form itself.</p>
<p>In this respect, Luke, I am a humourist, and many of my songs are essentially comic songs. I have always used humour as a way of presenting ideas that may otherwise be considered unacceptable. Humour is a device that allows us to push against the constraints of decorum and say the uncomfortable things that challenge our presumptions; it allows us room to <em>breathe</em>.</p>
<p>It is for this reason, Chris, that I have such deep admiration for comedians, from Buster Keaton to Lenny Bruce to Dave Chappelle. Anarchic and troublesome, comedians are the canaries in the coal mine of ideas, often saying things that cannot safely be said elsewhere and taking significant personal risk to speak truth, not just to power, but to stupidity too, to outrage and self-righteousness. Between the joke and the laughter resides our common humanity and as our laughing bodies relax, our hearts and minds open and serious ideas can penetrate. Humour is the Trojan horse that crosses the moat and infiltrates the castle, bringing with it the unsayable.</p>
<p>Ultimately, humour allows us to laugh at ourselves and the absurdity of our human predicament. Humour tells us that we are, in the greater scheme of things, both completely meaningless and supremely meaningful, and though our efforts are of no real consequence, they are heroic and deeply moving.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
<p>P.S. Bradley, The Bad Seeds are bound together by both our music and our collective sense of humour, however it is impossible to exaggerate just how funny Conway Savage was. Conway had a Depression-era, Dust Bowl wit, so dry and parched you couldn’t help but feel his perfectly timed, apocalyptic one-liners were the true cause of the world’s environmental chaos. We miss Conway very much.</p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<title>Nick Cave - The Red Hand Files - Issue #74 - I have a question about grief. You have written exquisitely on the subject, and I have found great comfort in your words, and have great empathy for you and your family&#039;s devastating loss of your precious son.My mom was murdered with an AR-15 by a white supremacist in our synagogue, killed because this 19-year-old felt Jews were &#039;destroying&#039; the white race. It has been almost 8 months, I stopped counting out of numbness, and I still don&#039;t have anger towards the shooter, but more so for people who my mother was close to, and in her death, claimed my mother as their own, and exploited the situation for their own gain. I am afraid to let go of the anger, because I feel it connects me to my mother, and to the tragedy where she died, my last experience with her. I am afraid to move forward in any way. Family members are grieving in a different way than I am and that makes things even more uncomfortable. I am afraid to connect or feel my mother&#039;s spirit in any way. Do you have any advice on these components of grief: the anger; the fear. With utmost gratitude towards your input, : The Red Hand Files</title>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-875" class="post-875 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #74 / December 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I have a question about grief. You have written exquisitely on the subject, and I have found great comfort in your words, and have great empathy for you and your family&#8217;s devastating loss of your precious son.<br/><br/>My mom was murdered with an AR-15 by a white supremacist in our synagogue, killed because this 19-year-old felt Jews were &#8216;destroying&#8217; the white race. It has been almost 8 months, I stopped counting out of numbness, and I still don&#8217;t have anger towards the shooter, but more so for people who my mother was close to, and in her death, claimed my mother as their own, and exploited the situation for their own gain. I am afraid to let go of the anger, because I feel it connects me to my mother, and to the tragedy where she died, my last experience with her. I am afraid to move forward in any way. Family members are grieving in a different way than I am and that makes things even more uncomfortable. I am afraid to connect or feel my mother&#8217;s spirit in any way. <br/><br/>Do you have any advice on these components of grief: the anger; the fear. <br/><br/>With utmost gratitude towards your input,				</h1>
				<h3>HANNAH, CALIFORNIA, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/question-about-grief/" title="I have a question about grief. You have written exquisitely on the subject, and I have found great comfort in your words, and have great empathy for you and your family&#8217;s devastating loss of your precious son.My mom was murdered with an AR-15 by a white supremacist in our synagogue, killed because this 19-year-old felt Jews were &#8216;destroying&#8217; the white race. It has been almost 8 months, I stopped counting out of numbness, and I still don&#8217;t have anger towards the shooter, but more so for people who my mother was close to, and in her death, claimed my mother as their own, and exploited the situation for their own gain. I am afraid to let go of the anger, because I feel it connects me to my mother, and to the tragedy where she died, my last experience with her. I am afraid to move forward in any way. Family members are grieving in a different way than I am and that makes things even more uncomfortable. I am afraid to connect or feel my mother&#8217;s spirit in any way. Do you have any advice on these components of grief: the anger; the fear. With utmost gratitude towards your input,">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/two-candles-new.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/two-candles-new.jpg 548w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/two-candles-new-250x307.jpg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/two-candles-new-120x147.jpg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 548px) 100vw, 548px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Hannah,</p>
<p>This is a very difficult question to answer, there are no adequate words and I worry that I will not do the enormity of the tragedy of your mother’s death justice, or your grief, for that matter. I apologise if I fall short. I cannot claim to understand the complexities of your situation, but although the circumstances are very different, I do understand about dealing with a death that is in the public eye and the deranging internal conflicts that it can bring.</p>
<p>The tragedy of my son’s death is inscribed into the collective consciousness of the town where we live and where he died. I have had to learn to share the reality of his passing with the town itself, because it affected us all. I doubt there was a mother in Brighton who did not feel a chill of horror and cling to her own children a little tighter upon hearing the news of Arthur’s senseless accident. But Arthur was our child, our own flesh and blood; Susie and I didn’t want to share him with anyone, and we were deeply possessive over his absence. It took us some time to understand that while he belonged to us, he belonged to the world too. In time we understood that, although we were the ultimate custodians of Arthur’s memory, he was, in fact, mourned by many, and many people felt outraged at the cruelty and randomness of the event, just as we did. Susie and I, individually and together, had to find a way to be with Arthur, but also to share him with a multitude.</p>
<p>In time we found a place away from the concerns of the world and our own conflicted feelings, that was silent and vast, where we could have the necessary and ongoing conversation with our son, to tell him that we loved him, and that we missed him, and that we were sorry. We found a place where we can be with him, in grief, beyond the glare and the noise of the world, a place of meaning.</p>
<p>Hannah, your tragedy was not an accident, nor a random act of fate, and this incident was an egregious affront to both your community and our collective humanity. Your mother was your mother, but she was also a Jew, and along with other members of her community simply doing the thing that observant Jews have always done on a Saturday morning. How difficult it must be for you to untangle this and find that silent space where you can speak with your mother, as her daughter, and be heard above the tumult of other people’s expectations, the various agendas of the media, your own rage and the enormity of the act itself. How can you find your own meaning in your mother’s passing?</p>
<p>It feels to me, that the meaning exists within the anger. Not only is your anger justified, it is compassionate and essential and, as you said, connects you to your mother, even as those around you take possession of her, eclipsing your feelings with their own needs. The righteous energy of your anger is the flaming sword you hold above your mother’s memory. It may be the very thing that protects her, shielding her from the suffocating demands of the world. Perhaps, at this time, your anger is a way of safekeeping the spirit of your mother, of caring for her, of seeking her, of calling her to you. It is a pure and holy anger.</p>
<p>But there is another place too, a quieter place that patiently awaits you, and maybe in time you will find a moment to temporarily lay down the sword and, speaking into the sacred silence, talk to your mother, in grief, in longing, and in her presence, and perhaps find some solace there. I very much hope so.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<title>Nick Cave - The Red Hand Files - Issue #73 - Many people have remarked that Ghosteen is a sad album, but I don&#039;t think it is at all. In fact I don&#039;t think I&#039;ve ever heard a more uplifting, jubilant record before. When I listened to it the first time alone, I was brought to tears. And when I listened to it again with my friend, both of us sitting in the car in complete silence, we both felt moved by its brightness and gentle optimism. Why do you think people are reacting so differently to it? I almost feel like I&#039;ve misinterpreted it. : The Red Hand Files</title>

In fact I don&#039;t think I&#039;ve ever heard a more uplifting, jubilant record before. When I listened to it the first time alone, I was brought to tears. And when I listened to it again with my friend, both of us sitting in the car in complete silence, we both felt moved by its brightness and gentle optimism. Why do you think people are reacting so differently to it? I almost feel like I&#039;ve misinterpreted it." />

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-853" class="post-853 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #73 / November 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Many people have remarked that Ghosteen is a sad album, but I don&#8217;t think it is at all. In fact I don&#8217;t think I&#8217;ve ever heard a more uplifting, jubilant record before. When I listened to it the first time alone, I was brought to tears. And when I listened to it again with my friend, both of us sitting in the car in complete silence, we both felt moved by its brightness and gentle optimism. Why do you think people are reacting so differently to it? I almost feel like I&#8217;ve misinterpreted it.				</h1>
				<h3>JONAH, SALT LAKE CITY, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/uplifting-jubilant-record/" title="Many people have remarked that Ghosteen is a sad album, but I don&#8217;t think it is at all. In fact I don&#8217;t think I&#8217;ve ever heard a more uplifting, jubilant record before. When I listened to it the first time alone, I was brought to tears. And when I listened to it again with my friend, both of us sitting in the car in complete silence, we both felt moved by its brightness and gentle optimism. Why do you think people are reacting so differently to it? I almost feel like I&#8217;ve misinterpreted it.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-1-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-1-2.png 843w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-1-2-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-1-2-250x250.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-1-2-768x768.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-1-2-700x700.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-1-2-120x120.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 843px) 100vw, 843px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">Ghosteen seems haunted. Is it?</h1>
<h3>AMBER, CORK, IRELAND</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">Where did the drums go?</h1>
<h3>KJELL, HOLMESTRAND, NORWAY</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Jonah, Amber and Kjell,</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">I am very happy to hear you describe Ghosteen as uplifting and jubilant, Jonah. This was certainly the Bad </span><span lang="EN-US">Seeds</span><span lang="EN-US">’ objective</span><span lang="EN-US"> when we made the record. We wanted each song to feel as if it were climbing toward an exultant and euphoric state, for the record to be a vessel that transported the listener far away from the world and its </span><span lang="EN-US">troubles, and</span><span lang="EN-US"> that it lived in the jubilant and hopeful beyond. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">If there is sadness in Ghosteen, perhaps it is the recognition that we are often blind to the splendour of the world and </span><span lang="EN-US">indifferent to its attendant</span><span lang="EN-US"> wonder. Perhaps the sadness is the recognition that the world is indeed beautiful, that it spins within the palm of our own hands and its beauty is available to </span><span lang="EN-US">all, if only we had eyes to see. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">And maybe</span><span lang="EN-US">, </span><span lang="EN-US">Amber, you are right and Ghosteen is haunted. Perhaps the songs became a kind of free-floating conversation with the spirit world</span><span lang="EN-US">,</span><span lang="EN-US"> buoyed up by the absence of the ones we love. Perhaps the ghostly forms of the departed are all around us, magnetised toward the act of creation. Perhaps they see that to be alive and upon the earth, at this time and against all the odds, is the most rare and coveted of things, and to be making art such a singular and fortuitous privilege, that they just wanted to come along for the ride. In the song Ghosteen, baby bear goes to the moon in a boat; Ghosteen <em>is</em> that boat, as it sails through the dark to the stars, a galleon ship collecting fireflies and spirit-children as it goes. At times Ghosteen may feel unmoored and homeless, but it is pointed firmly toward paradise, the crew is joyous, the world smiles, and the sun bursts over the edge of the earth.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA" style="text-align: center;"><span lang="EN-US">***</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Kjell, to answer your question, Thomas Wydler, our drummer, did some amazing work on this record, however, after a great deal of thought, we all felt that the drums anchored the songs to the ground and didn’t allow them to float. The</span><span lang="IT"> decision</span><span lang="EN-US"> was not made lightly or on a whim, rather it was a tough artistic decision determined by the needs of the songs themselves. Although there is little drumming on the first part of Ghosteen, Tommy’s absence is courageous and monumental and gives the record its amorphous sound. He is the very best there is.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">The </span><span lang="IT">decision </span><span lang="EN-US">as to what sort of record we make is largely out of our hands. We have no ‘</span><span lang="FR">intentions</span><span lang="EN-US">’ beyond meaning itself. The record must <em>mean</em> something, right? What more can we ask? The form that that</span> <span lang="EN-US">expression of meaning comes in is, to some degree, beside the point. We are slaves to manifest meaning and masters to nothing at all.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
<div></div>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-843" class="post-843 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #72 / November 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Is the screeching at the end of &#8216;Stagger Lee&#8217; due to the fact that when Stag filled Billy Dilly full of lead, he blew his own dick off in the process? After all, Billy Dilly was presumably still slobbering on his head when Stag opened fire. Thanks for taking the time to consider this question.				</h1>
				<h3>SLIM LEE, MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/screeching-stagger-lee/" title="Is the screeching at the end of &#8216;Stagger Lee&#8217; due to the fact that when Stag filled Billy Dilly full of lead, he blew his own dick off in the process? After all, Billy Dilly was presumably still slobbering on his head when Stag opened fire. Thanks for taking the time to consider this question.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Unknown-2.jpeg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Unknown-2.jpeg 1710w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Unknown-2-250x299.jpeg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Unknown-2-768x920.jpeg 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Unknown-2-700x839.jpeg 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Unknown-2-120x144.jpeg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 1710px) 100vw, 1710px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							BLIXA BARGELD SCREECHING							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Slim Lee, </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">During my more gloomy moments I sometimes wonder if anyone actually listens to my lyrics, and whether the enormous amount of work I put into them may in fact go unheeded. So it was with very real gratitude that I read this question, as you had clearly reflected long and hard on the matter. I am very moved, to be honest. On my knees, I thank you </span><span lang="EN-US">(but not in that way).</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">I didn’t even have to look at the address of this question to know that you were from Melbourne.</span> <span lang="EN-US">We Melburnians</span> <span lang="EN-US">are warped but meticulous thinkers and, I would tentatively suggest, a step ahead of everyone else. Our minds simply jump the leash and run, unchecked and slavering, where others fear to tread. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">It did occur to me one night, as I performed Stagger Lee in full priapic flight, that Stagger Lee does not shoot Billy Dilly with an actual gun at all, but that his being &#8220;f</span><span lang="EN-US">illed full of lead. Bang! Bang! Bang!” was simply a metaphor for the force of Stag’s ejaculation, and Blixa’s terrifying and inhuman screeching at the end orgasmic in nature. This made me wonder, chillingly at the time, what sleeping with Blixa must be like – something I am sadly unable to elaborate on. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Beyond that, my friend, I have nothing more to add, but if any more theories about my songs work their way into your beautiful mind, perhaps on one of those warm and eerie Melbourne nights, where the fruit bats fly from tree to tree, please do not hesitate to write in and tell me. I would love that.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Love, Nick</span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><img class="alignnone wp-image-845" src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-2-250x300.png" alt="" width="200" height="240" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-2-250x300.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-2-768x920.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-2-700x839.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-2-120x144.png 120w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-2.png 862w" sizes="(max-width: 200px) 100vw, 200px" /></p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-837" class="post-837 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #71 / November 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Don&#8217;t you get sick and tired of people asking dumb ass questions?				</h1>
				<h3>DAWNE, BIRMINGHAM, UK</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/sick-and-tired-of-people-asking-questions/" title="Don&#8217;t you get sick and tired of people asking dumb ass questions?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-1.png 920w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-1-250x119.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-1-768x366.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-1-700x334.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Picture-1-120x57.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 920px) 100vw, 920px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">Would you like to ask me a question?</h1>
<h3>NICOLA, WALLASEY, UK</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">[ ] I have come to believe that the right question is what we are really searching for, the answer may reveal itself if only we can find the right question. My question to you, then, is what is your question?</h1>
<h3>GEMMA, HOVE, UK</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p>Dear Dawne, Nicola and Gemma,</p>
<p>The question is the most valuable part of The Red Hand Files. Spend a moment to look inside most questions and you will find, embedded within, a supplementary enquiry that asks “Are you there?”</p>
<p>This would be my question too. “Are you there?”</p>
<p>Maybe the songs I’ve written over the years were febrile statements that have eventually turned into a solitary question. Maybe my songs used to say “Here I am”, demanding recognition. Now my songs ask “Are you there?”, longing for an answer.</p>
<p>Do I get sick and tired of the questions? The answer is no. In no way do I get sick and tired of the questions, because for me the questions are proof of life. Not only your lives, but of my own. Proof of existence. The questions are the answer, emerging from the impossible dark, at the edge of tears.</p>
<p>“Are you there?” I say.</p>
<p>“Yes, I am.” “Yes, I am.” “Yes, I am” they ask.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
</div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-829" class="post-829 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #70 / November 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Can you please pay for the Transcendental Meditation course for me? It&#8217;s really fucking expensive. [ ]				</h1>
				<h3>NICOLA, BAULKIM HILLS, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/transcendental-meditation-course-really-expensive/" title="Can you please pay for the Transcendental Meditation course for me? It&#8217;s really fucking expensive. [ ]">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/247.1985S.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/247.1985S.jpg 400w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/247.1985S-250x272.jpg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/247.1985S-120x131.jpg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">You endorse TM, but it&#8217;s so expensive (even with their recent pricing shift), I am inherently skeptical of the training program. It seems to be something only afforded by the rich. Can you speak on that a bit? [ ]</h1>
<h3>MARK, KANSAS CITY, USA</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">[ ] I had a slight problem with your answer in that it felt like you were generalizing other meditative practices and, by doing so it seemed you were saying that TM is better than other practices. [ ]</h1>
<h3>LYDIA, ROCKVILLE, USA</h3>
</div>
<p><span lang="EN-US">Dear Nicola, Mark, Lydia and others,</span></p>
<p>Thank you for writing, I completely appreciate your points. As far as I am aware the TM organisation has a scaling system depending on what you are able to pay and your individual circumstances. Regardless, you are right TM is not free of charge and you will have to pay something.</p>
<p>I did not mean to discount other practices of meditation; there is an excellent app called Waking Up, where Sam Harris guides you through ten-minute Mindfulness meditations. Sam operates a refund system if you don’t find the introductory course valuable, additionally, if you would like to use his app but genuinely cannot afford it, he is happy to consider free access. Waking Up requires little commitment time-wise, yet is incredibly effective. I use it often, in conjunction with TM.</p>
<p>While I endorse meditation, I also understand the practice may not be for everyone. However, if you are interested there are various types of meditation and numerous apps and courses out there.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
<div></div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>

			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #69 / November 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					How do I stop fearing the end of the world?				</h1>
				<h3>MAIA, BUCHAREST, ROMANIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/fearing-the-end-of-the-world/" title="How do I stop fearing the end of the world?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/247.1985S-2.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/247.1985S-2.jpg 400w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/247.1985S-2-250x286.jpg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/247.1985S-2-120x137.jpg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							DEMOCRITUS MEDITATING AT THE END OF THE WORLD 1662							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">Do you practice meditation?</h1>
<h3>MATTHAIS, FRANKFURT, GERMANY</h3>
</div>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Maia and Matthais, </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">The filmmaker, David Lynch, described the practice of Transcendental Meditation as catching the big fish. I read that he has been practising it since he had a breakdown around the time of making Eraserhead, over forty years ago. He claims he has never missed a meditation. If that is true, I am greatly impressed. The basics of TM are taught </span><span lang="EN-US">during a three session course</span><span lang="EN-US">, at the end of which your teacher gives </span><span lang="EN-US">you a personal mantra. Anyone can do it. It is effortless an</span><span lang="EN-US">d there is nothing to get right or wrong</span>. <span lang="EN-US">I have been practicing for around six years and found</span> <span lang="EN-US">it to be instantly and radically beneficial. So, to answer your question, Maia, from the first time I meditated, I stopped fearing the end of the world. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">I found that it also helps with low-level anger, uncommunicativeness, resentments, impatience, passive-aggression, depression, self-obsession, hatred of the worl</span><span lang="EN-US">d,</span><span lang="EN-US"> blaming others, wanting to murder and maim people and a host of other maladies that I had been dragging around and allowing to define me. Meditation modulated my calamitous internal thinking, and the freaked-out tyrant residing in my head that represented the worst possible version of myself was largely deposed.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">I also found those big fish down there in the depths, the deep creative ideas which David Lynch talks about, wild, bright and thrilling; but more importantly, I found a fundamental understanding of the next right thing to do, of making the choice of the least destructive course of action. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Unlike some meditation </span><span lang="EN-US">techniques that focus </span><span lang="EN-US">on a life lived entirely within the present moment, Transcendental Meditation seems to radiate backwards and forwards in time, evoking our common humanity and our deep connection to the earth’s inheritance, as it layers us in meaning. It may not hold back the end of the world, but it reduces the element of fear, allowing us to administer to the world more effectively. TM also implements a kind of mysterious reinstating of the soul, a honeying of life, a merciful acceptance of suffering, and reminds us of the incredible privilege it is to be alive. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>

		<article id="post-816" class="post-816 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #68 / October 2019</h2>

						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-is-shyness/" title="What is shyness?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-3.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-3.png 824w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-3-250x349.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-3-768x1072.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-3-700x977.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-3-120x167.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 824px) 100vw, 824px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							PAINTING BY ALEKSANDRA WALISZEWSKA							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">What was your first date with your wife like?</h1>
<h3>VERA, MODENA, ITALY</h3>
</div>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Daniel,</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Shyness is the tentative sound of the orchestra tuning up before the symphony begins. It is a beautiful, fractured piece of music in itself. It is the orchestra attempting to find its shared intent and is over all too quickly if you ask me.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">In some circumstances shyness never finds its harmonic agreement and the situation will never be in tune. Yet shyness is a gift that can </span><span lang="EN-US">also be the sometimes crippling, often overpowering, intuition that the next thing life presents is potentially momentous</span><span lang="EN-US">, be it beautiful or devastating, where an exchanged few words or a gesture is a gateway to a new and unknown world.</span> <span lang="EN-US">From these intimations of excruciating clarity, we can fall through our shyness into moments of earth-shaking significance, and our lives can change completely.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">My wife, Susie, has a hummingbird shyness. In social situations she displays herself for a magical, weightless moment then darts away. It is as if she is so acutely tuned into the inherent discomfort of others, whether they display it or not, that the situation becomes </span><span lang="EN-US">overwhelming. She is a rare thing, an exhibitionist that hates to be seen.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">My initial dinner ‘</span><span lang="NL">date</span><span lang="EN-US">’ with Susie was an awkward and hesitant affair because we both intuited, on some deep level, that we stood at the threshold of another life that would stretch on indefinitely into the future. We did not know what that life would be, and it was undeclared between us, but our mutual shyness was the orchestra tuning up, with its flutters and discords, as it tried to find its shared melodic objective. In the end, I did what was a potentially life-deranging act and lunged hideously and impulsively through the membrane of our mutual shyness, grabbed my future wife and kissed her. She responded in kind and our shyness dropped away and, well, the symphony began. Shyness became the firewall through which we walked to a strange and different world, and here we are, together.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

How long does it all take? - The Red Hand Files : The Red Hand Files</title>

	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-809" class="post-809 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #67 / October 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					How much time do you spend answering these questions? Thinking of a response? Researching for a factual (where necessary) response? Writing, editing and moulding the response? The fluidity of your responses seem like an almost spontaneous stream of consciousness, but the conciseness, the beauty, the lyricism, the depth of meaning and the way the response pulls together within its own universe belie a great deal of time. How long does it all take?				</h1>
				<h3>BRETT, PORT PIRIE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/how-much-time-do-you-spend-answering-these-questions-thinking-of-a-response-researching-for-a-factual-where-necessary-response-writing-editing-and-moulding-the-response-the-fluidity-of-your-res/" title="How much time do you spend answering these questions? Thinking of a response? Researching for a factual (where necessary) response? Writing, editing and moulding the response? The fluidity of your responses seem like an almost spontaneous stream of consciousness, but the conciseness, the beauty, the lyricism, the depth of meaning and the way the response pulls together within its own universe belie a great deal of time. How long does it all take?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1a.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1a.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1a-250x198.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1a-768x607.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1a-700x553.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1a-120x95.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p><span lang="EN-US">Dear Brett,</span></p>
<p>Fucking ages.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

<li id="menu-item-12" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-12"><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/ask-a-question/">Ask a Question</a></li>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-800" class="post-800 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #66 / October 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Why do you write?				</h1>
				<h3>WILL, NASHVILLE, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/why-do-you-write/" title="Why do you write?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-2.png 862w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-2-250x180.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-2-768x554.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-2-700x505.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-2-120x87.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 862px) 100vw, 862px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							PAINTING BY PETER BOOTH							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">What are your political leanings, in a broad way?</h1>
<h3>SNORRI, REYKJAVIK, ICELAND</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">How &#8216;woke&#8217; are you?</h1>
<h3>STELLA, PORTLAND, USA</h3>
</div>
<p><span lang="EN-US"><br />
Dear Will, Snorri and Stella,</span></p>
<p>One of the reasons I write is because it allows me the freedom to move beyond the declared world into the uncanny and unfamiliar world. As a songwriter I have made a commitment to uncertainty and to embrace that which I do not know, because I feel this is where true meaning exists. It allows me to write songs that have within them the spirit of enquiry and reciprocity. It leaves me open to chance, a sense of open-ended potentiality, and fills me with a devotion to the mystery of the world with its deep oceans and dark forests. This notion of uncertainty, of doubt, contains an enormous amount of creative power and is always accompanied by a state of yearning for something beyond certitude, beyond comprehension. My songs are essentially religious songs in that they hold within them a condition of longing for some approximation of Godliness.</p>
<p>But organised religion itself poses a huge problem for me. Even though it would be so much easier to doze off in the arms of a mutually decided truth, I find that, in most cases, structured systems of faith are specifically designed to switch off the apparatus of inquiry by presenting themselves as the ‘one true religion’. As a consequence, I am left feeling bored and cornered by the hubris of their own sureness.</p>
<p>I have always found great motivating energy in the idea that the thing I live my life yearning for, let’s call it God, in all probability does not exist. I feel my songs are conversations with the divine that might, in the end, be simply the babblings of a madman talking to himself. It is this thrilling uncertainty, this absurdity, from which all of my songs flow, and more than that, it is the way I live my life.</p>
<p>So, for me, Stella, living in a state of enquiry, neutrality and uncertainty, beyond dogma and grand conviction, is good for the business of songwriting, and for my life in general. This is the reason I tend to become uncomfortable around all ideologies that brand themselves as ‘the truth’ or ‘the way’. This not only includes most religions, but also atheism, radical bi-partisan politics or any system of thought, including ‘woke’ culture, that finds its energy in self-righteous belief and the suppression of contrary systems of thought. Regardless of the virtuous intentions of many woke issues, it is its lack of humility and the paternalistic and doctrinal sureness of its claims that repel me.</p>
<p>Antifa and the Far Right, for example, with their routine street fights, role-playing and dress-ups are participants in a weirdly erotic, violent and mutually self-sustaining marriage, propped up entirely by the blind, inflexible convictions of each other’s belief systems. It is good for nothing, except inflaming their own self-righteousness. The New Atheists and their devout opponents are engaged in the same dynamic. Wokeness, for all its virtues, is an ideology immune to the slightest suggestion that in a generation’s time their implacable beliefs will appear as outmoded and fallacious as those of their own former generation. <span lang="EN-US">This may well be the engine of progress, but history has a habit of embarrassing our treasured beliefs. </span><span lang="EN-US">Some of us, for example, are of the generation that believed that free speech was a clear-cut and uncontested virtue, yet within a generation this concept is seen by many as a dog-whistle to the Far Right, and is rapidly being consigned to the Left’s ever-expanding ideological junk pile. </span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">This is not to suggest we should not have our convictions or, indeed, that we should not be angry with the state of the world, or that we should not fight in order to correct the injustices committed against it. Conviction and anger can be the most powerful expressions of universal love. </span><span lang="EN-US">However, my duty as a songwriter is not to try to save the world, but rather to save the </span><em><span lang="EN-US">soul</span></em><span lang="EN-US"> of the world. This requires me to live my life on the other side of truth, beyond conviction and within uncertainty, where things make less sense, absurdity is a virtue and art rages and burns; where dogma is anathema, discourse is essential, doubt is an energy, magical thinking is not a crime and where possibility and potentiality rule. The answers to the secrets of the heart may just be there, in the inscrutable dark of the forest, in the unfathomable depths of the sea, at the uncertain tips of our fingers.</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">Love, Nick </span></p>
<div></div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>
