	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-791" class="post-791 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #65 / October 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I feel very bad about myself, I cannot see anything positive in my body, I hate to look at myself in the mirror and it makes me suffer a lot. I feel like everyone is better than me, even though I did very important things for being just 16 years old. How should I behave? What should I do for myself? Thank you for the possible answer.				</h1>
				<h3>BARBARA, ROME, ITALY</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/how-should-i-behave/" title="I feel very bad about myself, I cannot see anything positive in my body, I hate to look at myself in the mirror and it makes me suffer a lot. I feel like everyone is better than me, even though I did very important things for being just 16 years old. How should I behave? What should I do for myself? Thank you for the possible answer.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-1.png 841w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-1-250x338.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-1-768x1038.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-1-700x946.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-1-120x162.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 841px) 100vw, 841px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							PAINTING BY ALEKSANDRA WALISZEWSKA							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div>
<p>Dear Barbara,</p>
<p>Thank you so much for entrusting me with such a courageous and heartfelt question. I took the liberty of discussing it with a number of my female friends and there was not one among them that was not greatly affected by your honesty and that did not understand exactly what you were talking about. It seems that you are not alone in finding the mirror your enemy, but you are unique in being so open and truthful about your relation to it.</p>
<p>For me, the question took me back to my adolescence and the troubled relationship I had with my own reflected image, and those nightmarish teenage years lived inside the pitiless mirror. I’m afraid to say this constant self-evaluation does not significantly decrease as you grow older, however it does become more manageable. I live mostly in hotels these days, and as I cautiously enter a different bathroom each night, with its angled mirrors and merciless lighting, I stand before the mirror at my most defenceless and exposed, and watch it do its worst. I often wonder how much accumulated misery a hotel mirror contains as it reflects back at us what appears to be our essential self. But, of course, what the mirror projects is not our true self at all but only our reflected outer-shell. What is virtually impossible to see within a mirror is that the very essence of our humanness, our vulnerability and fragility, is the most beautiful thing we possess.</p>
<p>Yet, when we are young that vulnerability can appear to us as shame or weakness, as we attempt to brace ourselves against what we may see as a brutal, unforgiving and judgemental world. But those who have no awareness of their own fragility, who present themselves as overconfident, armoured-up and invulnerable, sacrifice the essence of what makes them both human and beautiful.</p>
<p>Vulnerability is the very thing that permits us to connect with each other, to recognise in others the same discomfort they have with themselves and with their place in the world. Vulnerability is the engine of compassion, and can be a superpower, a special vision that allows us to see the quivering, wounded inner world that most of us possess.</p>
<p>Barbara, I am happy to hear that you have done important things as a 16 year old, because it is often what we <em>do</em> that moves our attention away from what we think we <em>are</em>, or the way that we think we look. The note of pride in your words could be the very thing that escorts you home, where you fall back through the reflected surface of your body, into your authentic self. Your pain-filled question holds great hope because in order to connect meaningfully with the world we need to have some understanding of its innate tragedy. Paradoxically, the fragility of your question is its immense strength and says something very profound about you as a person; something very beautiful shines through its unhappy words. That body that you ‘can’t see anything positive in’ holds within it an unusually courageous, honest and intelligent heart. Your question is a testament to your specialness, and by asking it you have touched us all.</p>
<p>Finally, you asked what you could do, how to behave. Please, take care of yourself. Seek out beautiful things, inspirations, connections and validating friends. Perhaps you could keep a journal and write stuff down. The written word can put to rest many imagined demons. Identify things that concern you in the world and make incremental efforts to remedy them. At all costs, try to cultivate a sense of humour. See things through that courageous heart of yours. Be merciful to yourself. Be kind to yourself. Be kind.</p>
<p>With love, Nick</p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

        </li>

        <li>
          <h4><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-do-you-think-about-na/">Issue #120</a><br>-</h4>
          <h5><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-do-you-think-about-na/" title="What do you think about NA? As a recovering heroin addict, I am having difficulty getting into the Narcotics Anonymous scene. I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA?         </li>
              </ul>

      </div>

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-786" class="post-786 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #64 / October 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Do you have any regrets as you get older? I feel I could have just handled things better in my life. I even feel guilty for having regrets. Do you?				</h1>
				<h3>ROBIN, MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/do-you-have-any-regrets/" title="Do you have any regrets as you get older? I feel I could have just handled things better in my life. I even feel guilty for having regrets. Do you?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1.png 847w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-250x293.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-768x899.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-700x819.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Picture-1-120x140.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 847px) 100vw, 847px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">How do we say goodbye?</h1>
<h3>ELSE, LONDON, UK</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Robin and Else,</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">There is always a temptation to take the position that one has no regrets. There is a death row defiance to this notion that stares down the accusations of the past and says, ‘I am what I am and be damned’. We feel that to harbour regrets dishonours the very place to which we have arrived. But, it can be helpful to remind ourselves that these regrets are intimations informing us that we have developed sufficiently to perceive the nature of our past shortcomings. Regret can be a sorrowing hope that sees the faults of the past through the more lucid and open eyes of the present. They are growing pains as we become better at being ourselves. Most of our past mistakes are consistent with our personal evolution at that time, and the waves of regret simply signal a progression and expansion of our hearts.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Perhaps it is useful to see our lives as a series of failed or abandoned dreams, but to also recognise that these dreams are the very architecture of our humanity; to lovingly accept our shortcomings and lay them to rest in the knowledge that growth and regret go hand in hand, as do failure and potentiality. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Many of the regrets I have today seem to revolve around my past inability to say goodbye. For many years my way of dealing with things was to cut and run and not look back. I was forever fleeing from something or someone or some place, a disastrous situation, for example, or my various addictions or ruined relationships. This state of flight felt like a creative, motivating force, yet was actually completely devoid of reflection, and certainly unimpeded by the corrective influence of regret. I felt that if I ever stopped I would be eaten alive by the chaos that followed me around like a stray dog. It took many years before I found the resolve to turn around and stare down the imagined monster of my past. I found, when I finally looked, many ancient and festering wounds that a timely and heartfelt goodbye could well have healed. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Over time I have learned that the opportunity to say goodbye is the ultimate privilege. It can serve as a sigh of remembered love, a reparative breath that precedes an adjournment, a pause of gratitude before you inhabit the next you. To say goodbye, as difficult as it can be, must be seen as a gesture of reverence to the passage of life because there are many to whom this opportunity is denied, with devastating effect. There are those who are snatched away who never had the opportunity to comprehend the immense significance of their lives, and there are those left behind who stand yearning before a vacuum, paralysed in an eternal farewell that can never be spoken. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">So, to your question, Else, how <em>do</em> we say goodbye? We summon the courage by understanding that to say goodbye is an act of appreciation for the past that we have moved beyond, and a prelude to the new you that will, in time, require its own goodbye, and as you continue to grow, further goodbyes, each a rehearsal for the final, most precious goodbye of all. The way to say goodbye is to turn and face the past and administer the word as an offering of gratitude and also a healing gesture of mercy, and simply say it. Goodbye. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Love, Nick.</span></p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-774" class="post-774 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #62 / September 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					When can we expect a new album?				</h1>
				<h3>JOE, BEXHILL-ON-SEA, UK</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/when-can-we-expect-a-new-album/" title="When can we expect a new album?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/000355170006_6-2.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/000355170006_6-2.jpg 2048w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/000355170006_6-2-250x246.jpg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/000355170006_6-2-768x757.jpg 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/000355170006_6-2-700x690.jpg 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/000355170006_6-2-120x118.jpg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 2048px) 100vw, 2048px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div>
<p>Dear Joe,</p>
<p>You can expect a new album next week.</p>
<p>It is called Ghosteen.</p>
<p>It is a double album.</p>
<p>Part 1 comprises of eight songs.</p>
<p>The Spinning Song<br />
Bright Horses<br />
Waiting For You<br />
Night Raid<br />
Sun Forest<br />
Galleon Ship<br />
Ghosteen Speaks<br />
Leviathan</p>
<p>Part 2 consists of two long songs, linked by a spoken word piece.</p>
<p>Ghosteen<br />
Fireflies<br />
Hollywood</p>
<p>The songs on the first album are the children.</p>
<p>The songs on the second album are their parents.</p>
<p>Ghosteen is a migrating spirit.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
</div>
<div></div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-770" class="post-770 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #61 / September 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					How long will I be alone?				</h1>
				<h3>LIII, KRAKOW, POLAND</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/how-long-will-i-be-alone/" title="How long will I be alone?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-2.png 791w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-2-250x340.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-2-768x1044.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-2-700x951.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-2-120x163.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 791px) 100vw, 791px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Liii,</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">I am sorry I have taken so long to answer this question. You sent it to </span><em><span lang="DE">The Red Hand Files</span></em><span lang="EN-US"> almost nine months ago and I have carried it with me all this time, wanting to answer, but never quite knowing how. I think this little question has stayed with me, not just because of the lovely beat of pathos in it, but also because of its extraordinary existential reach. It seemed that it spoke to all of us, yet it felt simply beyond me to answer. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Aloneness and loneliness are two very different things, of course. I spend much of my time alone; I always have. I have learnt that being alone, as bereft as it perhaps feels to some, is busy with meaning and disclosure. For me, it is an essential place that intensifies the essence of oneself, in all its rampant need. It is the site of demons and sudden angels and raw truths; a quiet, haunted place and a place of unforeseen understandings. A place of unmasking and unveiling. It can be industrious or melancholic or frightening, sometimes all at the same time, yet within it there is a feeling of a latent promise that holds great power. Like Jesus praying alone in the garden, or Mary Magdalene alone at the mouth of Christ’s tomb, aloneness holds moments that tremble on the brink of revelation and great change.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">And then there is loneliness, which is aloneness without choice, an enforced condition that yearns for recognition, to be seen and to be heard. This brave and unguarded admission appears to be the aching heart of your question. As I sat on the plane travelling to Reykjavik for the last show of my ‘In Conversation’ tour, I felt suddenly that there was something I could say to you. Having spent much time travelling on this tour alone, it struck me that your question didn’t have to be answered, but simply acknowledged; that to reach out to you, as you reached out to me, could in itself be the answer and, perhaps, a remedy – to say to you, you are not alone, we are here, and that we, a multitude, are thinking of you. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

}</script>

	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-762" class="post-762 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #60 / September 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I attended your Symphony in August and was moved to tears. I think of you and your family often. Will you write us a poem about how much you love Susie?				</h1>
				<h3>HANNAH, MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/write-a-poem-about-how-much-you-love-susie/" title="I attended your Symphony in August and was moved to tears. I think of you and your family often. Will you write us a poem about how much you love Susie?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-1.png 804w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-1-250x350.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-1-768x1075.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-1-700x979.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-1-120x168.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 804px) 100vw, 804px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							PAINTING BY ALEKSANDRA WALISZEWSKA							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div>
<p>Dear Hannah,</p>
<p><strong>WIFE WITH EYES CLOSED  </strong></p>
<p>She sleeps and dreams to be before<br />
She seems to go there more and more<br />
She turns her back but not with any malice</p>
<p>She says she dreams of beasts run wild<br />
That circle around a rainbow child<br />
Cavorting through a many-roomed palace</p>
<p>And sometimes a black witch flies by<br />
With a wrath that blackens the entire sky<br />
The beasts all watch through a special telescope</p>
<p>And in time I leave her there and go<br />
To the world clawing against the window<br />
Hey, I’m not saying there isn’t any hope</p>
<p>For I can see a moment in between<br />
The waking horror and the sleeping dream<br />
Where the world and she are breathless beautiful<br />
Where the world and she are breathless beautiful</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA? 			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #59 / September 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					My girlfriend, a woman I love through soaring heaven and table-flipping hell, refuses to read any of my writing because she always sees some hint of infidelity, resentment, or perhaps madness in it. How do I get her to understand that just because I might write a poem about some lusty girl I saw on the train I don&#8217;t actually want to sleep with another woman?				</h1>
				<h3>CIRCIUM, COLORADO, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/my-girlfrieng-refuses-to-read-my-writing/" title="My girlfriend, a woman I love through soaring heaven and table-flipping hell, refuses to read any of my writing because she always sees some hint of infidelity, resentment, or perhaps madness in it. How do I get her to understand that just because I might write a poem about some lusty girl I saw on the train I don&#8217;t actually want to sleep with another woman?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/doc01208120190909171312-copy.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/doc01208120190909171312-copy.jpg 731w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/doc01208120190909171312-copy-250x190.jpg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/doc01208120190909171312-copy-700x531.jpg 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/doc01208120190909171312-copy-120x91.jpg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 731px) 100vw, 731px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Circium,</p>
<p>Tom Waits famously wrote “You are innocent when you dream”, yet dreams are not nearly as innocent as they seem. Neither are songs nor poetry. Songwriting and poetry are perilous callings, full of intrigue and infidelity. They are covert undertakings that creep around our deepest and most hazardous needs. They are not for the squeamish or the eager to please.</p>
<p>I believe you when you say you don’t want to sleep with the ‘lusty girl on the train’ – the problem is what you want to do is actually <em>worse</em>. You want to write a <em>poem</em> about her. To write a song or a poem about another human being can be one of the most intensely intimate acts a person can perform, it is an act of profound, unblinking contemplation, a near religious meditation on that moment of carnal recognition.</p>
<p>Listen to Patti Smith’s version of ‘Gloria’, where she has taken Van Morrison’s already wolfish classic and expanded it into a supercharged religious rumination on lust.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><em>I look out the window</em></p>
<p><em>See a sweet young thing</em></p>
<p><em>Humpin&#8217; on the parking meter</em></p>
<p><em>Leanin&#8217; on the parking meter</em></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Patti Smith’s ‘Gloria’ is not concerned so much with the actual sexual encounter, but rather with the brutal carnality and religious ecstasy of language itself. It is one of the most demented displays of predatory sexual desire ever recorded. Yet, it is beyond sex. It is even beyond worship. <em>It is poetry</em>. The “sweet young thing” that is “humpin&#8217; on the parking meter” is your “lusty girl on a train”.</p>
<p>Gloria, Peggy Sue, Billie Jean, Angie, Delilah, Fernando, Jolene, Ruby, Maggie May, Chuck E., Sharona, Sara, Suzanne, Sweet Caroline and, indeed, Deanna – these names live on, as sacrificial lambs, compulsively sexualised in our collective consciousness.</p>
<p>My song ‘Deanna’ was seen as a particularly brutal act of betrayal, and thirty years on I still haven’t been fully forgiven. I console myself with the thought that I was unflinching in my duties as a songwriter and in doing so wrote a song that brought joy to the lives of many, even though it broke a heart (or two) in the process.</p>
<p>From one wordsmith to another, and from someone who has spent a considerable amount of a long and contentious career in the songwriter’s doghouse, that’s the name of the game, Circium. Harsh as it is, we spend our lives walking on the hearts and messy eggshells we have smashed in order to make the omelet that feeds the multitudes.</p>
<p>I can perfectly understand why you want your girlfriend to read your stuff, as we poets and songwriters often have little else to offer than our words, and of course our perverse little truths. However, your poems are intimations of an eroticized and imaginative adventure of which your partner is excluded. It’s little wonder she might be reluctant to get involved.</p>
<p>Having said that, over time I have discovered great poetic and personal value in writing about the familiar, that which is in front of you, that which you see every day, that which sleeps beside you, for often that quotidian presence is the most extraordinarily complex and dangerous thing of all. It holds a looking glass up to beautiful and terrible truths that live inside us. As we look into our lover’s eyes and see our reflected selves, our courage as writers is tested and enlarged.</p>
<p>The girl on the train will always be there, forever travelling through that imaginative space, but maybe the challenge for you as a poet lies within the intricate wonder of the one who sits before you. She is, after all, your mirror.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
<div></div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-753" class="post-753 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #58 / September 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					How do you forgive somebody whom you love very much but has done something truly terrible?				</h1>
				<h3>MEL, TRENTON, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/how-do-you-forgive/" title="How do you forgive somebody whom you love very much but has done something truly terrible?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-250x333.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-768x1022.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-700x932.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Picture1-120x160.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Mel,</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Forgiveness is a form of self-rescue that goes, at times, against our very nature. Forgiveness can prevent us from becoming the living definition of the injury that has been inflicted upon us &#8211; from being consumed by anger, pain, resentment and bitterness. But how difficult it is to sometimes forgive; how unfair it seems to reward offence with compassion. Yet, despite our intuitions, despite the seeming insanity of the enterprise, we must try, because forgiveness can be the way to self-preservation. Forgiveness is an act of self-love where the malignancy you have endured can become the motivating force that helps enlarge the capacity of the heart.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">How to forgive the unforgivable? Now there is a question. Sometimes we feel the crime is such a violation, and so egregious, that it is beyond absolution &#8211; but the struggle to forgive is where it can find its true meaning. Even the attempt to move toward forgiveness allows us the opportunity to touch the borders of grace. To try is an act of resistance against the forces of malevolence &#8211; a form of </span><em><span lang="FR">defian</span></em><em><span lang="EN-US">t grace.</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">There are some who have found ways to forgive all manner of horrors and we look at them with awe. In Michigan, recently, a mother stood in court and told the murderer of her 17-year-old son. “I forgive you from the bottom of my heart. I pray for you as a mother. You are a child to me.” The mother of one of the victims of the Manchester bombing also publicly forgave the murderer of her child. These are forms of defiant grace, by people who refuse to be bowed by the malevolence of the world, and who rise to heights of compassion way beyond the reach of most of us, their acts of forgiveness a saintlike mixture of beauty, lunacy and courage.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">So, Mel, how do you forgive the one you love for doing something truly terrible? I would try to see the idea of forgiveness as an act of insubordination, a non-compliance to the forces of malevolence, a recognition that you will not be defined by the offence that has been inflicted upon you. See forgiveness as a gift, not to the person who has committed the injury, but to yourself, in the form of self-protection. The sooner you start the process, the less time you may spend imprisoned by resentment and bitterness, hopefully moving toward a more resilient self. To try and fail is in itself a form of betterment. There are times forgiveness is beyond us but still we must reach, still we must strive.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-746" class="post-746 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #57 / August 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Why did you give up on your relationship with PJ Harvey in the 90s? I love her music. I think she&#8217;s an amazing person and she writes brilliant songs.				</h1>
				<h3>RAMON, SAO PAULO, BRAZIL</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/your-relationship-with-pj-harvey/" title="Why did you give up on your relationship with PJ Harvey in the 90s? I love her music. I think she&#8217;s an amazing person and she writes brilliant songs.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-3.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-3.png 862w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-3-250x163.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-3-768x501.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-3-700x456.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-3-120x78.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 862px) 100vw, 862px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">I had a real hard time with your music, my boyfriend was a fan, until The Boatman&#8217;s Call. This record really spoke to me. Can you explain?</h1>
<h3>TANYA, TORONTO, CANADA</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Ramon and Tanya,</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">The truth of the matter is</span> <span lang="EN-US">that I didn’t give up on PJ Harvey, PJ Harvey gave up on me. There I am, sitting on the floor of my flat in Notting Hill, sun streaming through the window (maybe), feeling good, with a talented and beautiful young singer for a girlfriend, when the phone rings. I pick up the phone and it’s Polly.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">“Hi,” I say</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">“I want to break up with you.”  </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">“Why?!” I ask.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">“It’s just over,” she says.  </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US"> </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">I was so surprised I almost dropped my syringe.</span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="BodyA" style="text-align: center;"><span lang="EN-US">***</span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Deep down I suspected that drugs might have been a problem between us, but there were other things too. I still had a certain amount of work to do on</span> <span lang="EN-US">my understanding of the concept of monogamy, and Polly had her own issues, I suspect, but I think at the end of the day it came down to the fact that we were both fiercely creative people, each too self-absorbed to ever be able to inhabit the same space in any truly meaningful way. We were like two lost matching suitcases, on a carousel going nowhere.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Songwriting completely consumed me at that time. It was not what I did, but what I was. It was the very essence of me. Polly’s commitment to her own work was probably as narcissistic and egomaniacal as my own, although I was so deep into my own shit that I can’t really comment on this with any certainty. I remember our time together with great fondness though, they were happy days, and the phone call hurt;</span> <span lang="EN-US">but never one to waste a good crisis, I set about completing <em>The Boatman’s Call.</em></span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="BodyA" style="text-align: center;"><span lang="EN-US">***</span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">The Boatman’s Call</span></em><span lang="EN-US"> cured me of Polly Harvey. It also changed the way I made music. The record was an artistic rupture in itself, to which I owe a great debt. It was the compensatory largesse for a broken heart, or at least what I thought at the time was a broken heart – in recent years I have re-evaluated that term. The break up filled me with a lunatic energy that gave me the courage to write songs about commonplace human experiences (like broken hearts) openly, boldly and with meaning – a kind of writing that I had, until that date, steered clear of, feeling a need to instead conceal my personal experiences in character-driven stories</span><span lang="EN-US">.</span><span lang="EN-US"> It was a growth spurt that pushed me in a direction and style of songwriting that has remained with me ever since – albeit in different guises. It also pointed a way to a more poignant, raw, stripped back way of performance – the suspended and barely supported vocal. The Bad Seeds, to their eternal credit, stepped back and just let these piano-driven songs be. There are few bands on earth that understand that to <em>not</em> play, can be as important as its opposite.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Tanya, maybe it is a combination of all of these elements that changed the way you felt about The Bad Seeds’ music.</span> <span lang="EN-US">Perhaps there is also a feminine energy within <em>The Boatman’s Call</em> which you respond to. It feels a wiser, more empathetic record than anything that had been done previously, but whatever the reason, I am happy that you were drawn into the fold. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Love, Nick</span></p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-738" class="post-738 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #56 / August 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					What is the song &#8216;Rings of Saturn&#8217; about? I find myself in these lyrics. In Berlin I couldn&#8217;t stop crying when you performed it live. &#8220;Up and further up, up, up, up.&#8221; Is this song about evolving? I would love to know what you had in mind.				</h1>
				<h3>LISA, BERLIN, GERMANY</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-is-rings-of-saturn-about/" title="What is the song &#8216;Rings of Saturn&#8217; about? I find myself in these lyrics. In Berlin I couldn&#8217;t stop crying when you performed it live. &#8220;Up and further up, up, up, up.&#8221; Is this song about evolving? I would love to know what you had in mind.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-2.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-2-250x299.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-2-768x918.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-2-700x837.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-2-120x143.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							DETAIL FROM PAINTING BY ALEKSANDRA WALISZEWSKA							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Lisa,</p>
<p>There is great danger in asking a songwriter to explain their songs – or at least to make the assumption that their interpretation is in some way more valid or true than your own. This is simply not the case. I believe the fan often has a deeper understanding of a given song than its creator. Sometimes, I feel that I am the last to know what one of my own songs actually means. Sometimes, they take many years to reveal themselves. With that in mind, as you’ve asked, I will tell you what I think is going on in ‘Rings of Saturn’. I only hope my answer does not diminish the value of the song for you.</p>
<p>Warren emailed me a simple circular chord pattern that we had improvised in the studio. He liked its lo-fi, joyful feel. Sitting at the kitchen table, and using the Voice Memo App on my iPhone, I freestyled a lyric over the top and pinged it back to Warren.</p>
<p>Like several of the songs from <em>Skeleton Tree</em>, because the lyrics are essentially improvised, they tend to be ambiguous, unguarded, and to a certain extent, beyond my control. This, I believe, gives these particular songs their reckless power.</p>
<p>Listening to it now it seems the song is in three distinct parts. In the first verse, the narrator is involved in a sexual encounter with a woman, who is consumed by her own promiscuity. By using a voyeuristic cascade of erotic images – “upside down and inside out”, “like a funnel web”, “skinny white haunches high and skyward”, “black oily gash”, “crawling backwards”, “wet black fur” – the narrator propels the sexual encounter from the mundane, into the deep space of the imagination – “above the shops, the crowds, the cars and the town” – to the place where true sexual expression exists.</p>
<p>The chorus that follows suggests that, through this encounter the woman manifests her essential nature – “this is exactly what she was born to be” – and by implication, so too does the man. The euphoric lift of the chords on the chorus gives this notion a joyously old school and consensually abandoned feel.</p>
<p>The second verse then shifts into something different, and as the encounter becomes more surreal – “the air buckles and rushes in”, “her body moon-blue as a jellyfish” – the lyric turns its concerns away from the act itself, to the inability of the songwriter to do justice to the essentialness of this elemental moment. There are things beyond art that are carnal and godless, and the disempowered writer “spurts his ink across the sheets”, leaving her “completely unexplained”, and abandons himself to the servitude of her imperial feminine potential.</p>
<p>This time the chorus presents the woman as the divine force, beyond explanation, beyond description. She just cosmically <em>is.</em></p>
<p>In the third and final verse, the real world comes rushing back, and the woman rises from her bed. We see she is a mother, “stepping over piles of sleeping children”, as she reinstates herself to the chosen function of her womanhood – the nurturer, the provider, the font of life. As the sleeping children, born of this creative act, dream their innocent dreams, the mother ascends into the melancholy splendour of the cosmos and “dangles herself from the rings of Saturn” – in recognition of both the joy and sorrow of womanhood.</p>
<p>I love to perform it live because the rising, building chords take us to a place of collective bliss – of tearful, hopeful and mutually transcendent love. I suspect, Lisa, this is what you felt, that made you feel so emotional. I hope so.</p>
<p>When Warren received the iPhone recording I sent to him, he responded immediately. “A <em>fucking</em> classic.” The whole exchange took fifteen minutes.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-727" class="post-727 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #55 / August 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Do you believe in signs? I am currently seeing/hearing the name of someone my reason told me to forget, at least once a day (in books, on the streets). It&#8217;s like a daily reminder to maybe not listen to my reason.				</h1>
				<h3>AYLYN, BRUSSELS, BELGIUM</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/do-you-believe-in-signs/" title="Do you believe in signs? I am currently seeing/hearing the name of someone my reason told me to forget, at least once a day (in books, on the streets). It&#8217;s like a daily reminder to maybe not listen to my reason.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-1.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-1-250x299.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-1-768x918.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-1-700x837.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-1-120x143.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">My husband died some years ago but I feel him all around. How can this be?</h1>
<h3>MALINA, ATHENS, GREECE</h3>
</div>
<div>
Dear Aylyn and Malina,</p>
<p>Far be it from us to believe in signs; far be it from us to believe in spirits; far be it from us to intuit indications that the universe is not as it seems or, worse, that the dead are trying to tell us something – oh no! – because that would make us delusional (Richard Dawkins) or intellectually dishonest (Sam Harris) or in denial of death (Ernest Becker) or unreasonable (Steven Pinker) or cowardly (Bertrand Russell) or stupid (Ricky Gervais) or woo-woo (George from Alabama) – and we can’t have that! Yet here we are, with these lurking suspicions, these hunches, all around us. What do we do with them?</p>
<p>Often, while grieving, many of us are gripped by a form of madness, and start to believe, against our better judgments, all manner of lunacies and magical thinking; we believe our loved ones visit us in our dreams, we see them across crowded rooms, we think we hear their voices, we believe they inhabit other forms, we feel their ghost-hands in our own, we experience their presence &#8220;all around&#8221;.</p>
<p>These uncomfortable intuitions are confessed, in hushed and furtive tones, with a certain embarrassment, because we remember a time when we were rational people, a time when we thought there was some logical system to the universe, when we could believe in the protective power of reason, when the world made sense – and we realise that to admit to these intuitions may appear deluded or, worse, feeble-minded.</p>
<p>Two days after our son died, Susie and I went to the cliff where he fell. Now, when Arthur was a small child, he always, always, had a thing about ladybird beetles. He loved them. He drew them. He identified with them. He constantly talked about them. As we sat there, a ladybird landed on Susie’s hand. We both saw it, but said nothing, because even though we recognised the sad significance of it, we were not about to belittle the enormity of the tragedy with some sentimental display of magical thinking. But we were new to grief. We were unaware of grief’s particular appetites. When we returned home, as I was opening the door to our house, another ladybird landed on my hand. Since then Susie and I see ladybirds everywhere. When Warren and I were working on the last album a plague of ladybirds came into the studio. I don’t know what to make of this phenomenon, but each time I see a ladybird I receive a kind of jolt of recognition that maybe something is at play within the world that is beyond my comprehension, even though it is, in all probability, just ladybird season.</p>
<p>This need to believe in something beyond ourselves is a basic human function. Humans are essentially religious creatures by nature; we are possessed by inclinations and intuitions that are at odds with the rational world. For some of us, this is not simply wishful thinking or lack of nerve or being &#8220;stupid&#8221;, but a survival instinct that can bring great meaning to our lives, whether or not it conforms to the facts.</p>
<p>So, Aylyn, do I believe in signs? Well, I prefer to say that I have made, for reasons of survival, a commitment to the uncertain nature of the world. This is where my heart lies. I suspect it always has. And, Malina, I am joined in this enterprise by a legion of fellow grievers, many of us deranged by loss, and embarrassed by our sentimental inclinations. We tread gently around each other’s irrationalities because we know they are the fragile foundations of our vacillating sanity. You may hear some people say that feelings are not facts, but this is untrue. Feelings, to some, are facts. Sometimes these intuitions hold more truth than the rational world can ever hope to offer – when we are faced with a world that has long since stopped making sense and, indeed, lost its reason.</p>
<p>I think we disregard our intuitions at our peril. If you are left feeling the world is more mysterious than you perhaps once thought, and this feeling provides you with some sort of comfort, I would move toward the meaning, in whatever form it presents itself, because meaning is the antidote to despair, and, well, sometimes meaning can feel in scant supply and despair seems all around. My advice to the both of you is quietly, covertly, embrace the mystery that presents itself. It is yours alone.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<title>Nick Cave - The Red Hand Files - Issue #54- I recently received a pair of &#039;Bad Seed&#039; tube socks as a birthday present. A thoughtful gift from a dear friend, but they have left me somewhat confused. The almost spiritual connection I feel to you and The Bad Seeds&#039; work seems at odds with what is essentially banal (though very nicely designed) merchandise. I love the socks, I&#039;ve worn the socks, but I feel they might be a representation of everything your work isn&#039;t. I wonder what your thoughts are on the merchandising of art, and whether or not you&#039;d wear tube socks with the name of an artist you greatly admired on? : The Red Hand Files</title>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-720" class="post-720 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #54 / August 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I recently received a pair of &#8216;Bad Seed&#8217; tube socks as a birthday present. A thoughtful gift from a dear friend, but they have left me somewhat confused. The almost spiritual connection I feel to you and The Bad Seeds&#8217; work seems at odds with what is essentially banal (though very nicely designed) merchandise. I love the socks, I&#8217;ve worn the socks, but I feel they might be a representation of everything your work isn&#8217;t. <br/><br/>  I wonder what your thoughts are on the merchandising of art, and whether or not you&#8217;d wear tube socks with the name of an artist you greatly admired on?				</h1>
				<h3>PIERS, LONDON, UK</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-your-thoughts-are-merchandising-of-art/" title="I recently received a pair of &#8216;Bad Seed&#8217; tube socks as a birthday present. A thoughtful gift from a dear friend, but they have left me somewhat confused. The almost spiritual connection I feel to you and The Bad Seeds&#8217; work seems at odds with what is essentially banal (though very nicely designed) merchandise. I love the socks, I&#8217;ve worn the socks, but I feel they might be a representation of everything your work isn&#8217;t.   I wonder what your thoughts are on the merchandising of art, and whether or not you&#8217;d wear tube socks with the name of an artist you greatly admired on?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-250x299.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-768x918.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-700x837.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Picture1-120x143.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div>
<p>Dear Piers,</p>
<p>As I write, I am wearing an ancient Sonic Youth <em>Goo</em> T-shirt from 1990, back when I was in Thurston Moore’s good books. I also own a very beautiful Flatbush Zombies T-shirt, bought around the release of their first album. A few years ago the Zombies and I attempted a collaboration and I sent them my version of the T. Rex classic, <em>Cosmic Dancer</em>. They said they “could not relate to it” but they radically pitch-shifted my voice, sampled it and used it anyway, as the percussive heartbeat to an extraordinarily wild and fucked-up piece of hip-hop that neither of us released. I have a series of very lovely Current 93/David Tibet T-shirts, and a tote bag and some weird little esoteric Tibet pin things, all based on his visionary artwork. When I first came to London, David gave me an education in Christian mysticism, as we bonded over Spanish wine and our love of the artist Louis Wain. I also possess several ruined Dirty Three T-shirts featuring Mick Turner’s lovely mythic paintings – <em>and</em> a silver plastic Dirty Three sheriff’s badge, which I treasure because it is arguably the crappiest piece of merchandise ever made, but is a powerful emblem of the bad old days. I have an unused Dirty Three <em>Ocean Songs</em> tea towel – oh wow! a goldfinch just landed on my windowsill! – and Warren’s favourite AC/DC T-shirt, which I borrowed from him about twenty-five years ago and have still not returned. I also have an amazing T-shirt which Susie gave to me that says &#8220;Beyoncé Wasn’t Built in a Day&#8221;<em>, </em>although I suspect this is a bootleg. My favourite and most treasured piece of merchandise, though, is an original Elvis <em>Aloha from Hawaii via Satellite </em>T-shirt, sent to me by someone who claimed to have actually been at the concert in 1973. These items, Piers, are just the tip of a terrifying and deeply nostalgic iceberg – but a T-shirt, a pair of socks, a tea towel, a badge, it’s all essentially banal merchandise.</p>
<p>However, banal and as exploitative as these things may be, I value some of them hugely, and if there were a fire in my house they could quite possibly be the first things I would grab after the dogs. They have immense sentimental value, they are attached to certain times, people, places and things I love, and are enormously meaningful. I have a feeling that, similarly, many other music lovers have a T-shirt, a pair of socks or a hoodie that they value, and wear with a kind of reverence, not just for the artist, but for their own past – a past that, like their T-shirt, is old, faded, full of holes and beloved memories.</p>
<p>So, Piers, to answer your question would I wear a pair of merch socks myself? The answer is well, yeah, I do – when I do Jane Fonda’s Workout with my wife, I wear a pair of Radiohead compression socks, RiRi sweatpants, a Leather Nun T-shirt and a Dire Straits headband. I am a star jumping, butt clenching dervish of banality and exploitation. Look at me now!</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
<p>P.S. Piers, I just got your very sweet follow-up letter. No offence taken!</p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-714" class="post-714 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #53 / July 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					We know who your favourite singers are but who are your favourite guitarists?				</h1>
				<h3>DAVID, NYC, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/who-are-your-favourite-guitarists/" title="We know who your favourite singers are but who are your favourite guitarists?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-3.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-3.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-3-250x263.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-3-768x807.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-3-700x736.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-3-120x126.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">When was the last time you felt a sense of pride (in yourself)?</h1>
<h3>LAURA, NICE, FRANCE</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear David and Laura,</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Recently, I watched the movie </span><em>Mandy</em><span lang="EN-US"> with my sons </span>– <span lang="EN-US">a terrifying but beautiful film. The song </span>‘<span lang="ES-TRAD">Starless</span>’ <span lang="EN-US">by King Crimson was used to great effect during the opening credits. My sons agreed that this was an amazing song, which made me happy because when I was a teenager I was a huge King Crimson fan. King Crimson was able to combine extraordinary moments of purity and fragility with super heavy rock </span>‘n’ <span lang="EN-US">roll, and maybe they imprinted somewhere in my mind the template for some of the more schizophrenic Bad Seeds songs. King Crimson were masters of the sudden violent eruption. Bill Bruford, their drummer was simply off the planet and Robert Fripp was my favourite guitarist at the time, along with, of course, David Gilmour. As a teenager, I was a big English progressive </span><span lang="EN-US">rock fan. Pink Floyd, Jethro Tull, Procol Harum, Yes, Emerson, Lake and Palmer </span>– <span lang="EN-US">I loved that stuff. I still do. To this day, Robert Fripp and David Gilmour are giants to me, and remain among my favourite guitarists. Fripp and Gilmour are very different players but there is something about the tone of their instruments that touches me in a very deep place. The same goes for Funkadelic&#8217;s Eddie Hazel (check out Maggot Brain!). These guitarists play as if they are singing, I think. Tonally and emotionally, David Gilmour</span>’<span lang="EN-US">s guitar is simply a supercharged version of his voice </span>– <span lang="EN-US">satiny, stirring and epic. Robert Fripp</span>’<span lang="EN-US">s guitar sound is more radical, dangerous and unpredictable, but even at his most confrontational that lyrical and songlike quality is never far away.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">In 2010, Grinderman recorded a song called </span>‘<span lang="EN-US">Heathen Child</span>’ <span lang="EN-US">for the </span><em>Grinderman 2</em><span lang="EN-US"> album (part of </span>a yet to be<span lang="EN-US"> completed trilogy, you might be happy to know) and we invited Robert Fripp to play on the extended version. This version, called </span>‘<span lang="EN-US">Super Heathen Child</span>’<span lang="EN-US">, is Grinderman at their very best. I felt as though Grinderman was laying claim to their roots. Many music critics thought that Grinderman was a return to the sound of The Birthday Party, but I never understood that. </span><span lang="EN-US">From my own perspective within the band, Grinderman was much more influenced by the British progressive rock of my youth than anything else</span><span lang="EN-US"> (except Miles Davis&#8217; late electronic period, perhaps). </span>‘<span lang="EN-US">Super Heathen Child</span>’ <span lang="EN-US">continues to have an extraordinary hold over me, and contains within it a deep emotional pull because it is attached directly to my adolescence. Listening to it, I have that strange dizzying feeling a dream has when it suddenly becomes a reality; all that deep concentrated listening I did when I was a teenager manifesting itself over forty years later in a Fripp solo that just blows the mind. Recording with Robert Fripp remains one of the seismic events of my life. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">So, to answer your question, Laura, encouraged by my sons</span>’ <span lang="EN-US">appreciation for </span>‘<span lang="ES-TRAD">Starless</span>’ <span lang="EN-US">by King Crimson in the film <em>Mandy</em>, I did something that I very rarely do. I played one of my songs to my children. I put </span>‘<span lang="EN-US">Super Heathen Child</span>’ <span lang="EN-US">by Grinderman (featuring Robert Fripp</span><span lang="EN-US">) on the record player and cranked it all the way up, and well, Laura, it sounded good, and they seemed to really like it; and I was </span><em>proud.</em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>
<div id="recent-posts-4" class="widget_recent_entries"><h3>Recent Posts</h3>      <ul>
                
        <li>
          <h4><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/cope-with-negative-energy/">Issue #122</a><br>-</h4>
          <h5><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/cope-with-negative-energy/" title="In this time of illness, cynicism and cruelty, do you receive many mean or vile messages? How do you cope with that kind of negative energy?">‘In this time of illness, cynicism and cruelty, do you receive many mean or vile messages? How do you cope with that kind of negative energy?’</a></h5>
        </li>
                
        <li>
          <h4><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/pet-theory-your-creativity-flourish/">Issue #121</a><br>-</h4>
          <h5><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/pet-theory-your-creativity-flourish/" title="In an interview from 1997 in Los Angeles, you introduced us to your &#8220;pet theory&#8221;: your creativity could only flourish in a state of loss and longing, and that it needed catastrophes in your life. <br> Finally, and this is what resonated with me the most, you stated that you could not get much substance out of living a life which was content. Do you still believe that? <br> A sincere and devoted admirer of yours who sort of struggles in a content life.">‘In an interview from 1997 in Los Angeles, you introduced us to your &#8220;pet theory&#8221;: your creativity could only flourish in a state of loss and longing, and that it needed ...’</a></h5>
        </li>
                
        <li>
          <h4><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-do-you-think-about-na/">Issue #120</a><br>-</h4>
          <h5><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-do-you-think-about-na/" title="What do you think about NA? As a recovering heroin addict, I am having difficulty getting into the Narcotics Anonymous scene. I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA? As a recovering heroin addict, I am having difficulty getting into the Narcotics Anonymous scene. I see how it can help but I feel ...’</a></h5>
        </li>
              </ul>

      </div>
		</div>
		<!-- /wrapper -->

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-703" class="post-703 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #52 / July 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Do you get any nasty or annoying comments and questions via The Red Hand Files? I hope not! Thank you so much for this project &#038; your music!				</h1>
				<h3>JESSICA, BONN, GERMANY</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/do-you-get-any-nasty-or-annoying-comments-and-questions-via-the-red-hand-files-i-hope-not-thank-you-so-much-for-this-project-your-music/" title="Do you get any nasty or annoying comments and questions via The Red Hand Files? I hope not! Thank you so much for this project &#038; your music!">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-2.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-2-250x299.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-2-768x918.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-2-700x837.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-2-120x143.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">Do you ever get tired of all the pretentious fat lesbians who enjoy your music? Personally I enjoy a lot of your music, but I find most of your fans insufferable. I&#8217;m just wondering if you&#8217;re on the same page.</h1>
<h3>GEORGE, ALABAMA, USA</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Jessica and George,</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Jesus said on the cross, “Forgive them for they know not what they do.” George, I think Jesus may have been talking directly to you.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Some weeks ago, I answered a question at one of my “In Conversation” events. I was defending people’s right to say what they wanted. I was defending people’s right to offend. In short, I was defending the idea of free speech. It seems that these days free speech has fallen out of favour. The concept has been polarised by some and now a free speech advocate is often seen – I feel somewhat bizarrely – to be aligned to the </span><span lang="EN-US">far-right. However, I do believe that, even though we should have the right to say what we like, there are consequences to what we say and just because we can speak freely, </span><span lang="EN-US">it does not – and should not – inoculate us against these consequences.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">This is why it is important to think something through before sending those thoughts out into the world. When I set about answering a question on <em>The Red Hand Files</em>, I find it helpful to write my thoughts down before I formulate them into an answer. This scrutiny has its purpose, because it helps me to see where my thinking could be dishonest, unhelpful and damaging. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">So, in the interests of free speech, George, I have given you a platform. However, and I am </span><span lang="PT">speculat</span><span lang="EN-US">ing here, I think that probably </span><span lang="EN-US">ninety-nine percent of the people who read your question will think that you are being, well, a bit of an asshole. I could be wrong. It could be more. Now, you may say &#8220;So what? No one knows who I am. How can this possibly hurt me?&#8221; You may say that. But you would be wrong. I do not believe that your anonymity protects you, any more than I believe the anonymity of the hate trolls on social media protects them. I feel that there are psychic pathways that exist between us all, and that the negativity we create eventually finds its way back to us.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">The opportunity to </span><span lang="EN-US">act in a better way is one that is continuously afforded to us – to try </span><span lang="EN-US">to make the next thing we do the best thing, rather than </span><span lang="EN-US">the worst thing, the destructive thing. In this instance, George, it’s not too late for you. If you close your eyes and apologise to my fans, just maybe that negative attention will begin to dissipate. I think </span><span lang="EN-US">my fans are smart enough and sufficiently forgiving to understand that your words extend only to the margins of your own individual evolution.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">When Jesus said, “Forgive them for they know not what they </span><span lang="PT">do.</span><span lang="EN-US">” He meant that there is room for everyone to become better, every single one of us, because all of us really, “know not what we do.” We understand ourselves only to the limits of our own personal development as human beings. Yet, we can go further than that.</span><span lang="EN-US"> There is always room to evolve, to become better at being human, and to advance the common cause of humanity and civility – this applies not just to you, George, but to me too and, </span><span lang="NL">indeed, </span><span lang="EN-US">to all of us. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">With love, Nick</span></p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>
<div id="recent-posts-4" class="widget_recent_entries"><h3>Recent Posts</h3>      <ul>
                
        <li>
          <h4><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/cope-with-negative-energy/">Issue #122</a><br>-</h4>
          <h5><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/cope-with-negative-energy/" title="In this time of illness, cynicism and cruelty, do you receive many mean or vile messages? How do you cope with that kind of negative energy?">‘In this time of illness, cynicism and cruelty, do you receive many mean or vile messages? How do you cope with that kind of negative energy?’</a></h5>
        </li>
                
        <li>
          <h4><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/pet-theory-your-creativity-flourish/">Issue #121</a><br>-</h4>
          <h5><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/pet-theory-your-creativity-flourish/" title="In an interview from 1997 in Los Angeles, you introduced us to your &#8220;pet theory&#8221;: your creativity could only flourish in a state of loss and longing, and that it needed catastrophes in your life. <br> Finally, and this is what resonated with me the most, you stated that you could not get much substance out of living a life which was content. Do you still believe that? <br> A sincere and devoted admirer of yours who sort of struggles in a content life.">‘In an interview from 1997 in Los Angeles, you introduced us to your &#8220;pet theory&#8221;: your creativity could only flourish in a state of loss and longing, and that it needed ...’</a></h5>
        </li>
                
        <li>
          <h4><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-do-you-think-about-na/">Issue #120</a><br>-</h4>
          <h5><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-do-you-think-about-na/" title="What do you think about NA? As a recovering heroin addict, I am having difficulty getting into the Narcotics Anonymous scene. I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA? As a recovering heroin addict, I am having difficulty getting into the Narcotics Anonymous scene. I see how it can help but I feel ...’</a></h5>
        </li>
              </ul>

      </div>
		</div>

		<title>[ ] Part of the Pinocchio story is about this: Geppetto (Pinocchio’s father) is swallowed by a giant whale while searching for Pinocchio. When Pinocchio hears of this news, he travels deep into the ocean to find the whale that swallowed up Geppetto. Pinocchio makes his way inside the whale and reunites with his father. They build a huge fire causing the whale to sneeze. They are then blasted ashore and left to start their lives over together. If this is a truism that, in essence, the son saved his father from the abyss. Then now what of people like us? What happens if the son dies? Do we lose the ability to be saved and evolve? [ ] - The Red Hand Files : The Red Hand Files</title>
