	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-695" class="post-695 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #51 / July 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					[ ] Part of the Pinocchio story is about this: <br><br> Geppetto (Pinocchio’s father) is swallowed by a giant whale while searching for Pinocchio. When Pinocchio hears of this news, he travels deep into the ocean to find the whale that swallowed up Geppetto. Pinocchio makes his way inside the whale and reunites with his father. They build a huge fire causing the whale to sneeze. They are then blasted ashore and left to start their lives over together. <br><br> If this is a truism that, in essence, the son saved his father from the abyss. Then now what of people like us? What happens if the son dies? Do we lose the ability to be saved and evolve? [ ]				</h1>
				<h3>K, LONDON, UK</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/part-of-the-pinocchio-story-is-about-this-geppetto-pinocchios-father-is-swallowed-by-a-giant-whale-while-searching-for-pinocchio-when-pinocchio-hears-of-this-news-he-travels-deep-in/" title="[ ] Part of the Pinocchio story is about this:  Geppetto (Pinocchio’s father) is swallowed by a giant whale while searching for Pinocchio. When Pinocchio hears of this news, he travels deep into the ocean to find the whale that swallowed up Geppetto. Pinocchio makes his way inside the whale and reunites with his father. They build a huge fire causing the whale to sneeze. They are then blasted ashore and left to start their lives over together.  If this is a truism that, in essence, the son saved his father from the abyss. Then now what of people like us? What happens if the son dies? Do we lose the ability to be saved and evolve? [ ]">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-1.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-1-250x141.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-1-768x433.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-1-700x395.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-1-120x68.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear K,</span></p>
<p class="BodyAA"><span lang="EN-US">I read about the death of your son in the paper. I am so very sorry. Thank you for your letter &#8211; it was honest, searching and beautifully articulated. I think that it is better not to publish it in full though, so as not to rekindle any attention that could cause unnecessary suffering for you and your family. I hope you don’t mind.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">You talked about the story of Pinocchio, a story I love very much. I included it as one of my favourite books in a recent Red Hand File. Geppetto, the maker and father of the puppet-boy Pinocchio, trapped in the darkened belly of the beast, is a very powerful metaphor for the father who has been separated from his child – the grieving father. The epic story of the incorrigible Pinocchio’s attempt at reuniting with his father and becoming a real boy is one of the most moving in all literature. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">We grieving fathers, all of us, begin our </span><span lang="EN-US">time in the vast and darkened belly of the beast. We also have become the child, as you said</span> <span lang="EN-US">in your letter – and perhaps some dark force had always destined that to be. For a while we become the one that died, as we are plunged into a darkness from which there seems no escape. But you also mentioned the inability of the child to save the father from ‘the abyss’ if the child has died. Eventually, I found this not to be true. I found the </span><em><span lang="IT">spirit</span></em><span lang="EN-US"> of my son was ultimately able to release me from this terrible place. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">The spirits of our children can become the guides that eventually lead us out of the dark. After a while, I found the spirit of my son</span> <span lang="EN-US">braved the sea and found and entered the whale, and lighting the fire, convulsed the whale and released me from </span><span lang="EN-US">its unlit interior, ‘blasting me ashore’. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Most of the </span><span lang="EN-US">time, these days, I feel on solid ground and in the air and the light. But the process has been slow. You are in your very early days. It is four years to the day for me, yet still my son comes to the rescue – parenting me, <em>fathering </em>me, as the darkness reasserts itself. Yet I see a day when my son can let go of my hand and return to his spirit-form – the child – and be free. I can become his father again. That day is coming, but is not </span><span lang="EN-US">here yet, for you or for me. We are still, as you said, on some level, ‘living in another world’ with the departed. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">I read Pinocchio again this week, after you wrote to me – I hadn’t read it since the death of my son – and I found it very helpful. What a deep little book it is. These stories talk to us, down the ages, and give us powerful images that can articulate our deepest feelings and help make some sense of things. Thank you for reminding me of it and, again, I am so sorry to hear about your little boy. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
<div></div>
<div><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-696" src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture2-1-250x183.png" alt="" width="250" height="183" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture2-1-250x183.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture2-1-768x563.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture2-1-700x513.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture2-1-120x88.png 120w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture2-1.png 864w" sizes="(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px" /></div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-683" class="post-683 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #50 / July 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					<P ALIGN=LEFT>Do you pray with you&#8217;r family and maybe friends,<br><br> hopeing that sometimes &#8216;someone&#8217; leesen you&#8217;r<br><br> despered &#8216;litle&#8217; iner-voice, to get answer<br><br> or gidence, ephifany, in this cruel world,<br><br> which most of us taket for granted?				</h1>
				<h3>GIANELLI, PULA, CROATIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/do-you-pray-with-your-family-and-maybe-friends-hopeing-that-sometimes-someone-leesen-your-despered-litle-iner-voice-to-get-answer-or-gidence-ephifany-in-this-cruel-world-which-most-of/" title="Do you pray with you&#8217;r family and maybe friends, hopeing that sometimes &#8216;someone&#8217; leesen you&#8217;r despered &#8216;litle&#8217; iner-voice, to get answer or gidence, ephifany, in this cruel world, which most of us taket for granted?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture2.png 862w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture2-250x379.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture2-768x1164.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture2-700x1061.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture2-120x182.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 862px) 100vw, 862px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Gianelli,</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">I love this despairing and soulful question so much. I have put it in verse form and changed the spacing so that it behaves as a poem, rather than a question, as it rises hauntingly from the dark. I hope you don’t mind. I will do my best to answer it.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Firstly, do I pray with my family and friends? The answer is sadly no. My family,</span> <span lang="EN-US">and especially my friends, are mostly not the praying types, and I’m not sure they would know who to pray to if they were  – apart that is from darling Susie, my wife. Susie prays a lot, I think, but alone, I would say, terribly alone. I do pray myself – and I also meditate; prayer and meditation are different practices but they serve a similar function. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Do I hope someone listens to my prayers – to my inner voice? Well, I don’t know where my prayers go. I don’t know if anyone is listening. However, I still kneel down alone and pray. My prayers mostly revolve around the wellbeing of the ones I love, because I feel, possibly erroneously, that the world aligns itself in such a way that it draws those I send my prayers to closer to me. I feel, without any evidence to suggest that this is true, that the people I pray for benefit from my prayers, as if the energy of my prayers travels along streams of collective goodness that connect us all in some way, in a sort of humanistic cooperation of light and compassion.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Do I get guidance from prayer and meditation? The answer is certainly, yes. After applying my full attention to whatever it is I am praying about – and to whoever it is I am praying to –</span> <span lang="EN-US">I feel that I simply know how to proceed</span> <span lang="EN-US">in a rightful way; one that causes the least harm to myself and to others.</span> <span lang="EN-US">I feel less a victim of the endless self-defeating thoughts that can go on in my mind, and instead I feel a quietness and clarity of thought.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Is this world cruel? I don’t think so. I think this world is indifferent and indifference is not cruelty. What connects me to you, Gianelli, and you to every other sentient being in the universe, is that the universe, simply does not care about us; it does not act with malice or desire to harm us – it is simply unaffected by our condition. If one acknowledges this state of affairs, then it sets up a situation that allows us to make a simple choice – either we respond to the indifference of the universe with self-pity and narcissism – as if the world has in some way personally betrayed us – and live our lives in a cynical, pessimistic and self-serving manner; or we stand tall, set our eyes clearly upon this unfeeling universe and <em>love it all the same</em> – even though, or especially because, it doesn’t love us. This act of cosmic defiance, of subversive optimism, of unconditional and insubordinate love, is the greatest act of human beauty we can perform. To stand before this great, blank, heartless cosmic event and say: ‘<em>We believe in you’. ‘We love you’. ‘We care for you’</em>. This is the definition of grace, Gianelli, and this is the epiphany you speak of. We create our own divinity, our own Godliness, through our ferocious need. We yearn the heavens awake, and if we are quiet, in prayer or in meditation, sometimes we can feel the heavens stirring, breathing our fragile and reckless love back through us.  </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Thank you for your question.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Love, Nick</span></p>
<div></div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-669" class="post-669 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #49 / July 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I&#8217;m a young writer. Your music has inspired me deeply in terms of not being afraid of throwing my feelings into my texts, but sometimes it is not easy to describe them in words. I guess you learned to do that through books and poems. I wish you could recommend to me your favourite texts so I can learn from them too.				</h1>
				<h3>ALEJANDRÁ, BOGOTA, COLUMBIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/recommend-your-favourite-texts/" title="I&#8217;m a young writer. Your music has inspired me deeply in terms of not being afraid of throwing my feelings into my texts, but sometimes it is not easy to describe them in words. I guess you learned to do that through books and poems. I wish you could recommend to me your favourite texts so I can learn from them too.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1.png 856w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-250x167.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-768x513.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-700x468.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Picture1-120x80.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 856px) 100vw, 856px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							FLANNERY O'CONNOR							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">I&#8217;m in search of books to read. Which books and writers would you recommend to a 19-year old girl?</h1>
<h3>EVA, VORDINGBORG, DENMARK</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">Do you have a list of books that you think everybody should read, especially somebody in his early twenties?</h1>
<h3>MARAT, BUCHAREST, ROMANIA</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p class="Body"><span lang="ES-TRAD">Dear Alejandr</span>á<span lang="EN-US">, Eva and Marat,</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">I read somewhere that between the ages of seventeen and twenty-four our brains are super-receptive, and that it is the period when we form acutely close attachments to things </span>– <span lang="EN-US">songs, books, films, paintings etc. </span>– <span lang="EN-US">that will be the guiding lights that lead us through the rest of our lives.</span> <span lang="ES-TRAD">So, Alejandr</span>á<span lang="EN-US">, Eva and Marat, you are all in those bright and shining years where you should absorb as much art as possible. Drink it up, while the thrill is there, whenever and wherever you can, because as the years go on, that flush of wonder may subside, as we direct our attention to our own work.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">As with the other lists I have posted here on <em>The Red Hand Files,</em> this is in no way definitive and by no means reflects the </span>‘<span lang="EN-US">best</span>’ <span lang="EN-US">books I have read, nor are these necessarily the greatest books by the particular author I have chosen, but here are a dozen books of fiction that I love. Most of them I read when I was a quite young, and each of them introduced me to worlds that were strange and fascinating and new. I hope you like them. </span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="Body"><strong><span lang="EN-US">Crime and Punishment </span></strong><span lang="NL">Fyodor Dostoyevsky</span></p>
<p class="Body"><strong><span lang="IT">The Adventures of Pinocchio</span></strong><span lang="IT"> Carlo Collodi</span></p>
<p class="Body"><strong><span lang="EN-US">Blood Meridian </span></strong><span lang="EN-US">Cormac McCarthy</span></p>
<p class="Body"><strong><span lang="EN-US">The Rings of Saturn</span></strong><span lang="EN-US"> W. G. Sebald</span></p>
<p class="Body"><strong><span lang="IT">Lolita</span></strong> Vladimir Nabokov</p>
<p class="Body"><strong><span lang="EN-US">As I Lay Dying </span></strong><span lang="DE">William Faulkner</span></p>
<p class="Body"><strong><span lang="DE">Train Dreams </span></strong><span lang="FR">Denis Johnson</span></p>
<p class="Body"><strong>Moby Dick</strong> Herman Melville</p>
<p class="Body"><strong><span lang="EN-US">Coming Through Slaughter</span></strong><span lang="NL"> Michael Ondaatje </span></p>
<p class="Body"><strong><span lang="EN-US">Wise Blood</span></strong><span lang="EN-US"> Flannery O</span>’<span lang="DE">Connor</span></p>
<p class="Body"><strong><span lang="EN-US">Tess of the d</span>’<span lang="EN-US">Urbervilles</span></strong><span lang="DA"> Thomas Hardy</span></p>
<p class="Body"><strong><span lang="EN-US">The Count of Monte Cristo </span></strong><span lang="FR">Alexandre Dumas</span></p>
</div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<div>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Much love, Nick</span></p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-664" class="post-664 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #48 / June 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I was lucky enough to be at your recent London show and you played Cosmic Dancer by T Rex. It reminded me how Morrissey also covered and released this. In turn it reminded me of my current struggle reconciling his recent unsavoury far right support to how I used to put him on a pedestal. <br>Generally, is it possible to separate the latter-day artist from his earlier art? More specifically, what are your views on Morrissey, both early days and his newer more ugly persona?				</h1>
				<h3>MARK, REDHILL, UK</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/views-on-morrissey/" title="I was lucky enough to be at your recent London show and you played Cosmic Dancer by T Rex. It reminded me how Morrissey also covered and released this. In turn it reminded me of my current struggle reconciling his recent unsavoury far right support to how I used to put him on a pedestal. Generally, is it possible to separate the latter-day artist from his earlier art? More specifically, what are your views on Morrissey, both early days and his newer more ugly persona?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-3.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-3.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-3-250x327.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-3-768x1005.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-3-700x916.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-3-120x157.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p><span lang="EN-US">Dear Mark,</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">I understand it is very difficult when an artist you admire reveals something about themselves which you feel casts an unhappy shadow across their work &#8211; and this is by no means exclusive to Morrissey. It happens all the time and I have talked a little about this in a previous issue of The Red Hand Files. </span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">I think perhaps it would be helpful to you if you saw the proprietorship of a song in a different way. Personally, when I write a song and release it to the public,</span> <span lang="EN-US">I feel</span> <span lang="EN-US">it stops being <em>my </em>song. It has been offered up to my audience and they, if they care to, take possession of that song and become its custodian. The integrity of the song now rests not with the artist, but with the listener. </span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">When I listen to a beloved song &#8211; Neil Young’s ‘On the Beach’, for instance &#8211; I feel, at my very core, that that song is speaking to me and to me alone, that I have taken possession of that song exclusively. I feel, beyond all rationality, that the song has been written with me in mind and, as it weaves itself into the fabric of my life, I become its steward, understanding it better than anybody else ever could. I think we all can relate to this feeling of owning a song. This is the singular beauty of music.</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">Perhaps it doesn’t matter what Neil Young’s personal conduct may be like therefore, or Morrissey’s, as they have handed over ownership of the songs to their audience. Their views and behaviour are separate issues – Morrissey’s political opinion becomes irrelevant. Whatever inanities he may postulate, we cannot overlook the fact that he has written a vast and extraordinary catalogue, which has enhanced the lives of his many fans beyond recognition. This is no small thing. He has created original and distinctive works of unparalleled beauty, that will long outlast his offending political alliances.</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">At my recent &#8216;In Conversation&#8217; event in Nottingham a gentleman put forward an excellent challenge to my views on free speech &#8211; he pointed out the perceived</span> <span lang="EN-US">racism of Morrissey’s political stance and told how personally wounded he felt by Morrissey’s views on immigration. As I sat in my dressing room after the show, I wished I had done a better job of answering his question &#8211; I felt I had made a poorly constructed, over-earnest and possibly insensitive defence of Morrissey’s right to his opinions, <em>no matter what they are</em>.</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">I very much appreciate people challenging my views. The ‘In Conversation’ events are fluid in form and very much a work in progress, and they are intended at times to prompt debate. Sometimes certain uncomfortable issues are raised, but a different point of view is always welcome. Often it can serve as a kind of corrective – even an education – and can be extremely helpful to me next time that same subject is broached. </span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">Open debate and conversation are the very structure of civilisation, and in Nottingham it was a privilege to be challenged by this very thoughtful young man. However, even though I was unsatisfied by my own response, I still believe that despite how upsetting Morrissey’s views may be to the marginalised and dispossessed members of society, or anyone else for that matter, he still should have the freedom to express his views, just as others should have the freedom to challenge them – even if just to know in what guise their enemy may appear. The charge that defending a person’s right to their opinions somehow aligns one with their views makes no sense at all and strikes at the heart of the problem itself – that of conflating the concept of free speech with bigotry. This is very dangerous territory indeed.</span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">As a songwriter and someone who believes songs possess extraordinary healing power, I am saddened by the thought that songs by arguably the greatest lyricist of his generation &#8211; songs like ‘This Charming Man’, ‘Reel Around the Fountain’ and ‘Last Night I Dreamed Somebody Loved Me’ &#8211; are consigned to the moral dustbin by those who feel they have been tainted by his current political posturing. I respect and understand why people respond in this way, but can’t help but feel it is of significant personal loss to them. </span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">Perhaps it is better to simply let Morrissey have his views, challenge them when and wherever possible, but allow his music to live on, bearing in mind we are all conflicted individuals – messy, flawed and prone to lunacies. We should thank God that there are some among us that create works of beauty beyond anything most of us can barely imagine, even as some of those same people fall prey to regressive and dangerous belief systems. </span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-US">Love, Nick</span></p>
<div></div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-660" class="post-660 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #47 / June 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					You are the only musical artist that comes readily to mind whose work has improved, by an order of magnitude, after having given up drugs and alcohol. If this statement resonates with you, what are your thoughts?				</h1>
				<h3>MICHAEL, AUSTIN, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/work-improved-after-giving-up-alcohol/" title="You are the only musical artist that comes readily to mind whose work has improved, by an order of magnitude, after having given up drugs and alcohol. If this statement resonates with you, what are your thoughts?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture2.png 862w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture2-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture2-250x250.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture2-768x768.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture2-700x700.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture2-120x120.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 862px) 100vw, 862px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							PHOTO BY BLEDDYN BUTCHER							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">The greatest songs, I think, you wrote under influence of drugs. How is it these days?</h1>
<h3>PETI, ZURICH, SWITZERLAND</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p>Dear Michael and Peti,</p>
<p>Clearly you people have a difference of opinion. Maybe many an hour is spent amongst Bad Seeds fans squaring the merits of a song like <em>The Mercy Seat</em>, that was written during a period of serious and prolonged heroin and amphetamine use, against <em>Jubilee Street</em>, which was written by two drug-free vegetarians, or comparing a ballad like <em>Love Letter</em> (very stoned) with its tragic counterpart, <em>I Need You</em> (very straight). What makes me happy is that there is actually a conversation to be had. In rock ‘n’ roll there almost never is. Sometimes, but mostly never.</p>
<p>But all speculation aside, the value of a song does not rest with the song itself, but rather the feeling it can provoke in the listener. What moves me may not move you. And so it goes. I see the effect the songs have on my audience when we perform them live so know that these value judgements have little intrinsic meaning &#8211; <em>Girl in Amber</em> may have a young fan in floods of tears and another fan stifling yawns and looking at their watch, and a song like <em>Tupelo</em> can tap into a reservoir of nostalgia for an older fan, but to a millennial, say, be just some crazy shit about a guy called Elvis (and who is Elvis anyway?) One man at a recent <em>In Conversations</em> event told me he got married to <em>Rock of Gibraltar</em> (true story), yet a Gibraltarian wrote to me saying that the release of this ‘atrocious song’ was a ‘dark day for Gibraltar’ and that he had suggested lowering the national flag to half-mast. I have people write to me to say <em>Skeleton Tree</em> is the worst record the Bad Seeds ever made, and I have also read letters from people who value that record beyond all others.</p>
<p>In the end, all I can do as a songwriter is to follow my own heart. I have written most days of my adult life, some of them stoned and some of them straight, and the most I have been able to do was to give the process itself my best shot. The actual value of the songs is weighed entirely in the hearts of those who choose to receive them.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-647" class="post-647 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #46 / June 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					In Issue #43 you gave David a song lyric. Can I have one too?				</h1>
				<h3>RAY, HAWAII, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/song-lyric-can-i-have-one-too/" title="In Issue #43 you gave David a song lyric. Can I have one too?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-copy.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-copy.png 879w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-copy-250x243.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-copy-768x748.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-copy-700x682.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-copy-120x117.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 879px) 100vw, 879px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">How do you forgive yourself for the horrible things you did to someone else in the throes of addiction?</h1>
<h3>MATT, MONTREAL, CANADA</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Ray and Matt,</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">As chance would have it I was clearing some papers off my desk yesterday and found these words,</span> <span lang="EN-US">which I think I wrote a couple of years ago but sort of forgot about. The lyric is called ‘<em>Kiss of the Spider Woman’ </em>and is actually pretty good. As a rock ‘n’ roll lyric it is more fit for purpose than ‘</span><em><span lang="IT">Incinerator Man</span></em><em><span lang="EN-US">’ </span></em><span lang="EN-US">(from #43) –</span> <span lang="EN-US">which, to be honest, reads more like a conventional poem –</span> <span lang="EN-US">so it’s probably easier to arrange these words to music. Ray, you can have it, if you like. If you record and release it, and it becomes a hit and you go on to become a world-famous pop star, well, I’ll be happy. I’ll also be very surprised as the song is about heroin addiction.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">The lyric recalls a time, back in the eighties, when I was stranded in what had to be the worst ‘hotel’ in Tijuana (possibly in the world), withdrawing from a particularly nasty heroin habit. There was a girl involved, of course, and she was Mexican and beautiful and had a tattoo of a spider’s web on her elbow. We’d run out of money and I was strung-out and everything was suitably sordid. We were like a couple of ruined characters from some dreadful Bukowski novel, and if you think it sounds sort of romantic – it wasn’t. I mostly</span> <span lang="EN-US">remember lying in my underwear on the ‘bed’ in a pool of sweat, watching insects drop from the ceiling and crawl around on my chest and not having the strength of purpose to do anything about it. I don’t usually dredge up old memories and put them in songs – it’s bad form, in my opinion, it feels like a sort of betrayal of <em>the now</em> &#8211; so this is why the song probably never saw the light of day. Having said that, it is a solid rock ‘n’ roll lyric and maybe you can do something with it. I don’t want it.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US"> </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><strong><em><span lang="EN-US">KISS OF THE SPIDER WOMAN</span></em></strong></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">I awake to a voice calling from the other side of the wall</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">I am alone and tangled in a web of backward thought </span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US"> </span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">The Mexican girl with the luminous skin</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">Sponged my face that had fallen on the dosshouse floor</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US"> </span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">The Mexican girl with the web on her elbow </span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">Had eyes like windows and legs like a door</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US"> </span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">I lay there three days dying, three days or maybe more</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">We couldn’t close the windows and we sure couldn’t open the door</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US"> </span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">I love women, but I always loved drugs more</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">Even when I was in ‘em, I was halfway out the door to score</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US"> </span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">I kissed the Spider Woman and she spun me deep inside her silk</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">Hung me from the door frame, rubbed me in argan oil and milk</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US"> </span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">How many blue skies were lost there, how many missed opportunities?</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">How many knocked doors unanswered, how many phones left to ring?</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US"> </span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">How many days lived in the centre of the web, alone and scared?</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">How often did I call along the threads, only to find nobody there?</span></em></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">I am alone and tangled in a web of backward thought</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">I am the voice calling from the other side of the wall</span></em></p>
<div></div>
<div style="text-align: center;">***</div>
<div></div>
<div>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">So, not a bad lyric, with an elegant shift from the description of memory as a ‘web of tangled thought’, to the ‘web on her elbow’, to the idea of the Spider Woman being the addiction itself, and being ‘spun deep inside her silk’ – lovely metaphor for being stoned, if I may say so myself – followed by the melancholy idea, which every long-term addict will recognise, of ‘calling along the threads to find nobody there’. It then returns full circle to the sticky lacework of recollection. The song is, in itself, a web. This is good stuff, and if you placed the lyrics over a linear two-chord</span> <span lang="EN-US">groove, like ‘Born in the USA’, or ‘Jane Says’ by Jane’s Addiction, or ‘Achy Breaky Heart’ or something like that, well, you never know, you may have a monster hit on your hands! Then again you mightn’t. In this game, you never do know.  </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">If you are going to use these words, I might just draw your attention to the lovely couplet that divides the lyric into its two parts –</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">I love women, but I always loved drugs more</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><em><span lang="EN-US">Even when I was in ‘em, I was halfway out the door to score</span></em></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">This is in no way a glorification of drug taking, rather these words are heavy with a very real regret for the utter havoc my heroin addiction caused in my relationships with women. Every addict, male or female, will identify with these two lines. However, despite the thread of despair that runs through them, there is much fun to be had in the words themselves and I am especially proud of rhyming ‘<em>women</em>’ with ‘<em>in ‘em’ </em>and the momentum of the internal trip-rhyme ‘</span><em><span lang="NL">door</span></em><em><span lang="EN-US">’ </span></em><span lang="EN-US">with <em>‘score’, </em>as if the narrator of the song is already making a run for it. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">And, Matt, just to say, all addicts at times do horrible things, because addicts are people and people at times do horrible things. The real difficulty that arises around self-forgiveness is when you come to realise that you still do horrible things even when you are clean. My advice to you is this &#8211; <em>be kind</em> &#8211; to yourself and to others. It is the simplest of remedies but remarkably effective. A small, bright act of kindness towards another human being is not only a gesture of existential hope, it also reconciles us with the world, and ultimately becomes the path to self-forgiveness. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
<div></div>
</div>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

SOURCE: https://www.theredhandfiles.com/into-my-arms-love/
<!doctype html>
<html lang="en-AU" class="no-js">
	<head>
		<meta charset="UTF-8">
		<title>Nick Cave - The Red Hand Files - Issue #45 - Dear Nick, I was at your In Conversation event in Antwerp. There was a man with a light and a microphone, but suddenly he was gone. I just wanted to tell you something. I didn&#039;t want to tell you and all the other people the full story that evening, just a bit, but I want to tell it to you now. My partner died in 2014: traffic. At that moment I was actually pregnant by him, but nobody knew. It was still a little early and I was pregnant after fertility-treatment. He died and five days after his death, I lost his child. Our child. He was a huge fan of your music and I think I became a fan of your music because of him. &#039;Into My Arms&#039; became our song. The song was playing and he asked me to dance and so it became our song. Nothing special, but for us it was a special song. I wanted to play it at his funeral. People asked me afterwards if I thought it was a love song or a song of loss. A song of love, I thought. It was a silly question - but the man I love was there in a coffin and I just wanted to hear that song on the day he was buried, because it was our song, the song of our love for each other and I loved that man and I still love him. Nothing more, nothing less, that was the reason I wanted it played at his funeral. We had already bought tickets for a Bad Seeds concert together. He was dead, so because of that my best friend went with me. You played &#039;Into My Arms&#039; and I started to cry, not because of the sadness, but because of the beauty of it. I was standing there and for the first time since he passed away, I felt my partner standing by my side. Maybe it sounds stupid, but I really felt him standing by my side. My best friend cuddled me and gave me a kiss on my forehead. She cuddled me in a strong way. I was really crying, smiling too and I felt love everywhere, for and from my partner and for and from my best friend too. I went into a kind of trance of love, it was an amazing experience, that&#039;s for sure, and it was when you were playing that song. I&#039;m crying now, because I feel that same feeling. I still think it was wonderful. It was 2015, those days. My best friend died in 2016: cancer. &#039;Into My Arms&#039; is not just the song for me and my partner anymore, it is the song for and from my best friend and all the people I love, but those two people are standing for true love for me too, so it became a song of true love, true love I actually feel when you play that song. Since they died, I like to be at any of your concerts, because of the amazing beauty I feel when you play &#039;Into My Arms&#039;. I feel Guido and Amber beside me. And all I wanted to ask was if you would play that song, so I could feel them again beside me that evening. The man with the light and the microphone was suddenly gone, but you played &#039;Into My Arms&#039; anyway. I was very grateful that you played it. Now I just want to say &quot;thanks&quot;, for that song, for all of your songs, for such a wonderful evening, because it was with love. : The Red Hand Files</title>

<!-- This site is optimized with the Schema plugin v1.7.1 - https://schema.press -->
<script type="application/ld+json">{
    "@context": "http://schema.org",
    "@type": "BreadcrumbList",
    "itemListElement": [
        {
            "@type": "ListItem",
            "position": 1,
            "item": {
                "@id": "https://www.theredhandfiles.com",
                "name": "Home"
            }
        },
        {
            "@type": "ListItem",
            "position": 2,
            "item": {
                "@id": "https://www.theredhandfiles.com/into-my-arms-love/",
                "name": "Dear Nick, I was at your In Conversation event in Antwerp. There was a man with a light and a microphone, but suddenly he was gone. I just wanted to tell you something. I didn&#8217;t want to tell you and all the other people the full story that evening, just a bit, but I want to tell it to you now.  My partner died in 2014: traffic. At that moment I was actually pregnant by him, but nobody knew. It was still a little early and I was pregnant after fertility-treatment. He died and five days after his death, I lost his child. Our child. He was a huge fan of your music and I think I became a fan of your music because of him.  &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217; became our song. The song was playing and he asked me to dance and so it became our song. Nothing special, but for us it was a special song. I wanted to play it at his funeral. People asked me afterwards if I thought it was a love song or a song of loss. A song of love, I thought. It was a silly question &#8211; but the man I love was there in a coffin and I just wanted to hear that song on the day he was buried, because it was our song, the song of our love for each other and I loved that man and I still love him. Nothing more, nothing less, that was the reason I wanted it played at his funeral.  We had already bought tickets for a Bad Seeds concert together. He was dead, so because of that my best friend went with me. You played &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217; and I started to cry, not because of the sadness, but because of the beauty of it. I was standing there and for the first time since he passed away, I felt my partner standing by my side. Maybe it sounds stupid, but I really felt him standing by my side. My best friend cuddled me and gave me a kiss on my forehead. She cuddled me in a strong way. I was really crying, smiling too and I felt love everywhere, for and from my partner and for and from my best friend too. I went into a kind of trance of love, it was an amazing experience, that&#8217;s for sure, and it was when you were playing that song.  I&#8217;m crying now, because I feel that same feeling. I still think it was wonderful. It was 2015, those days. My best friend died in 2016: cancer. &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217; is not just the song for me and my partner anymore, it is the song for and from my best friend and all the people I love, but those two people are standing for true love for me too, so it became a song of true love, true love I actually feel when you play that song. Since they died, I like to be at any of your concerts, because of the amazing beauty I feel when you play &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217;. I feel Guido and Amber beside me. And all I wanted to ask was if you would play that song, so I could feel them again beside me that evening.  The man with the light and the microphone was suddenly gone, but you played &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217; anyway. I was very grateful that you played it. Now I just want to say &#8220;thanks&#8221;, for that song, for all of your songs, for such a wonderful evening, because it was with love.",
                "image": "https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Edvard_Munch_-_The_Kiss_-_Google_Art_Project.jpeg"
            }
        }
    ]
}</script>

	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-642" class="post-642 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #45 / June 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					<P ALIGN=LEFT>Dear Nick, <br><br>I was at your In Conversation event in Antwerp. There was a man with a light and a microphone, but suddenly he was gone. I just wanted to tell you something. <br><br>I didn&#8217;t want to tell you and all the other people the full story that evening, just a bit, but I want to tell it to you now.  <br><br>My partner died in 2014: traffic. At that moment I was actually pregnant by him, but nobody knew. It was still a little early and I was pregnant after fertility-treatment. He died and five days after his death, I lost his child. Our child. He was a huge fan of your music and I think I became a fan of your music because of him.  <br><br>&#8216;Into My Arms&#8217; became our song. The song was playing and he asked me to dance and so it became our song. Nothing special, but for us it was a special song. I wanted to play it at his funeral. People asked me afterwards if I thought it was a love song or a song of loss. A song of love, I thought. It was a silly question &#8211; but the man I love was there in a coffin and I just wanted to hear that song on the day he was buried, because it was our song, the song of our love for each other and I loved that man and I still love him. Nothing more, nothing less, that was the reason I wanted it played at his funeral.  <br><br>We had already bought tickets for a Bad Seeds concert together. He was dead, so because of that my best friend went with me. You played &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217; and I started to cry, not because of the sadness, but because of the beauty of it. I was standing there and for the first time since he passed away, I felt my partner standing by my side. Maybe it sounds stupid, but I really felt him standing by my side. My best friend cuddled me and gave me a kiss on my forehead. She cuddled me in a strong way. I was really crying, smiling too and I felt love everywhere, for and from my partner and for and from my best friend too. I went into a kind of trance of love, it was an amazing experience, that&#8217;s for sure, and it was when you were playing that song.  <br><br>I&#8217;m crying now, because I feel that same feeling. I still think it was wonderful. It was 2015, those days. My best friend died in 2016: cancer. &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217; is not just the song for me and my partner anymore, it is the song for and from my best friend and all the people I love, but those two people are standing for true love for me too, so it became a song of true love, true love I actually feel when you play that song. Since they died, I like to be at any of your concerts, because of the amazing beauty I feel when you play &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217;. I feel Guido and Amber beside me. And all I wanted to ask was if you would play that song, so I could feel them again beside me that evening.  <br><br>The man with the light and the microphone was suddenly gone, but you played &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217; anyway. I was very grateful that you played it. Now I just want to say &#8220;thanks&#8221;, for that song, for all of your songs, for such a wonderful evening, because it was with love.</P>				</h1>
				<h3>ELS, MECHELEN, BELGIUM</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/into-my-arms-love/" title="Dear Nick, I was at your In Conversation event in Antwerp. There was a man with a light and a microphone, but suddenly he was gone. I just wanted to tell you something. I didn&#8217;t want to tell you and all the other people the full story that evening, just a bit, but I want to tell it to you now.  My partner died in 2014: traffic. At that moment I was actually pregnant by him, but nobody knew. It was still a little early and I was pregnant after fertility-treatment. He died and five days after his death, I lost his child. Our child. He was a huge fan of your music and I think I became a fan of your music because of him.  &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217; became our song. The song was playing and he asked me to dance and so it became our song. Nothing special, but for us it was a special song. I wanted to play it at his funeral. People asked me afterwards if I thought it was a love song or a song of loss. A song of love, I thought. It was a silly question &#8211; but the man I love was there in a coffin and I just wanted to hear that song on the day he was buried, because it was our song, the song of our love for each other and I loved that man and I still love him. Nothing more, nothing less, that was the reason I wanted it played at his funeral.  We had already bought tickets for a Bad Seeds concert together. He was dead, so because of that my best friend went with me. You played &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217; and I started to cry, not because of the sadness, but because of the beauty of it. I was standing there and for the first time since he passed away, I felt my partner standing by my side. Maybe it sounds stupid, but I really felt him standing by my side. My best friend cuddled me and gave me a kiss on my forehead. She cuddled me in a strong way. I was really crying, smiling too and I felt love everywhere, for and from my partner and for and from my best friend too. I went into a kind of trance of love, it was an amazing experience, that&#8217;s for sure, and it was when you were playing that song.  I&#8217;m crying now, because I feel that same feeling. I still think it was wonderful. It was 2015, those days. My best friend died in 2016: cancer. &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217; is not just the song for me and my partner anymore, it is the song for and from my best friend and all the people I love, but those two people are standing for true love for me too, so it became a song of true love, true love I actually feel when you play that song. Since they died, I like to be at any of your concerts, because of the amazing beauty I feel when you play &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217;. I feel Guido and Amber beside me. And all I wanted to ask was if you would play that song, so I could feel them again beside me that evening.  The man with the light and the microphone was suddenly gone, but you played &#8216;Into My Arms&#8217; anyway. I was very grateful that you played it. Now I just want to say &#8220;thanks&#8221;, for that song, for all of your songs, for such a wonderful evening, because it was with love.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Edvard_Munch_-_The_Kiss_-_Google_Art_Project.jpeg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Edvard_Munch_-_The_Kiss_-_Google_Art_Project.jpeg 960w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Edvard_Munch_-_The_Kiss_-_Google_Art_Project-250x306.jpeg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Edvard_Munch_-_The_Kiss_-_Google_Art_Project-768x941.jpeg 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Edvard_Munch_-_The_Kiss_-_Google_Art_Project-700x858.jpeg 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Edvard_Munch_-_The_Kiss_-_Google_Art_Project-120x147.jpeg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 960px) 100vw, 960px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							"THE SONG WAS PLAYING AND HE ASKED ME TO DANCE."							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Els,</span></p>
<p>Thank you for this beautiful letter. It means a great deal to me.</p>
<p><span lang="NL">Much love, Nick</span></p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->

Do you still believe that? <br> A sincere and devoted admirer of yours who sort of struggles in a content life.">‘In an interview from 1997 in Los Angeles, you introduced us to your &#8220;pet theory&#8221;: your creativity could only flourish in a state of loss and longing, and that it needed ...’</a></h5>

As a recovering heroin addict, I am having difficulty getting into the Narcotics Anonymous scene. I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA? 	<head>
		<meta charset="UTF-8">
		<title>Nick Cave - The Red Hand Files - Issue #44 - I&#039;m non-binary, which (sorry if you already know this) means I feel neither male nor female. To most of the people who know me in this shitty country town, I&#039;m a butch dyke. My amazing girlfriend got me into your music, and I honestly can&#039;t adequately thank her for it, and can&#039;t adequately thank you. Especially when I saw some of the music videos, the androgyny and sort of cross-genderedness of your performance style (my girlfriend agrees you often bring an amazing drag-queen energy) make me feel so seen and understood, in a way I never get to in my real life. I never thought I&#039;d see the physical embodiment of what my mind desperately wants my body to be like, though it&#039;ll never be. It was an unformed yearning before. I want to be like you when I grow up. I guess my question is, what would you say to as not-man, not-woman, pseudo-dyke fan and their unformed yearning to feel right in their body and now has an admittedly unattainable model for exactly what they want to be? : The Red Hand Files</title>

		<link href="//www.google-analytics.com" rel="dns-prefetch">
		<link href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/themes/red-hand-files/dist/img/icons/favicon.ico" rel="shortcut icon">
		<link href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/themes/red-hand-files/dist/img/icons/touch.png" rel="apple-touch-icon-precomposed">
		<link rel="alternate" type="application/rss+xml" title="The Red Hand Files" href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/feed/" />

		<meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge,chrome=1">
		<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
		<meta name="description" content="You can ask me anything. There will be no moderator. This will be between you and me. Let&#039;s see what happens. Much love, Nick">

<meta property="og:title" content="Nick Cave - The Red Hand Files - Issue #44 - I&#039;m non-binary, which (sorry if you already know this) means I feel neither male nor female. To most of the people who know me in this shitty country town, I&#039;m a butch dyke. My amazing girlfriend got me into your music, and I honestly can&#039;t adequately thank her for it, and can&#039;t adequately thank you. Especially when I saw some of the music videos, the androgyny and sort of cross-genderedness of your performance style (my girlfriend agrees you often bring an amazing drag-queen energy) make me feel so seen and understood, in a way I never get to in my real life. I never thought I&#039;d see the physical embodiment of what my mind desperately wants my body to be like, though it&#039;ll never be. It was an unformed yearning before. I want to be like you when I grow up. I guess my question is, what would you say to as not-man, not-woman, pseudo-dyke fan and their unformed yearning to feel right in their body and now has an admittedly unattainable model for exactly what they want to be?" />
<meta property="og:description" content="Dear Mary “Mickey”, I enjoyed your letter very much and I think I understand your notion of &quot;unformed yearning&quot; – a kind of longing that has yet to find..." />
<meta property="og:url" content="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/unformed-yearning-to-feel-right-in-their-body/" />
<meta property="og:site_name" content="The Red Hand Files" />
<meta property="article:section" content="Uncategorised" />
<meta property="article:published_time" content="2019-06-10T11:28:54+00:00" />

<meta name="twitter:card" content="summary_large_image" />
<meta name="twitter:description" content="Dear Mary “Mickey”, I enjoyed your letter very much and I think I understand your notion of &quot;unformed yearning&quot; – a kind of longing that has yet to find..." />
<meta name="twitter:title" content="Nick Cave - The Red Hand Files - Issue #44 - I&#039;m non-binary, which (sorry if you already know this) means I feel neither male nor female. To most of the people who know me in this shitty country town, I&#039;m a butch dyke. My amazing girlfriend got me into your music, and I honestly can&#039;t adequately thank her for it, and can&#039;t adequately thank you. Especially when I saw some of the music videos, the androgyny and sort of cross-genderedness of your performance style (my girlfriend agrees you often bring an amazing drag-queen energy) make me feel so seen and understood, in a way I never get to in my real life. I never thought I&#039;d see the physical embodiment of what my mind desperately wants my body to be like, though it&#039;ll never be. It was an unformed yearning before. I want to be like you when I grow up. I guess my question is, what would you say to as not-man, not-woman, pseudo-dyke fan and their unformed yearning to feel right in their body and now has an admittedly unattainable model for exactly what they want to be?" />
<meta name="twitter:image" content="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-1.png" />

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-637" class="post-637 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #44 / June 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I&#8217;m non-binary, which (sorry if you already know this) means I feel neither male nor female. To most of the people who know me in this shitty country town, I&#8217;m a butch dyke. My amazing girlfriend got me into your music, and I honestly can&#8217;t adequately thank her for it, and can&#8217;t adequately thank you. Especially when I saw some of the music videos, the androgyny and sort of cross-genderedness of your performance style (my girlfriend agrees you often bring an amazing drag-queen energy) make me feel so seen and understood, in a way I never get to in my real life. I never thought I&#8217;d see the physical embodiment of what my mind desperately wants my body to be like, though it&#8217;ll never be. It was an unformed yearning before. I want to be like you when I grow up. I guess my question is, what would you say to as not-man, not-woman, pseudo-dyke fan and their unformed yearning to feel right in their body and now has an admittedly unattainable model for exactly what they want to be?				</h1>
				<h3>MARY "MICKEY", SOMERVILLE, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/unformed-yearning-to-feel-right-in-their-body/" title="I&#8217;m non-binary, which (sorry if you already know this) means I feel neither male nor female. To most of the people who know me in this shitty country town, I&#8217;m a butch dyke. My amazing girlfriend got me into your music, and I honestly can&#8217;t adequately thank her for it, and can&#8217;t adequately thank you. Especially when I saw some of the music videos, the androgyny and sort of cross-genderedness of your performance style (my girlfriend agrees you often bring an amazing drag-queen energy) make me feel so seen and understood, in a way I never get to in my real life. I never thought I&#8217;d see the physical embodiment of what my mind desperately wants my body to be like, though it&#8217;ll never be. It was an unformed yearning before. I want to be like you when I grow up. I guess my question is, what would you say to as not-man, not-woman, pseudo-dyke fan and their unformed yearning to feel right in their body and now has an admittedly unattainable model for exactly what they want to be?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-1.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-1-250x299.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-1-768x918.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-1-700x837.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-1-120x143.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Mary “Mickey”,</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">I enjoyed your letter very much and I think I understand your notion of &#8220;unformed yearning&#8221; – a kind of longing that has yet to find its provenance. I have felt something similar for most of my life, although obviously in a very different way, and it has taken me a lifetime to work out <em>who I am,</em> or at least what my own personal value is in the world. It also seems that for most of my life I felt a strange gravitational pull toward an undisclosed traumatic event, that could only be described as a <em>dreadful</em> <em>yearning</em>, and I found it eventually in my son’s death – something that both destroyed me and ultimately defined me. It feels that the unformed yearning that followed me through my days, manifested in the death of my son. Does that make any sense to you? My son’s death brought me to the essence of my <em>formed</em> self. I mention this, because it could be that the unformed yearning that you speak of may turn out to be something that eventually obliterates you, but also brings you back to life, transforming you into something beyond yourself. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">As for the &#8220;androgyny and cross-genderedness&#8221; that you spoke of in your letter, well, this can be fairly simply explained. Although I am a man –</span> <span lang="EN-US">and have spent a fair amount of energy writing about that –</span> <span lang="EN-US">I have actually never felt any real allegiance to my masculinity; </span><span lang="EN-US">there was nothing</span><span lang="EN-US"> particularly invested in it, and even </span><span lang="EN-US">though I was more</span><span lang="EN-US"> or less heterosexual, I have always felt pliant in my navigations between maleness and femaleness, even – and perhaps especially – growing up within the overtly masculine Australian culture. It just wasn’t of any special focus to me – my interests were elsewhere – art, music, image, clothes, etc. – of which many of the students at the school I attended, back in the 70s, were deeply suspicious. My small group of friends and I were known at the school as the &#8220;art poofs&#8221; – we kind of liked it actually, and happily appropriated a certain queer and rarefied air, as it ring-fenced us off from the rest of the school, and in retrospect it toughened us up for the world to come. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">I am happy that </span><span lang="EN-US">your girlfriend acknowledged</span><span lang="EN-US"> my &#8220;drag-queen energy&#8221; – which means to me, </span><span lang="FR">defiant</span><span lang="EN-US">, courageous and savvy; to </span><span lang="IT">quote Camille Paglia, </span><span lang="EN-US">“The drag queens of old knew how to handle themselves on the street.” As for me being a role model, well, you could probably do better, but I am honoured to serve as a placeholder until someone more suitable comes along.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">As I said, I very much enjoyed your letter, and maybe I recognise some of what you are talking about. Obviously, I have no real authority to answer you, except to say, I hope you find some form of escape from your “shitty little town”, within yourself or outside of the town itself, and the unformed yearning of which you so beautifully speak, in time, manifests to your needs. Whatever, I am with you.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">With love, Nick</span></p>
<div></div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-627" class="post-627 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #43 / June 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I&#8217;m a songwriter. I&#8217;m seriously blocked. Do u have any spare lyrics I can have?				</h1>
				<h3>DAVID, BALTIMORE, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/do-u-have-any-spare-lyrics/" title="I&#8217;m a songwriter. I&#8217;m seriously blocked. Do u have any spare lyrics I can have?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1.png 785w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-250x410.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-768x1259.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-700x1148.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Picture1-120x197.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 785px) 100vw, 785px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							"IT'S BETHLEHEM THERE WITH ITS CRIBS AND MOPING BEASTS"							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear David,</p>
<p>Sure, here are some lyrics for you. They are a little on the dark side and pretty obscure, and perhaps a bit too heavy on the old Frederick Seidel (I had just been reading his brilliant collection of poems, <em>Peaches Goes It Alone</em>), and maybe there is an unearned and spurious use of Holocaust imagery (I apologise for that), and there is not a hell of lot of <em>structure</em> to it, plus the last verse may need a bit of work &#8211; but all that aside, there is some nice symbolism in there and if you chuck on a simple chorus, like <em>“Wo! I’m the Incinerator Man!”</em> and throw it on a lean circular chord formation, with lots of space and air, so that you can really creep the vocal and tell the story, then brother, you may be able to make something worthwhile out of it. I couldn’t.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>INCINERATOR MAN</strong></p>
<p>The moon holds itself in the dark with its glow</p>
<p>The monster moves through the garden</p>
<p>And waits beneath the window</p>
<p>I take the monster for a walk and plough on into town</p>
<p>My monster has a chimney sticking out of its back</p>
<p>I try to find a single story I can bring home</p>
<p>That won’t give you a flat-out heart attack</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>To be honest I’m not allowed back in the house</p>
<p>It’s Bethlehem there with its cribs and moping beasts</p>
<p>I’m either underneath the school desk braced</p>
<p>Or commuting between Auschwitz and outer space</p>
<p>I’m thinking of drinking something truly horrible</p>
<p>I’m a slow moving monster with a giant chimney</p>
<p>Sticking out of my back. Look out!</p>
<p>I’m coming now just like I came before!</p>
<p>I’m all over the place. I’m the same but more.</p>
<p>There never ever was any turning back</p>
<p>I’m coming now! I’m a full on heart attack.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title" style="text-align: center;">***</h1>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>This, of course, will not help with your &#8220;block&#8221;. My advice to you is to change your basic relationship to songwriting. You are not the ‘Great Creator’ of your songs, you are simply their servant, and the songs will come to you when you have adequately prepared yourself to receive them. They are not inside you, unable to get out; rather, they are outside of you, unable to get in. Songs, in my experience, are attracted to an open, playful and motivated mind. Throw my song away &#8211; it isn’t that good anyway &#8211; sit down, prepare yourself and write your own damn song. You are a songwriter. You have the entire world to save and very little time to do it. The song will find its way to you. If you don’t write it, someone else will. Is that what you want? If not, get to it.</p>
<p>Much love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-617" class="post-617 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #42 / May 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					As one ages, does the reduction of sexual desire affect their general desire for creation, the ability to create or the whole cognitive and sensual involvement of being? { } How is the correlation between the sexual and the creative going in old age? { }				</h1>
				<h3>PHILIP, KIEV, UKRAINE</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/desire-for-creation/" title="As one ages, does the reduction of sexual desire affect their general desire for creation, the ability to create or the whole cognitive and sensual involvement of being? { } How is the correlation between the sexual and the creative going in old age? { }">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-2.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-2-250x187.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-2-768x575.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-2-700x524.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-2-120x90.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">Not sure if there is a whole lot of sex in your religion or a whole lot of religion in your sex. Which is it?</h1>
<h3>KIARA, LONDON, UK</h3>
</div>
<div>
Dear Philip and Kiara,</p>
<p>Philip, please forgive me for the radical edit I made to your question. It went to a place I was not entirely sure I understood &#8211; the gist of which was, I think, that you are a young man who abstains from sex as it allows you to be more “enacted in your existence”, and provides your youthful mind with a heightened sensibility towards your own writing. If I have got that wrong, please excuse me, as I am old, doddery and enfeebled, and certain concepts are simply beyond me.</p>
<p>If I do have the basic premise of your question correct, then I am happy to impart that sexual desire for the aged, as far as I can tell, is not subject to any particularly dramatic downturn, and the reptilian male brain remains as deranged and priapic as ever. Actually, I have a terrible feeling that as we blunder into our bleak and bladdery winter years, it may just get a whole lot worse. Of course, it may just be that I am living a kind of last hurrah, and in a year or two a band of tearful mermaids will wave goodbye as I sail my little empty boat into the setting sun, with an oar that won’t row, row, row. I don’t know, but I’ll keep you informed.</p>
<p>With regards to sexual desire and songwriting, creativity and desire have always been inextricably linked for me. Many songs I write are simply erotic re-enactments, written with the sole intention of creating a remembered image of the one I love and, indeed, desire. Beyond that though, there is a certain sexualness to the very act of writing – the process itself is erotic. With songwriting we enter the imagination, that wildest of erogenous zones, where intense, obsessive yearning can be like a roaring in the heart and the loins both. The imagination becomes both the ‘safe space’ and the ‘un-safe space’, a strange blend of almost religious rigour and total abandonment, where everything rises to the starry heavens, even as it goes to hell.</p>
<p>So to answer your question, Philip, the good news is that this imaginative space still feels alive with potential  – old age has not diminished it  – indeed, it still rages and burns.</p>
<p>And, Kiara, to get to your question, I think this is why religion and the erotic are often indistinguishable from each other in my writing &#8211; they both inhabit the same yearning space, are both transcendent acts of wishfulness, and both require the imagination to make them function in any meaningful way. You are right to suggest that there may not be any difference between them at all.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>
