	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-610" class="post-610 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #41 / May 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Dear Nick, a couple of years ago I found myself in the midst of a heated debate about how each of us imagined God&#8217;s voice. At least a couple of people said that God would sound like you. Not me. There is a twistedness to my idea of God that makes me think of Tom Waits. In your mind, does God have a voice and if so, is it a familiar one? Or does God make him/her/itself heard in other ways?				</h1>
				<h3>RUTE, LISBON, PORTUGAL</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/dear-nick-a-couple-of-years-ago-i-found-myself-in-the-midst-of-a-heated-debate-about-how-each-of-us-imagined-gods-voice-at-least-a-couple-of-people-said-that-god-would-sound-like-you-not-me-ther/" title="Dear Nick, a couple of years ago I found myself in the midst of a heated debate about how each of us imagined God&#8217;s voice. At least a couple of people said that God would sound like you. Not me. There is a twistedness to my idea of God that makes me think of Tom Waits. In your mind, does God have a voice and if so, is it a familiar one? Or does God make him/her/itself heard in other ways?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-1.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-1-250x333.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-1-768x1024.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-1-700x933.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-1-120x160.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Rute,</p>
<p>I hope the voice of God would be something other than booming, authoritarian and male. Wouldn’t that be a pleasant surprise? How nice it would be if God’s voice didn’t sound like Nick Cave or Tom Waits – or Morgan Freeman for that matter. What a relief that would be.</p>
<p>In the recording studio, when you multi-layer vocals, sometimes the more voices you lay down and the more varied they are, the more pure the tone of the chorus becomes, as all individuality is erased and a pristine collected sound flows forth. As you add more voices, a strange inverse reaction happens, and the smaller, more distilled and weirdly intimate the cascade of voices seems to become. Perhaps that is what God sounds like. Perhaps, God would have the combined voice of all the untold billions of collected souls, an assembly of the departed speaking as one – without rancour, domination or division; a great, many-layered calling forth that rings from the heavens in the small, determined voice of a child, maybe; sexless, pure and uncomplicated – that says <em>&#8216;Look for me. I am here&#8217;</em>.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-603" class="post-603 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #40 / May 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					How can I reclaim songs of yours which I have, until recently, associated intensely with a really terrible relationship? I want them back, unharmed. Can you help me?				</h1>
				<h3>FREYJA, OXFORD, UK</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/how-can-i-reclaim-songs-of-yours/" title="How can I reclaim songs of yours which I have, until recently, associated intensely with a really terrible relationship? I want them back, unharmed. Can you help me?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/gettyimages-3093820.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/gettyimages-3093820.jpg 591w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/gettyimages-3093820-250x254.jpg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/gettyimages-3093820-120x122.jpg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 591px) 100vw, 591px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Freyja,</p>
<p>Yes, I can certainly help you with this problem but it will involve a bit of witchcraft I’m afraid, and you must follow my instructions, closely.</p>
<p><strong>1)</strong> Find a quiet place where you will not be disturbed and sit down and close your eyes.</p>
<p><strong>2)</strong> Bring to mind your &#8220;terrible relationship&#8221; in all its fucked-upness and, despite how painful this may be, spend a couple of minutes allowing this memory to permeate your mind.</p>
<p><strong>3) </strong>Imagine a shimmering golden cord that attaches you to the memory of this relationship. Really imagine it.</p>
<p><strong>4) </strong>In your mind, speak down the cord to the other person in the relationship, and despite what a douche-bag this person may have been, wish them well. Say &#8211;</p>
<p><strong>May you be happy on your journey wherever it may lead.</strong></p>
<p><strong>5)</strong> Now, imagine a giant pair of scissors cutting the golden cord in half and that &#8220;terrible relationship&#8221; floating off into space, never to bother you again.</p>
<p><strong>6)</strong> You are now released spiritually from this relationship. Breathe in this freedom and remember these words, from me to you &#8211;</p>
<p><strong>I am returning my songs to you, unharmed. May they remain with you forever.</strong></p>
<p><strong>7)</strong> Now, go to your record player or laptop or whatever and play a Nick Cave and The Bad Seeds song and say &#8211;</p>
<p><strong>I reclaim this song. This song is mine.</strong></p>
<p>You have now reasserted ownership of these songs. They belong with you. May they travel lightly with you through the years, for they are forever yours.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<article id="post-597" class="post-597 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #39 / May 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					What made you become a vegetarian?				</h1>
				<h3>SAMUEL, GLASGOW, SCOTLAND</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-made-you-become-a-vegetarian/" title="What made you become a vegetarian?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-copy.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-copy.png 765w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-copy-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-copy-250x250.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-copy-700x700.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-copy-120x120.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 765px) 100vw, 765px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">What do you think is the best way to cope with loneliness?</h1>
<h3>ELENA, REGGIO EMILIA, ITALY</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">How do you deal with loneliness?</h1>
<h3>LARS, ÖSTERBYBRUK, SWEDEN</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">Did you feel times of seemingly endless loneliness? What did you do against it?</h1>
<h3>FLORIAN, OPPONITZ, AUSTRIA</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">I&#8217;m writing right now to ask you for advice on how to deal with loneliness?</h1>
<h3>MEL, THESSALONIKI, GREECE</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">How long will I be alone?</h1>
<h3>LIII, KRAKOW, POLAND</h3>
</div>
<div>
Dear Samuel, Elena, Lars, Florian, Mel and Liii,</p>
<p>It was about eight months after our son had died. Susie and I had barely left the house. Susie decided it would be a good idea if we went somewhere for a few days to just get away from it all. Often times you think a change in location might put things right, but, of course, in the end, you take yourself with you and the thing you are running from ultimately finds you. So it was with us. We flew to Marrakesh and checked into a hotel next to the central square.</p>
<p>That evening, Susie and I walked through the main market place of Marrakesh. It is difficult to exaggerate the suffering of the animals that we saw there – ancient donkeys and workhorses being flogged, monkeys on chains, dozens of chickens stuffed into small cages, emaciated street dogs, skinned carcasses hanging on hooks. Death and suffering and cruelty were everywhere and I felt overwhelmed by a dark energy. How much of this energy existed within Marrakesh itself or how much I was carrying with me was difficult to say, but everywhere I looked I saw existential anguish. I was, in part, seeing this remarkable city through my own cultural prejudices, of course, and it was not lost on me that industrial farming in the West, in terms of net suffering, was on a vastly greater scale than what I was witnessing here on the streets of Marrakesh. However, it was the seeing, the close proximity to the cruelty, that made all the difference.</p>
<p>Susie had met a man on the plane, an English guy, who had set up a rescue centre for ancient workhorses in Marrakesh and Susie wanted to visit it, so the next day we caught a cab and drove there.</p>
<p>On the way to the rescue centre, we entered a busy roundabout and saw, in the middle of the road, a cat that had been run over. Its back was broken and it was arched horribly, spraying blood and literally screaming in pain. It was a deeply upsetting sight and one that instantly attached itself to the most vulnerable and traumatic images that lived in my mind. At that moment, something ruptured. I had had enough. Life was too much. It was literally impossible to bear. My son was gone. I would never see him again. In the back of the cab, in Marrakesh, I broke down.</p>
<p>The next morning, we decided to return to the UK. But, sitting on the plane, something had changed in me. I felt different. I felt that if I were to continue to live in this world I had to do what I could to reduce the existential suffering around me, or at the very least, not to add to it. It felt like a way forward. I felt that our collective unhappiness was brimming at its maximum capacity. There was no room for any more. I felt a sense of duty to do whatever I could, in my own way, to minimise sentient suffering. That call to action extended in many directions, and has stayed with me since, but one of the consequences of it was that I gave up eating meat. I have not eaten it since.</p>
<h1 class="post-title" style="text-align: center;">***</h1>
<p>As we go through our lives we take on the expanding burden of our own distress – as we are abandoned, broken apart, betrayed, isolated, lost and hurt. This is essentially part of what it is to live. This despair will overwhelm us and turn inward into bitterness, resentment and hatred &#8211; worse, we will take it out upon the ones closest to us if we do not actively live our lives in the service of others and use what power we have to reduce each other’s suffering. This, in my opinion, is essentially the key to living. This is the remedy to our own suffering; our own feelings of separateness and of disconnectedness. And it is the essential antidote for loneliness.</p>
<p>We must live our lives in such a way as to make better, even in the smallest way, the situation that we are currently experiencing. This is what it means to ‘take on the suffering of the world’ – that we each act in accordance with the limits of our own personal capacity for good. By doing this, the lives around us will become incrementally better and therefore, so will our own lives, and the life of the world itself.</p>
<p>In the Philip Larkin poem ‘The Mower’, Larkin runs over a hedgehog while he is mowing the lawn. As he removes the body of the hedgehog from the blades of the mower, he muses on the nature of death and ends the poem with these words.</p>
<p>We should be careful<br />
Of each other, we should be kind<br />
While there is still time</p>
<p>The urgency of these words came to me on that flight back from Marrakesh. The vision of the dying cat wrenched me from my own self-absorption and bitterness and isolation and loneliness and showed me that the world, in all its terrible wounded beauty, was in need of our urgent attention.</p>
<p>Much love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>

	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-589" class="post-589 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #38 / May 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I was first introduced to you by my stepfather in the early 80s. I was around 8 years old. I would later find much solace during a difficult time in The Boatman&#8217;s Call. Now I have 3 young boys and I find it to be the one thing that fills me with both fear and hope. I have an aching about the future world they are coming into. It confuses me &#8211; the darkness seems overwhelming.				</h1>
				<h3>NICK, MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/fills-me-with-both-fear-and-hope/" title="I was first introduced to you by my stepfather in the early 80s. I was around 8 years old. I would later find much solace during a difficult time in The Boatman&#8217;s Call. Now I have 3 young boys and I find it to be the one thing that fills me with both fear and hope. I have an aching about the future world they are coming into. It confuses me &#8211; the darkness seems overwhelming.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1.png 862w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-250x300.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-768x920.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-700x839.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Picture1-120x144.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 862px) 100vw, 862px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">I always liked the line in &#8216;Nature Boy&#8217;, about how beauty is gonna save the world. Is there anything that you think of as essentially beautiful, and that is sustained and forceful enough to save us.</h1>
<h3>DAVID, BERLIN, GERMANY</h3>
</div>
<p>Dear Nick and David,</p>
<p>I very much understand your distress. It is often difficult to look at the world through anything other than an apocalyptic prism and in doing so, simply despair. You wake up in the morning, look out at the day &#8211; blue sky, fluffy clouds – then go online and ten minutes later you have lost the will to live. Sadly, the existential terror we absorb through the constant onslaught of bad news can become the gift we pass onto our children – a terminal anxiety that rings down through the generations and infects everything we do.</p>
<p>In the first verse of the Bad Seeds song &#8216;Nature Boy&#8217;, I recall an incident that happened when I was fourteen years old, at my grandmother’s house in Melbourne. I saw a news report on TV that showed footage of the attempted assassination of American presidential candidate, George Wallace. I remember it occurring to me that this was real and not made-up, like in the movies, and being extremely disturbed by the images. I had simply never seen anything like it. This particular piece of footage has remained lodged in my memory ever since; Wallace’s speech, the walk through the crowd, the armed assassin, the gun going off, Wallace bleeding on the ground. My father, who was watching TV with me, saw my distress and his response was two-fold. He told me that, yes, these terrible things happen but he also set about showing me stuff he thought was beautiful – reading me things mostly, and encouraging me to follow an artistic direction in my life. It was a simple but effective action, a redressing of the balance of the bad and the good, and life changing in its way.</p>
<p>So, I have always seen it as a kind of parental duty to show my own children beautiful stuff, and in doing so reveal to them an alternate world. By beautiful, I mean interesting, inspiring, ambiguous, challenging and sometimes dangerous things that exist within the world of art. I feel that the online world provides us ready access to a vast and ever-deepening barrage of bad shit, where the cruel reality of the world is well covered. This continual onslaught of negativity can erode our souls and the souls of our children. My job is to show my children that there is a whole universe that exists beyond the grim issues of the day. This is not to divert them from certain truths, but rather to remind them that the parallel world of art and the imagination can literally save their lives, as it certainly saved mine.</p>
<p>The good news is that kids react well to this sort of attention. It is nice to imagine that as they go about their business, dealing with the world, they may have a copy of <em>Lolita</em>, similar to that given to me by my father, shoved in their jacket pocket. And as they respond to the world we have built for them, inventing new forms of madness beyond our comprehension (as we did with our own parents), it is comforting to feel they have some understanding of the aesthetic nature of the world and art’s ultimate capacity for salvation.</p>
<p>Love Nick x</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #37 / April 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					It&#8217;s Wednesday, 21.49 and it starts to rain. I light a cigarette and smoke on my balcony and listen to a vinyl. I contemplate the rain and realize that despite all the shit and cruelty in this fucked up world of ours, some moments are so precious that there must be a God or something greater than me, you, everyone. How do you feel about God? Really.				</h1>
				<h3>DEE, ROSARIO, ARGENTINA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/how-do-you-feel-about-god-really/" title="It&#8217;s Wednesday, 21.49 and it starts to rain. I light a cigarette and smoke on my balcony and listen to a vinyl. I contemplate the rain and realize that despite all the shit and cruelty in this fucked up world of ours, some moments are so precious that there must be a God or something greater than me, you, everyone. How do you feel about God? Really.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-2.png 849w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-2-250x317.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-2-768x972.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-2-700x886.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-2-120x152.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 849px) 100vw, 849px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">Do you smoke?</h1>
<h3>SUSAN, LOS ANGELES, USA</h3>
</div>
<p>Dear Dee and Susan,</p>
<p>A couple of Bad Seeds tours ago, when I was trying to stop smoking, I limited myself to one cigarette a day. After the show, as soon as I came off stage, Jacek, my assistant, would escort me to a solitary chair in the back alley of the venue, where I would sit and roll a cigarette. With immense anticipation, I would light that little white stick of joy and inhale. There, in the Zen-like supremacy of the moment, on the road and adrift in this world, the nicotine would enter my bloodstream and with a blissful rush of pure meaning God would declare Himself to me &#8211; just as He did to you, Dee, on your balcony, at 21.49, on that rainy evening in Rosario, Argentina. That five minute interlude, puffing on a cigarette, in the deranged chaos of our lives &#8211; you on your balcony and me in some alley in some foreign city &#8211; was, to paraphrase Leonard Cohen, the crack where the light came in. </p>
<p>So, how do I really feel about God? Well, the more absent He feels, and the more indifferent the cosmos appears to be, the more fervent and necessary my search for meaning becomes. For me though, the actual existence of God is beside the point &#8211; the argument between belief and disbelief does nothing to assuage the sadness and emptiness I sometimes feel in the face of existence. Prayer and meditation, however, do help me hugely, even if I am praying to a phantom or a memory or an invention. These acts of devotion, and investment in the unknowable, define my life. Whether God is my witness or whether He is not is not of my concern and has no real impact on the spiritual nature of my life. For me, the search itself is where the action is.</p>
<p>As the Bad Seeds tour progressed I predictably began to seek my communion with God before the show as well, then in the middle of the day, until eventually I was jamming a cigarette in my mouth the moment I woke up, till the moment I went to sleep and I was back to a pack and a half a day &#8211; equally predictably God vanished and all I was left with was the age-old, fiendish cigarette habit, as I coughed and wheezed my way across Europe. After the tour I simply gave up and haven’t had a cigarette since. </p>
<p>Now, I sometimes think I have discovered God in other situations. Sometimes I feel a certain divine presence and sometimes I don’t &#8211; but I still long for meaning and I still search. A fool’s mission maybe, but wherever this journey may lead, please Dee, next time you sit on the balcony with the rain coming down, put on a Bad Seeds record &#8211; something loud or something soft, it doesn’t matter &#8211; and light up a fag for me. I am with you in spirit. </p>
<p>With love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-574" class="post-574 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #36 / April 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					How would you describe a stereotypical Nick Cave fan? We all have a perception of you, how do you perceive us?				</h1>
				<h3>FLORENCIA, STAVANGER, NORWAY</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/how-do-you-perceive-us/" title="How would you describe a stereotypical Nick Cave fan? We all have a perception of you, how do you perceive us?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/37984967_741655332676119_347789164386713600_n.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/37984967_741655332676119_347789164386713600_n.jpg 1080w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/37984967_741655332676119_347789164386713600_n-250x313.jpg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/37984967_741655332676119_347789164386713600_n-768x960.jpg 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/37984967_741655332676119_347789164386713600_n-700x875.jpg 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/37984967_741655332676119_347789164386713600_n-120x150.jpg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 1080px) 100vw, 1080px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							PHOTO BY NIKOLAY NERSESOV							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">I am kinda involved with my third Nick Cave fan. They are all just, er, impossible to resist. Also my friends who are from the same universe say, &#8220;Nick Cave fans are just too kind and special&#8221;. What do you think about your fans?</h1>
<h3>ME, XX, XX</h3>
</div>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Florencia and You,</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">When I stand on stage I feel a tremendous need emanating from the audience. I recognise this need because it exists within myself. I think we all see the opportunity for rapture and recognise its importance. Ultimately, this is a relationship of mutual dependence, that surpasses simple entertainment and moves into the domain of the sacred. I say this because the performative act, for me, is a process of peeling away one</span>’<span lang="EN-US">s ego and self-importance, of letting go and laying oneself open to the audience, in a mutual acknowledgement of each other</span>’<span lang="EN-US">s humanity. In doing so, a simple but profound connection is made. This connection is the responsibility of both the audience and the performer </span>– <span lang="EN-US">we take each other</span>’<span lang="EN-US">s hands and move beyond ourselves to a higher place of spiritual reciprocity in order to restore each other. If we can do this together, we have achieved something sublime. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">I feel that over time my audience and I have come to fully understand this relationship. I think we have brought each other to this heightened place, and we all feel a mutual and urgent call to traverse our individual suffering and just fucking <em>lose</em> ourselves.  </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Perhaps there are some performers who see the performative process as a one-way street, where the artist is dominant and simply delivers, whilst the passive audience receives. Personally, I do not see it in this way, at all. As the writer, Greil Marcus says, the performer needs </span>“<span lang="EN-US">an aggressive, critical audience, with a conscious sense of itself as an audience, </span>…<span lang="EN-US"> one whose complexity and diverse needs can push an artist beyond comfortable limits.</span>” <span lang="EN-US">This is how I experience it. I feel, on stage, that the audience is<em> making</em> me, just as I am <em>making</em> them, in an act of shared, primordial creation. </span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">As a consequence of this, Florencia, our fans have grown to be uniquely devotional, that is to say, devotional to the transcendent experience itself, just as the Bad Seeds and I are more devotional to the audience and their needs. We are all just completely <em>needed </em></span>and<em><span lang="EN-US"> in need.</span></em></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">And, You, from Xx, whoever you are and wherever you may be, be careful with that third Nick Cave fan you</span>’re <em>kinda</em><span lang="EN-US"> involved with. Be nice. Treasure her or him. They are indeed kind and special people, full of a formidable beauty and may just end up being the very best part of you.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Love to you all, Nick</span></p>
<div></div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		conditionizr.config({
			assets: 'https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/themes/red-hand-files/dist',
			tests: {}
		});
		</script>

	</head>
	<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-561 single-format-standard thoughts-on-modern-rock-music">

<!-- End Google Tag Manager (noscript) -->
		<!-- wrapper -->
		<div class="wrapper">

			<!-- header -->
			<header class="header clear" role="banner">

					<!-- logo -->
					<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com"  class="logo">
						<!-- svg logo - toddmotto.com/mastering-svg-use-for-a-retina-web-fallbacks-with-png-script -->
						<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/themes/red-hand-files/dist/img/logo.svg" alt="Logo" class="logo__img">

			</header>

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-561" class="post-561 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #35 / April 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					What are your thoughts on the current state of modern rock music?				</h1>
				<h3>DYLAN, BRISBANE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/thoughts-on-modern-rock-music/" title="What are your thoughts on the current state of modern rock music?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-1.png 860w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-1-250x348.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-1-768x1069.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-1-700x974.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-1-120x167.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 860px) 100vw, 860px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">How do you feel about the current trend of connecting the shortcomings of an artist&#8217;s personal conduct and the art they create and using that criteria to determine if said works are corrupted and therefore to be relegated to the dustbins or not?<br />
What does it mean for the future of art if we expect our artists, those that help us collectively explore and understand the human experience, to be morally perfect and beyond reproach?</h1>
<h3>JASON, BROOKLYN, USA</h3>
</div>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Dylan and Jason,</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Rock music has lurched and shuddered its way through its varied and tumultuous history and somehow managed to survive. It is within the very nature of rock ‘n’ roll to mutate and to transform &#8211; to die so it can live again. </span><span lang="EN-US">This churning is what keeps the whole thing moving forward. As musicians we are always in danger of becoming obsolete and superseded by the next generation’s efforts, or by the world itself and its big ideas. Not so long ago the big idea in the world was freedom of expression. It looks like the new big idea is moralism. Will rock music survive this one? We shall see. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">My feeling is that modern rock music, as we know it, has anyway </span><span lang="EN-US">been </span><span lang="EN-US">ailing for</span><span lang="EN-US"> some time now. It has become afflicted with a kind of tiredness and confusion and faint-heartedness,</span> <span lang="EN-US">and no longer has the stamina to fight the great battles that rock music has always </span><span lang="EN-US">fought. </span><span lang="EN-US">It seems to me there is little new or authentic, </span><span lang="EN-US">as it becomes safer, more nostalgic, more cautious and more corporate.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">As far as rock music goes, I think that the new moral zealotry that is descending upon our culture could actually be a good thing. </span><span lang="EN-US">Maybe</span><span lang="EN-US">,</span><span lang="EN-US"> it</span><span lang="EN-US"> is exactly what rock ‘n’ roll needs at this moment in time. Contemporary rock music no </span><span lang="EN-US">longer </span><span lang="EN-US">seems to have</span><span lang="EN-US"> the fortitude to contend with these enemies of the imagination, these enemies of art &#8211; and in this present form perhaps rock music isn’t worth saving. The permafrost of puritanism could be the antidote for the weariness and nostalgia that grips it. Perhaps a painful reckoning is needed – a great crushing of creativity that descends and lays its self-righteous ice across art –</span> <span lang="EN-US">so that in time, a wild, dangerous and radical form of music can tear its way through the ice, teeth bared, and rock ‘n’ roll can get back to the business of transgression. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Transgression is fundamental to the artistic imagination, because the imagination deals with the forbidden. Go to your record collection and mind-erase those who have led questionable lives and see how much of it remains. It is the artist who steps beyond the accepted social </span><span lang="EN-US">boundaries </span><span lang="EN-US">who will bring back</span><span lang="EN-US"> ideas that shed new light on what it means to be alive. This is, in fact, the artist’s </span><span lang="EN-US">duty </span><span lang="EN-US">&#8211; and sometimes this</span><span lang="EN-US"> journey is accompanied by a certain dissolute behaviour, especially in rock ‘n’ roll. In fact, the nature of rock ‘n’ roll <em>is</em> dissolute. Sometimes an individual’s behaviour is purely malevolent, and </span><span lang="EN-US">this </span><span lang="EN-US">surely needs</span><span lang="EN-US"> to be exposed for what </span><span lang="EN-US">it is &#8211; and we must make a personal choice as to whether or not we engage with their work.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">However, in the world of ideas the sanctimonious have little or</span> <span lang="EN-US">no place. Art must be wrestled from the hands of the pious, in whatever form they may come</span><span lang="EN-US"> &#8211; </span><span lang="EN-US">and they are </span><em><span lang="EN-US">always </span></em><span lang="EN-US">coming, knives out, in</span><span lang="EN-US">tent </span><span lang="EN-US">on murdering creativity.</span> A<span lang="EN-US">t </span><span lang="EN-US">this depressing time in rock &#8216;n&#8217; roll though,</span> <span lang="EN-US">perhaps they can serve a purpose, perhaps rock music needs to die for a while, so that something powerful and subversive and truly monumental can rise up out of it.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">Love, Nick</span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

					<!-- logo -->
					<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com"  class="logo">
						<!-- svg logo - toddmotto.com/mastering-svg-use-for-a-retina-web-fallbacks-with-png-script -->

					<nav class="nav" role="navigation">
						<a href="#" class="nav__burger"></a>
						<ul><li id="menu-item-11" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-11"><a href="http://theredhandfiles.com">The Files</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-12" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-12"><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/ask-a-question/">Ask a Question</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-13" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-13"><a href="#subscribe">Subscribe</a></li>

					<!-- /nav -->

			</header>
			<!-- /header -->

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-556" class="post-556 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #34 / April 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					What does Elvis mean to you?				</h1>
				<h3>GEORGIA, GLASGOW, UK</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-does-elvis-mean-to-you/" title="What does Elvis mean to you?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1.png 860w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-250x390.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-768x1198.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-700x1092.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture1-120x187.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 860px) 100vw, 860px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Georgia,</p>
<p>In early 2000, I saw Johnny Cash walk into a studio in LA, old and ill and temporarily blind (he had toward the end of his life a condition that affected his sight), sit down and sing a song, then transform into a higher being. I have seen Nina Simone climb a flight of stairs to the stage at the Royal Festival Hall in London, barely able to walk, sit down at the piano and be transformed. I have seen Shane MacGowan stand on stage at a concert in France after taking ten LSD trips, and not knowing where he was, shuffle to the microphone, begin to sing so very beautifully, and be transformed. These transformative moments encapsulate the religious nature of performance as they imitate the crucifixion and resurrection of Jesus Christ Himself. This narrative of suffering and rebirth is played out again and again within our own lives, but I believe it is captured most beautifully, within the musical performance itself. Through the boundless power of music, a performer transcends his or her own wretchedness by performing a kind of public exorcism and by doing so, transforms into a deity.</p>
<p>In 1981, in London, I saw the movie <em>This Is Elvis</em>. I had always been an Elvis fan, with a special love for the songs he made in the seventies – <em>Suspicious Minds</em>, <em>In the Ghetto</em>, <em>Kentucky Rain</em>, <em>Always on My Mind</em> – and had a particular obsession with the gospel album, <em>How Great Thou Art</em> that he recorded in the early sixties. The last ten minutes of <em>This Is Elvis</em> changed my ideas on performance forever.</p>
<p>In the final minutes of the film, we see Elvis, on stage in Las Vegas, sing the famous so-called ‘Laughing Version’ of <em>Are You Lonesome Tonight?</em> The camera begins with a long shot and does a slow zoom in on Elvis’s face. Elvis is stoned and overweight and by the time he performs the disastrous central monologue, we can see the pure anguish of his performance, the drugged and mortified eyes, the terrible aloneness, the horror of the moment &#8211; his vast soul crucified on the cross of his own body as he blunders through the words. It is one of the most traumatic pieces of footage I have ever seen. This is followed by the medley, <em>An American Trilogy</em>. Elvis dies and as the world media reports his death, we hear him sing <em>Dixie</em> over shots of his funeral procession. We see the motorcade, the weeping crowds, the coffin, and the flowers, as the film returns to the Vegas concert and Elvis sings the eternally beautiful <em>All My Trials</em>. To me it is immeasurably moving, Elvis’s head bowed, his extraordinary voice steeped in sorrow &#8211; then the band rises, he lifts his head and sings <em>The Battle Hymn of the Republic</em> and Elvis is resurrected, triumphant. It is pure religion and as powerful as anything I have ever seen. The final shot of him, in slow motion, arms outstretched, the angel wings of his silver cape flung wide, shows his exultant ascent into heaven.</p>
<p>As I walked from the cinema, I was left with these three images &#8211; Elvis’s mortified, tear-streaked face; his head hung in sorrowful acceptance; and his caped arms outstretched in triumph. These are the stages of Christ’s passage upon the cross, the anguish, the sufferance and the resurrection, a journey which welcomes us all, in time.</p>
<p>Elvis continued performing until the end. In my eyes, he was some kind of angel; both terribly and awfully human yet divine in his meteoric reach that touched so many hearts. He was fallible and God-like at the same time. He crucified himself on stage in Vegas, at the supper show and the late show, hundreds and hundreds of times. His latter years on Earth were as sad and lonely as any can be, but his Vegas performances were epic triumphs of human transcendence, where the angels looked down on one who had fallen so far, then looked up to where he ascended.</p>
<p>Much love, Nick</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-558" src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture2-250x218.png" alt="" width="250" height="218" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture2-250x218.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture2-768x668.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture2-700x609.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture2-120x104.png 120w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Picture2.png 864w" sizes="(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px" /></p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-544" class="post-544 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #33 / March 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Did you ever want to simply give up and quit, because of your inner voice?				</h1>
				<h3>URSULA, WARSAW, POLAND</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/did-you-ever-want-to-give-up/" title="Did you ever want to simply give up and quit, because of your inner voice?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2-2.png 445w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2-2-250x254.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2-2-120x122.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 445px) 100vw, 445px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">Have you ever suffered a crisis of confidence?</h1>
<h3>JOE, EDMONDS, USA</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">I hate myself sometimes and wonder why I even bother.</h1>
<h3>ROD, NEW ORLEANS, USA</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">Do you have a harsh inner critic?</h1>
<h3>SOPHIA, LIVERPOOL, UK</h3>
</div>
<div>
Dear Ursula, Joe, Rod and Sophia and many more,</p>
<p>I don’t know how many times I have been asked this question, or a version of it, in <em>The Red Hand Files</em>. Let me say this &#8211; the ‘harsh inner critic’ that you speak of is in no way unique to you. The truth is that virtually anybody who is trying to do anything worthwhile at all, especially creatively, has seated in his or her brain, a horrible homunculus that blows a dreadful little trumpet, and only knows one song – a song that goes, “You are not good enough. Why bother?” This evil little gnome is full of bad jazz, and is, in the words of author Sam Harris, “an asshole.” The enemy of aspiration, this atrocious inner voice demands you turn away from whatever your higher calling may be and become a second-rate, cut-price version of yourself. As your very own personal detractor it is deeply persuasive in its dark business. Many of us listen, many of us accept its message, and many of us throw up our hands and give in. The problem is, of course, that this inner voice, this monstrous homunculus, is you.</p>
<p>The creative act is an act of war – but as much as this inner critic is your adversary, it is also fundamental to the creative process. It is what anyone worth their salt is doing battle with <em>all the time </em>– we are in a perpetual dogfight with the lesser version of ourselves. To lose the battle is to become the embodiment of the homunculus itself. Defeated, we do nothing but sit in perpetual judgment of the world, idly watching, as it goes down in flames. As vicious as this fight with our own selves may be, it is this very conflict that puts the blood in the art, the tears too, and carves the battle scars deep into the work itself.</p>
<p>The world, for all its failings, is an extraordinary experiment in rampant human imagination. At its best, it exists because there were people who had the courage to follow through on an idea – who resisted the inner voice that said, “You are worthless. Why bother?”</p>
<p>I’ve said it before. Beautiful ideas abound. These ideas swim around us, ideas that can be of immense utility to world. Some ideas have our singular names inscribed upon them and it is our responsibility to reach beyond our lesser selves to the brightest version of what we can be and breathe life into these ideas. This act of reaching is almost always accompanied by the wretched homunculus and its dreary anthem of personal incompetence, but it is our sacred duty, to turn around and kick this little fucker in the balls. The fight with the dark force inside us is the forge in which true art is formed.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
<p>P.S.  A homunculus is a very small human or humanoid creature.</p></div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-528" class="post-528 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #32 / March 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					You&#8217;ve written at length in song, poetry &#038; prose about love. What is love? Why do love songs so frequently move us? Perhaps a list of your top 10 love songs?				</h1>
				<h3>MACK, BAIRNSDALE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-is-love/" title="You&#8217;ve written at length in song, poetry &#038; prose about love. What is love? Why do love songs so frequently move us? Perhaps a list of your top 10 love songs?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-copy-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-copy-2.png 673w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-copy-2-250x268.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-copy-2-120x129.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 673px) 100vw, 673px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							KAREN DALTON							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">How important is the song in your life, as a listener?</h1>
<h3>LUIZA, VIÇOSA, BRAZIL</h3>
</div>
<p>Dear Mack and Luiza,</p>
<p>It’s the early hours of the morning, here in Los Angeles, and I can’t sleep. I’ve been in the studio all night, working on new songs. The melodies and words are running around in my head, so excuse this letter if it’s kind of scrambled. You asked about love, Mack, and maybe that’s what love is right there &#8211; maybe <em>songs </em>are the parlance of love. Maybe that’s what we have conceived them for – to give a voice to this strange, inscrutable feeling that tears away at us, all our lives. I don’t know. Maybe some songs are the embodiment of love itself and that’s why they move us so deeply. They are simple, plainspoken, incendiary devices that bomb the heart to pieces – something other art forms can’t do with the same sudden and frightening precision.</p>
<p>So, here is a list of ten of my most treasured love songs – old, sad songs mostly, and sentimental too, that have travelled with me through the years, holding sway over my world and never failing to rescue me. They are just small unassuming love bombs, but dear Luiza, as important as anything can ever be.</p>
<p>Much love, Nick<br />
&nbsp;<br />
<strong>Ten Love Songs</strong></p>
<p>To Love Somebody &#8211; Bee Gees</p>
<p>My Father &#8211; Nina Simone</p>
<p>I Threw It All Away &#8211; Bob Dylan</p>
<p>Comfort You &#8211; Van Morrison</p>
<p>Angel of the Morning &#8211; Merrilee Rush &amp; The Turnabouts</p>
<p>Nights In White Satin &#8211; The Moody Blues</p>
<p>Where’s the Playground Susie? &#8211; Glen Campbell</p>
<p>Something On Your Mind &#8211; Karen Dalton</p>
<p>Always on My Mind &#8211; Elvis Presley</p>
<p>Superstar &#8211; Carpenters<br />
&nbsp;</p>
<div></div>
<div><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-530" src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2-1-250x249.png" alt="" width="250" height="249" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2-1-250x249.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2-1-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2-1-700x697.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2-1-120x120.png 120w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2-1.png 766w" sizes="(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px" /></div>
<p style="text-align: center;">BOB DYLAN</p>

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-520" class="post-520 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #31 / March 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					What was the thought process behind choosing the cover of Push the Sky Away?				</h1>
				<h3>JO, PERTH, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/choosing-the-cover-of-push-the-sky-away/" title="What was the thought process behind choosing the cover of Push the Sky Away?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-1.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-1-250x223.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-1-768x684.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-1-700x624.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-1-120x107.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							EXPULSION FROM PARADISE							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Jo,</p>
<p>Our dear friend Dominique Issermann was photographing Susie, at our home in Brighton, for a fashion magazine. I was the designated assistant for the day and when I poked my head in the room to see if anyone wanted a cup of tea, Dominique asked me to go to the bedroom window and open the shutters to let the sunlight in. Susie was changing for the next shot and was naked under her robe and in a purely improvised act of subversion dropped the robe as I opened the shutters. Dominique, the most fast-thinking and attentive photographer I have ever met, snapped the picture &#8211; one photograph and that was it. We were not attempting to shoot an album cover, rather this was a moment snatched from time, which we promptly forgot about.</p>
<p>The next day, as Susie and I sat with Dominique looking through the shots, we found this remarkable photograph. It instantly spoke to us, reminding me of Masaccio’s fresco, Expulsion from the Garden of Eden, a much-loved Old Testament story of mine, and I thought it would make a great cover for <em>Push the Sky Away</em>, as it felt in keeping with many of the record’s concerns. I showed it to the band and they seemed happy and everyone in my office loved it. So that was that, the Dominique Issermann picture became the cover.</p>
<p>How lovely the cover is and how beautiful my wife looks &#8211; the animal stance, up on her toes, the defensive positioning of her arms, and her face hidden in her hair. It is a brave and unsettling picture pulsing with ambiguity, mythology and life, and is probably Susie’s most treasured shot of herself and a favourite of Dominique’s as well.</p>
<p>When the record came out there was a flurry of disapproval from a handful of people that questioned why Susie was naked and I wasn’t, that it was exploitative and sexist, inferring that I had somehow forced Susie into taking the picture. I was flattered that there were people who thought I had Svengali-like powers over my wife, and could cast spells on her and do with her as I pleased, but sadly this is not the case. I would say, in fact, that the situation is completely the reverse.</p>
<p>I understand why people may have found the cover disturbing, but in the end, beauty knows best &#8211; it leads us beyond our narrow notions of what is appropriate into the realms of the enigmatic and discomforting. Here, beauty creates a dissonance in the mind that inflames the imagination. This fire of the mind is the place where the angels and devils play happily together. I hope this is also the place where many of my songs reside.</p>
<p>Dominique’s photo is an uncanny and haunting work, born of a happy accident and full of contradictions, that will be forever attached to <em>Push the Sky Away</em> and of which Susie and I are immensely proud.</p>
<p>Much love, Nick</p>
<p><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-521" src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2-250x643.png" alt="" width="117" height="300" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2-250x643.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2-120x309.png 120w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture2.png 564w" sizes="(max-width: 117px) 100vw, 117px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;">EXPULSION FROM THE GARDEN OF EDEN BY MASACCIO</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>
<div id="recent-posts-4" class="widget_recent_entries"><h3>Recent Posts</h3>      <ul>
                
        <li>
          <h4><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/cope-with-negative-energy/">Issue #122</a><br>-</h4>
          <h5><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/cope-with-negative-energy/" title="In this time of illness, cynicism and cruelty, do you receive many mean or vile messages? How do you cope with that kind of negative energy?">‘In this time of illness, cynicism and cruelty, do you receive many mean or vile messages? How do you cope with that kind of negative energy?’</a></h5>
        </li>
                
        <li>
          <h4><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/pet-theory-your-creativity-flourish/">Issue #121</a><br>-</h4>
          <h5><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/pet-theory-your-creativity-flourish/" title="In an interview from 1997 in Los Angeles, you introduced us to your &#8220;pet theory&#8221;: your creativity could only flourish in a state of loss and longing, and that it needed catastrophes in your life. <br> Finally, and this is what resonated with me the most, you stated that you could not get much substance out of living a life which was content. Do you still believe that? <br> A sincere and devoted admirer of yours who sort of struggles in a content life.">‘In an interview from 1997 in Los Angeles, you introduced us to your &#8220;pet theory&#8221;: your creativity could only flourish in a state of loss and longing, and that it needed ...’</a></h5>
        </li>
                
        <li>
          <h4><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-do-you-think-about-na/">Issue #120</a><br>-</h4>
          <h5><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-do-you-think-about-na/" title="What do you think about NA? As a recovering heroin addict, I am having difficulty getting into the Narcotics Anonymous scene. I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA? As a recovering heroin addict, I am having difficulty getting into the Narcotics Anonymous scene. I see how it can help but I feel ...’</a></h5>

              </ul>

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-510" class="post-510 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #30 / March 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I have just finished watching One More Time With Feeling. How is Susie doing? I am just feeling a great desire to give Susie a big hug from afar, and hope she knows that she has many things to look forward to, both in the lives of the Cave family and in her own career.				</h1>
				<h3>VIVIAN, DENMARK, WESTERN AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/how-is-susie-doing/" title="I have just finished watching One More Time With Feeling. How is Susie doing? I am just feeling a great desire to give Susie a big hug from afar, and hope she knows that she has many things to look forward to, both in the lives of the Cave family and in her own career.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-copy.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-copy.png 793w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-copy-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-copy-250x249.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-copy-768x764.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-copy-700x696.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-copy-120x119.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 793px) 100vw, 793px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							DAWN TEACHES SUSIE TO KNIT. MELBOURNE.							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Vivian,</p>
<p>Susie is sitting across the kitchen table from me, humming to herself and knitting what looks like a scarf. I have just read her your very sweet message. She is confused to find that Denmark has now become part of Australia, but Google tells us that Denmark is a small coastal town in Western Australia with a population of 2,558 people. Susie says she wants to go there on holiday and hug you back.</p>
<p>In <em>One More Time With Feeling</em> we see an interview with a woman who is new in her grief. I don’t think I could ever watch that piece of footage of Susie again. It was the very hardest part &#8211; to see, day by day, the uncontainable and merciless dimensions of grief. It is the very reason I am so careful when I reply on <em>The Red Hand Files</em> to people who have lost someone, because I have seen the tenuous hold that a grieving mother has on life itself. I have seen the paralysis and the terrible retreat from the world. I have seen life lived in a darkened room, essentially a tomb, crumpled around a memory, as if to be dead herself somehow brought her closer to the spirit of her departed child. I learned the appalling meaning of the words ‘inconsolable’ and ‘helpless’ &#8211; and I never knew a person could cry for so long.</p>
<p>But I have also seen a woman ultimately step from that room, changed – defiant and scoured clean by grief; a woman with a mutinous and ferocious grace, now more open, daring and creative than ever; a woman who has simply defied the cosmic odds and bloomed.</p>
<p>And I think that is what Susie and I want to say to those deep in grief, to the inconsolable. We want to say that, in spite of ourselves, life moves on. That in time we learn to absorb our loss, as a form of armouring, and that it can become our strength. That the very thing we thought would destroy us, now becomes a fierce source of creative power, as if our departed are breathing an essential energy through us, drawn from a wellspring deep within the trauma itself. We want to say that allowing this process of renewal to occur is the greatest gift we can give to those who have left us. We become the living vessels that carry their spirits, out of that dark and shuttered place, and release them into the heavens.</p>
<p>Finally, we want to say that even though there are still the deep and sudden weeps &#8211; the flash floods &#8211; they don’t assert the same hold on us anymore, for we know they pass, as do all things.</p>
<p>So, Vivian, to answer your question, &#8220;how is Susie doing?&#8221; Susie is doing okay. I watch her now, across from me, humming to herself and knitting a scarf and I am awed.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<article id="post-496" class="post-496 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #29 / March 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					What is your earliest memory and has it in any way framed or spoken to any past or ongoing thematic concerns?				</h1>
				<h3>CATHERINE, SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-is-your-earliest-memory/" title="What is your earliest memory and has it in any way framed or spoken to any past or ongoing thematic concerns?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1.png 767w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-250x249.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-700x696.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Picture1-120x119.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 767px) 100vw, 767px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							OEDIPUS							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">In what way did the profession of your father influence you as an artist and as a person?</h1>
<h3>MICHAEL, SEVENOAKS, ENGLAND</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title">Do you believe in an afterlife? If not, what do you think happens when we die?</h1>
<h3>THEO, BRIGHTON, ENGLAND</h3>
</div>
<p>Dear Catherine, Michael and Theo,</p>
<p>I am not sure what my ‘earliest’ memory was – rather I have a muddle of images from my childhood, that make no real sense to me at all. I remember seeing a decapitated chicken running around a chopping block; I remember my mother naming the flowers in our garden; I remember climbing up a wire fence, falling off and splitting open my head; I remember my father painting a theatre prop in the backyard; I remember the devastating feeling of letting go of my mother’s hand on the first day of kindergarten – these memories are part of a disjointed narrative that lives inside my head and that approximates my childhood. But mostly I just remember the feeling of my childhood – that it was free, uncomplicated and happy and that my parents loved me. I have one memory however that sits firmly in my mind because it was the same episode that played out over many nights.</p>
<p>My father was involved in amateur theatre and this meant that some nights he was away from home. At some point he explained to me that he was performing in the play Oedipus. To my child’s mind that involved him dressing up in a cat outfit – as in Oedi-puss. Many nights I would lie awake in bed, waiting for my father to come home, and in the silent darkness, if I concentrated hard enough, I could hear my blood beating in my ears. I would imagine this sound was my father’s footsteps coming down the garden path. I imagined him in his cat suit arriving home and the rhythm of his steps comforted me and I would fall asleep.</p>
<p>Does this memory speak to any thematic concerns? I don’t know. Probably. But I will say this. My father instilled in me the idea of the pre-eminence of creativity – that to create was an act of largesse that had the capacity to redeem the world, and that the pursuit of this path was a serious matter. My father despised cynicism. He felt that whatever a person decided to do in life, they needed to apply themselves fully to the task, and not fuck around. Admittedly, I took a fairly destructive and treacherous route on the way to understanding what he meant. But I know now. He meant that we are at war with the mundane and the uninspired, and that apathy and complacency are moral failings and that it is our urgent duty to be of service to the world. He meant that what we do in life has consequences, and that each of us are effectual and of great value. He believed in the sovereignty of the individual and felt that although we do not always have control over the things that happen to us, it is entirely our choice how we live our life in relation to them.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;">* * * *</p>
<p>Sometimes, Theo, I think, that if there is an after-life, it will have something to do with the worlds we have dreamed or imagined, especially as children. I think these luminous imaginings, these memories, are locked deep into our sub-conscious and that the infinite and enigmatic nature of consciousness and the possibility of an after-life are inextricably linked. At times, I think that when I die and my spirit leaves my body, searching for its guide, it will be met by a glimmering man in a cat suit walking down the garden path toward me.</p>
<p>Love Nick</p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

			};
		</script>
	</body>

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-490" class="post-490 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #28 / February 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					How do you deal with evil? The casual, everyday evil, like throwing tobacco in the eyes of a beautiful animal in a zoo?				</h1>
				<h3>KATJA, COPENHAGEN, DENMARK</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/how-do-you-deal-with-evil/" title="How do you deal with evil? The casual, everyday evil, like throwing tobacco in the eyes of a beautiful animal in a zoo?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-2.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-2.png 862w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-2-250x291.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-2-768x895.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-2-700x815.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-2-120x140.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 862px) 100vw, 862px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p class="BodyA" dir="ltr"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Katja,</span></p>
<p class="BodyA" dir="ltr"><span lang="EN-US">These days the word ‘</span><span lang="ES-TRAD">evil</span><span lang="EN-US">’ is seen by many as anachronistic and outmoded. What much contemporary thought offers us is a representation of humanity as little more than a mass of twitching nerves, with no inherent purpose other than to merely exist, that there is no ultimate good or bad, and concepts such as evil are redundant social constructs. I disagree, of course, and I must answer your question through my own view of the world &#8211; that we are spiritual and transcendent beings, that our lives have meaning, and that our individual actions have vast implications on the well-being of the universe. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA" dir="ltr"><span lang="EN-US">Throwing tobacco in the eyes of an animal in a zoo is an act of deliberate malevolence, and in that respect, evil. However, I think we must all look inside ourselves and acknowledge that we each have a capacity for malevolence. It requires little self-examination to envisage a situation where ‘good’ people could &#8211; under certain circumstances &#8211; perform acts that are wicked. This acknowledgement of our own capacity for evil, difficult as it may be, can ultimately become our redemption. If we don’t acknowledge our potential for malevolence, we disconnect ourselves from the unlimited ability for good that is contained within us. It is important to understand that as individual human beings we hold, in our own hands, the ability to both destroy and save the world. </span></p>
<p class="BodyA"><span lang="EN-US">The transcendent spirit for good can be accessed with profound effect through the imagination &#8211; the creative force can act as a counter-agent to evil. We cannot eradicate evil, yet it need not paralyse us &#8211; rather we </span><span lang="EN-US">should take</span><span lang="EN-US"> what steps we can, however small, toward the betterment of the world, and our place in it.</span> <span lang="EN-US">This is the essence of creativity.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA" dir="ltr"><span lang="EN-US">Sometimes, the world appears to lean deeper into its evilness and feels reductive and devoid of light, but Katja, your letter of concern is a small and subversive act of goodwill that can help tilt the world the other way. You are never helpless in the face of evil (unless you sit in perpetual condemnation of the world, as some sadly do). Your simple act of solicitude is the spark of kindness that can illuminate the entire universe. The world already feels brighter.</span></p>
<p class="BodyA" dir="ltr"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>
