	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-486" class="post-486 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #27 / February 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Have your own songs ever made you cry whilst performing them on stage?				</h1>
				<h3>SARAH, MANCHESTER, UK</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/have-your-own-songs-ever-made-you-cry-whilst-performing-them-on-stage/" title="Have your own songs ever made you cry whilst performing them on stage?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-1.png 864w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-1-250x167.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-1-768x513.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-1-700x467.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-1-120x80.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 864px) 100vw, 864px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Sarah,</p>
<p>The truth is it is very difficult to be sad on stage. When I walk on stage, I am thrust into the immediate moment &#8211; into the acute and astonishing now. I am seized by the enormous energy of the crowd, and the power of the music itself, where all memories disappear and the future does not exist. I am simply situated in the ecstatic present. I sing the songs with the utmost attention. I attempt to carry my audience with me, into the fullness of the moment, by applying complete concentration to the words. The words deliver their meaning, speaking to me afresh, <em>as if for the first time</em>, because the present moment is perpetually the first time. It is a state of blamelessness – a rapturous innocence – freed from what has gone before and what is yet to come.</p>
<p>However, every now and then, a sudden thought, beyond my control, pierces this state of present-ness – a devastating image or a shocking recollection or an impossible wish – and that <em>holy state of now</em> ruptures and the world comes crashing in, and, well, sometimes you cry.</p>
<p>And so it was at the Bad Seeds’ concert at the Manchester Arena, in your hometown, Sarah. I remember that concert so vividly. It was four months after the terrorist bombing, where twenty-three people died and untold were wounded, physically and psychologically. It was one of the first gigs in the Manchester Arena since it had re-opened, and there was a feeling of real defiance in the room, of course, but a terrible sadness too, I thought, at the sheer monstrousness of it all. A sadness because we understood that evil does walk among us, and that none of us has any real control over our destinies, that we are all tossed around by the arbitrary winds of fate and who ever really knows what is going to happen next?</p>
<p>At that concert in Manchester Arena, with these thoughts going through my mind, I felt an intense common bond with the audience, that became in the end almost overwhelming and which I will never forget. The unrestrained release at the end of the show was a deliverance for us all.</p>
<p>So to answer your question, Sarah, generally my own songs don’t make me cry, but sometimes I cry all the same. How can we not?</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-480" class="post-480 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #26 / February 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I am 10 and have been surrounded by and listened to your music as long as I can remember. I saw you in Hobart in January 2017 and I&#8217;ll be there again to see you in January 2019. None of my friends listen to anything cool, interesting or beautiful. How will having your music in my life so early on affect me, and have you got any advice for me? Thank you.				</h1>
				<h3>PTOLEMY, LAUNCESTON, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/how-will-your-music-affect-me/" title="I am 10 and have been surrounded by and listened to your music as long as I can remember. I saw you in Hobart in January 2017 and I&#8217;ll be there again to see you in January 2019. None of my friends listen to anything cool, interesting or beautiful. How will having your music in my life so early on affect me, and have you got any advice for me? Thank you.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1.png 824w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-250x377.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-768x1159.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-700x1056.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-120x181.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 824px) 100vw, 824px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							BEFORE I RECEIVED THE SECRET KNOWLEDGE							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Ptolemy,</p>
<p>I think I may have already answered your question at the In Conversations in Hobart &#8211; if you’re the little blonde kid, who was sitting on the right side of the hall. I can’t remember exactly what I replied, but I thought more about the question after the show, and I remember wishing I had answered it better.</p>
<p>Perhaps, this is what I should have said. Listening to Bad Seeds music at your age is like having a secret knowledge. When I was about your age I had a secret knowledge too. My eldest brother, Tim, used to listen to a lot of very strange and obscure music and he passed this knowledge on to me. Back then I lived in a rural city in Victoria and it seemed to me that nobody my age listened to the music my brother played to me. As far as I could tell they all listened to a whole lot of shit. It was like I carried a secret around inside me, a special knowledge about the world that my friends didn’t have. It was a secret power. I carried this secret power with me all through my kid-years until I went to a school in Melbourne, where I met three or four other people who also had this special knowledge – this secret power. These people became my best friends and we went on to form a band and tried, in our way, to take this knowledge and pass it on to the world.</p>
<p>This secret knowledge you have is a strength that lives only inside certain people. It is a strength that will inspire you to do wondrous things &#8211; like write stories, or draw pictures, or build rockets that fly to Mars. It will give you the courage to take on anything that the world might put in front of you. It’s a wild power that can be of untold value to the world.  Your name, Ptolemy, is a warrior’s name. A boy full of inspiration with a warrior’s name! The world is waiting for you. Blow ‘em away, kid.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

}

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-472" class="post-472 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #25 / February 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					I know who the greats are, but who are your most loved poets?				</h1>
				<h3>ASTRID, LA, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/your-most-loved-poets/" title="I know who the greats are, but who are your most loved poets?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-copy.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-copy.png 766w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-copy-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-copy-250x249.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-copy-700x698.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture1-copy-120x120.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 766px) 100vw, 766px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							JOHN BERRYMAN							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">During one of the &#8216;In Conversation&#8217; events, you mentioned that you look to some poets for inspiration in your songwriting. Which ones?</h1>
<h3>KATIE, PERTH, AUSTRALIA</h3>
</div>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Astrid and Katie,</span></p>
<p>I have always read a lot of poetry. It’s part of my job as a songwriter. I try to read, at the very least, a half-hour of poetry a day, before I begin to do my own writing. It jimmies open the imagination, making the mind more receptive to metaphor and abstraction and serves as a bridge from the reasoned mind to a stranger state of alertness, in case that precious idea decides to drop by.</p>
<p>Sometimes the reading is something of a chore and there are many “great” poets I find boring, inscrutable, long-winded and painful to read. They can be bad news for the imaginative process.</p>
<p>However, I have a few poets that, purely on a personal level, always delight and are a simple pleasure to read. There are enough surprises within their writing to keep the mind light and alive. This is by no means a definitive list and in no particular order. I’m just sitting here at my desk looking at my bookshelf, in fact. They are poets whose company I consistently enjoy.  </p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Stevie Smith</p>
<p>Frederick Seidel</p>
<p>William Blake</p>
<p>Sherwood Anderson</p>
<p>Rae Armantrout</p>
<p>Langston Hughes</p>
<p>E. E. Cummings</p>
<p>W. B. Yeats</p>
<p>John Berryman</p>
<p>Sylvia Plath</p>
<p>Thomas Hardy</p>
<p>Philip Larkin</p>
<p>Emily Dickinson</p>
<p>Sharon Olds</p>
<p>W. H. Auden</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Just to say, my list, in this instance, is of poets writing in the English language, for no other reason than to make the list more manageable.</p>
<p>Beyond this list, there are various poetry anthologies which are always an education and an immense pleasure to dive into, most notably those put together by the great Jerome Rothenberg &#8211; among them Barbaric, Vast and Wild, Shaking the Pumpkin, A Big Jewish Book, America a Prophesy and Technicians of the Sacred. (See Red Hand File #5).</p>
<p>Much love, Nick</p>
<p><img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture2-copy-250x250.png" alt="" width="250" height="250" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-476" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture2-copy-250x250.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture2-copy-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture2-copy-700x699.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture2-copy-120x120.png 120w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Picture2-copy.png 764w" sizes="(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;">STEVIE SMITH</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-466" class="post-466 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #24 / February 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					In your response to an audience question in Brisbane, I am bothered that you dismissed the idea of leaving a legacy &#8211; that it didn&#8217;t matter what you left behind. I&#8217;d like to challenge you on this. A body of artistic work, that has also had an enormous personal impact on the lives of many people &#8211; given meaning, comfort, joy and hope, and shaped their world views &#8211; is a legacy to be acknowledged and respected. Could you expand on your thoughts of your legacy?				</h1>
				<h3>ANGELINA, BRISBANE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/thoughts-of-your-legacy/" title="In your response to an audience question in Brisbane, I am bothered that you dismissed the idea of leaving a legacy &#8211; that it didn&#8217;t matter what you left behind. I&#8217;d like to challenge you on this. A body of artistic work, that has also had an enormous personal impact on the lives of many people &#8211; given meaning, comfort, joy and hope, and shaped their world views &#8211; is a legacy to be acknowledged and respected. Could you expand on your thoughts of your legacy?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Unknown-3.jpeg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Unknown-3.jpeg 563w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Unknown-3-250x284.jpeg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Unknown-3-120x136.jpeg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 563px) 100vw, 563px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							SELF CLEANSE BY BEN SMITH							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Angelina,</p>
<p>I very much take your point &#8211; my answer was dismissive and unhelpful. As you point out, it undermined the relationship with my work that other people may have. I’m sorry about that. I very much appreciate you writing in and pushing back against my statement.</p>
<p>What I should have said is that I am still actively engaged in the business of songwriting and doing everything in my power to stay afloat. This is not as easy as it may appear and involves a certain amount of self-deception. Part of that process is to occasionally affect a dismissive attitude toward my earlier songs, as if my best work is still ahead of me. How could I continue to write if I believed otherwise? Here, most probably, truth collides with necessity. We look to what ought to be rather than what is. The newly formed song needs all the support it can get to front up to the impossible weight of the hundreds of songs I have already written. Indeed, how can the new idea ever hope to compete with the deep attachment that people seem to have with those past and treasured songs?</p>
<p>I am dancing on water lilies when I write and one’s heritage can have a terrifying tonnage. I must remain one step ahead of the songs, optimistically hopping from lily pad to lily pad, and doing my best to ignore the great dark wave of work that is building up behind me. How many artists have we seen stop and turn around to look, only to literally drown in a pool of their own legacy.</p>
<p>I am sure a time will come, Angelina &#8211; perhaps in the not too distant future &#8211; when I can sit back like some loony old patriarch and cast a weepy eye over my legacy, as they wheel me on stage to receive my ‘Lifetime Achievement Award&#8217;, but not this year, please, I beg you, not this year.</p>
<p>With Love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-460" class="post-460 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #23 / January 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Three and a half years ago I lost my wife and I was left to take care of my (then 2 year old) daughter. She&#8217;s a happy little girl but I know she&#8217;s happiest when her father is happy. I&#8217;ve been finding it hard to find happiness. It&#8217;s not my loss &#8211; I made peace with that a while back. I just haven&#8217;t found my life again.  You&#8217;re a happy man. We all get that vibe when we see you play live.  Has it always been this way, have you always been able to cut through the heavy moments in life to enjoy living?				</h1>
				<h3>WILLIAM, BROOKLYN, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/hard-to-find-happiness/" title="Three and a half years ago I lost my wife and I was left to take care of my (then 2 year old) daughter. She&#8217;s a happy little girl but I know she&#8217;s happiest when her father is happy. I&#8217;ve been finding it hard to find happiness. It&#8217;s not my loss &#8211; I made peace with that a while back. I just haven&#8217;t found my life again.  You&#8217;re a happy man. We all get that vibe when we see you play live.  Has it always been this way, have you always been able to cut through the heavy moments in life to enjoy living?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-5.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-5.png 862w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-5-250x165.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-5-768x508.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-5-700x463.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-5-120x79.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 862px) 100vw, 862px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							PHOTO BY GOSHA RUBCHINSKIY							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear William,</p>
<p>Thank you for your question. Please accept this answer, in the spirit that it is given, as a simple and supportive response to your letter.</p>
<p>It seems to me that you are reacting entirely appropriately to a devastating situation that has ransacked your life. This is not what you signed up for when you got married &#8211; to be alone and looking after your little daughter. When you said that you have made peace with the death of your wife, this may on some level be true, but the residual feelings of aloneness, loss of control, and cosmic betrayal must still hold a powerful sway over your life. No wonder you can’t find your life. That life you once had does not exist. You have a new life.</p>
<blockquote>
<p style="text-align: center;">No wonder you can&#8217;t find your life. That life you once had does not exist. You have a new life.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Three and a half years have passed, for both of us. We feel we should be better. We feel equilibrium should be restored. We feel we have in someway failed and that we should have made peace with the world. We feel people must be sick to death of us, and our fucking <em>grief</em>. But grief is beyond our control; it is omnipotent and invincible and we are miniscule in its presence and when it comes for us, all we can do is to kneel before it, heads bowed and await its passing.</p>
<p>But, as you know, grief is also tidal. In time, it can recede and leave us with feelings of peace and advancement, only for it to wash back in with all its crushing hopelessness and sorrow. Back and forth it goes, but with each retreating drift of despair, we are left a little stronger, more resilient, more essential and better at our new life. I can feel these tides of anguish and restoration move through your words. They say so much about grief, but also the sanctity of fatherhood. What a glorious thing fatherhood is! Within your words, William, great hope resides, for you, for your daughter, and for us all.</p>
<blockquote>
<p style="text-align: center;">They say so much about grief, but also the sanctity of fatherhood. What a glorious thing fatherhood is!</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Nothing, of course, happens fast enough and we just want to be returned to that uncomplicated life we once had &#8211; we want stability restored &#8211; but it is not to be. Now we have a new life; unchartered, uncertain, beyond our control, and that we are on some level undertaking alone, even within the company of the ones we love. Our worlds are still raw and new. They hum with suffering, but there is immense power there too.</p>
<p>We are alone but we are also connected in a personhood of suffering. We have reached out to each other, with nothing to offer, but an acceptance of our mutual despair. We must understand that the depths of our anguish signal the heights we can, in time, attain. This is an act of extraordinary faith. It makes demands on the vast reserves of inner-strength that you may not even be aware of. But they are there. As your little daughter dances through her father’s tears, she leads the way. The way lies there before us.</p>
<p>With love, Nick.</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-452" class="post-452 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #22 / January 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Considering human imagination the last piece of wilderness, do you think AI will ever be able to write a good song?				</h1>
				<h3>PETER, LJUBLJANA, SLOVENIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/considering-human-imagination-the-last-piece-of-wilderness-do-you-think-ai-will-ever-be-able-to-write-a-good-song/" title="Considering human imagination the last piece of wilderness, do you think AI will ever be able to write a good song?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-4.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-4.png 922w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-4-250x165.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-4-768x508.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-4-700x463.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-4-120x79.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 922px) 100vw, 922px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div>Dear Peter,</p>
<p>In Yuval Noah Harari’s brilliant new book <em>21 Lessons for the 21<sup>st</sup> Century, </em>he writes that Artificial Intelligence, with its limitless potential and connectedness, will ultimately render many humans redundant in the work place. This sounds entirely feasible. However, he goes on to say that AI will be able to write better songs than humans can. He says, and excuse my simplistic summation, that we listen to songs to make us feel certain things and that in the future AI will simply be able to map the individual mind and create songs tailored exclusively to our own particular mental algorithms, that can make us feel, with far more intensity and precision, whatever it is we want to feel. If we are feeling sad and want to feel happy we simply listen to our bespoke AI happy song and the job will be done.</p>
<p>But, I am not sure that this is all songs do. Of course, we go to songs to make us feel something – happy, sad, sexy, homesick, excited or whatever &#8211; but this is not all a song does. What a great song makes us feel is a sense of awe. There is a reason for this. A sense of awe is almost exclusively predicated on our limitations as human beings. It is entirely to do with our audacity as humans to reach beyond our potential.</p>
<blockquote>
<p style="text-align: center;">A sense of awe is almost exclusively predicated on our limitations as human beings.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>It is perfectly conceivable that AI could produce a song as good as Nirvana’s <em>Smells Like Teen Spirit</em>, for example, and that it ticked all the boxes required to make us feel what a song like that should make us feel – in this case, excited and rebellious, let’s say. It is also feasible that AI could produce a song that makes us feel these same feelings, but more intensely than any human songwriter could do.</p>
<p>But, I don’t feel that when we listen to <em>Smells Like Teen Spirit</em> it is only the song that we are listening to. It feels to me, that what we are actually listening to is a withdrawn and alienated young man’s journey out of the small American town of Aberdeen – a young man who by any measure was a walking bundle of dysfunction and human limitation – a young man who had the temerity to howl his particular pain into a microphone and in doing so, by way of the heavens, reach into the hearts of a generation. We are also listening to Iggy Pop walk across his audience’s hands and smear himself in peanut butter whilst singing <em>1970</em>. We are listening to Beethoven compose the <em>Ninth Symphony</em> while almost totally deaf. We are listening to Prince, that tiny cluster of purple atoms, singing in the pouring rain at the Super Bowl and blowing everyone’s minds. We are listening to Nina Simone stuff all her rage and disappointment into the most tender of love songs. We are listening to Paganini continue to play his Stradivarius as the strings snapped. We are listening to Jimi Hendrix kneel and set fire to his own instrument. </p>
<blockquote>
<p style="text-align: center;">We are listening to Jimi Hendrix kneel and set fire to his own instrument.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>What we are actually listening to is human limitation and the audacity to transcend it. Artificial Intelligence, for all its unlimited potential, simply doesn’t have this capacity. How could it? And this is the essence of transcendence. If we have limitless potential then what is there to transcend? And therefore what is the purpose of the imagination at all. Music has the ability to touch the celestial sphere with the tips of its fingers and the awe and wonder we feel is in the desperate temerity of the reach, not just the outcome. Where is the transcendent splendour in unlimited potential? So to answer your question, Peter, AI would have the capacity to write a good song, but not a great one. It lacks the nerve.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<title>Nick Cave - The Red Hand Files - Issue #21 - Dear Nick - and All Ingrates Who Don&#039;t Appreciate Nocturama, Issue #20 might be a fun little read but please kindly note that you&#039;re all in my burn-book now for spitting on Nocturama, which I love with a capital L. I&#039;ve taken Nocturama with me to battles; it has whispered and screamed me to sleep; it has proven to be a true friend through assorted trials - when and where all other musicks failed; it is a lot of things, not one thing, it conjures the night during the day and the day during endless-seeming nights; it is of thresholds, nether-places, about leaps of faith, the bravery of leaving old riches and old rots behind; and I shall front its detractors and enemies, alone if needs be, until the day I die - and am buried while they play Bring It On. Whatever did you think. Nocturama is not a failure. It is a breakthrough. It is a musical monument marking rebirth. It is alive. End of Declaration of War and Testament of Greatness. : The Red Hand Files</title>

I&#8217;ve taken Nocturama with me to battles; it has whispered and screamed me to sleep; it has proven to be a true friend through assorted trials &#8211; when and where all other musicks failed; it is a lot of things, not one thing, it conjures the night during the day and the day during endless-seeming nights; it is of thresholds, nether-places, about leaps of faith, the bravery of leaving old riches and old rots behind; and I shall front its detractors and enemies, alone if needs be, until the day I die &#8211; and am buried while they play Bring It On. 		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-444" class="post-444 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #21 / January 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Dear Nick &#8211; and All Ingrates Who Don&#8217;t Appreciate Nocturama, Issue #20 might be a fun little read but please kindly note that you&#8217;re all in my burn-book now for spitting on Nocturama, which I love with a capital L. I&#8217;ve taken Nocturama with me to battles; it has whispered and screamed me to sleep; it has proven to be a true friend through assorted trials &#8211; when and where all other musicks failed; it is a lot of things, not one thing, it conjures the night during the day and the day during endless-seeming nights; it is of thresholds, nether-places, about leaps of faith, the bravery of leaving old riches and old rots behind; and I shall front its detractors and enemies, alone if needs be, until the day I die &#8211; and am buried while they play Bring It On. Whatever did you think.                   Nocturama is not a failure. It is a breakthrough. It is a musical monument marking rebirth. It is alive.  End of Declaration of War and Testament of Greatness.				</h1>
				<h3>BURCU, ISTANBUL, TURKEY</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/spitting-on-nocturama/" title="Dear Nick &#8211; and All Ingrates Who Don&#8217;t Appreciate Nocturama, Issue #20 might be a fun little read but please kindly note that you&#8217;re all in my burn-book now for spitting on Nocturama, which I love with a capital L. I&#8217;ve taken Nocturama with me to battles; it has whispered and screamed me to sleep; it has proven to be a true friend through assorted trials &#8211; when and where all other musicks failed; it is a lot of things, not one thing, it conjures the night during the day and the day during endless-seeming nights; it is of thresholds, nether-places, about leaps of faith, the bravery of leaving old riches and old rots behind; and I shall front its detractors and enemies, alone if needs be, until the day I die &#8211; and am buried while they play Bring It On. Whatever did you think.                   Nocturama is not a failure. It is a breakthrough. It is a musical monument marking rebirth. It is alive.  End of Declaration of War and Testament of Greatness.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Unknown-5-1.jpeg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Unknown-5-1.jpeg 473w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Unknown-5-1-150x150.jpeg 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Unknown-5-1-250x250.jpeg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Unknown-5-1-120x120.jpeg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 473px) 100vw, 473px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Burcu,</p>
<h1>😀</h1>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>

I see how it can help but I feel as if many people replaced doing drugs with talking about when they used to do drugs. I am trying to find a good support system but it is hard. 					<!-- /nav -->

			</header>
			<!-- /header -->

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-438" class="post-438 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #20 / January 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Can you explain why Nocturama is so hated amongst your fans?				</h1>
				<h3>DELILAH, NYC, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/why-nocturama-is-so-hated/" title="Can you explain why Nocturama is so hated amongst your fans?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-1.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-1-250x323.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-1-700x903.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-1-120x155.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 768px) 100vw, 768px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							AROUND THE TIME OF NOCTURAMA. PHOTO: POLLY BORLAND.							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title"><strong><span lang="EN-US">Nick, why is it, do you think, that many of your fans are so critical of Nocturama?</span></strong></h1>
<h3>ANNE, MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title"><strong><span lang="EN-US">Nocturama is your worst record? Why?</span></strong></h1>
<h3>MIGUEL, PORTO, PORTUGAL</h3>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title"><strong><span lang="EN-US">Nocturama? What the fuck?!!</span></strong></h1>
<h3>FADUMA, MOGADISHU, SOMALIA</h3>
</div>
<div>
<p>Dear Delilah, Anne, Miguel and Faduma,</p>
<p>Nocturama is held in such universal contempt that its very title has become a byword for failure or disaster. “He tried his best but ultimately he met his Nocturama,” you may hear someone say, or perhaps “What a complete and utter Nocturama!” As the years have passed, the disdain for this record has not diminished, and Nocturama has become just another word for ‘loser’ – as in “Fuck you, you fucking Nocturama!” and still it continues to this day, so that when a Bad Seeds fan gets poked in the eye or kicked in the nuts, they cry, “<em>Nocturama!”</em></p>
<p>Therefore it comes as no surprise that many of the questions I have received on The Red Hand Files circle around the failings of this sad, brave, little record.</p>
<p>Personally, I like Nocturama. I like that it is out there, moving around the place and spoiling things. I like it that someone may accidently play it at a party and people start throwing up in the ashtrays. I like it that everyone stands upwind from it. I especially like it that of the sixteen records the Bad Seeds have produced we only have one Nocturama, whereas with some bands half their records are Nocturamas, and with most bands <em>all</em> of their records are Nocturamas.</p>
<p>I think that in the end we all need our Nocturamas. Your Nocturama may, indeed, be the most important thing you ever do. Failure fortifies us. It moves us forward. It strips everything back to its essential nature and leaves us clean and pure, ready to begin again. You don’t create something as problematic as Nocturama without a certain risk and a little courage and the temerity to fail. I love this troubled record for that. It may just be my favourite.</p>
<p>Much love to you all, Nick</p>
</div>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-432" class="post-432 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #19 / January 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Why do you want to talk to your fans and what do you hope to achieve by doing this?				</h1>
				<h3>JONATHAN, CHOBHAM, UK</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/why-do-you-want-to-talk-to-fans/" title="Why do you want to talk to your fans and what do you hope to achieve by doing this?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Unknown-5.jpeg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Unknown-5.jpeg 473w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Unknown-5-150x150.jpeg 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Unknown-5-250x250.jpeg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Unknown-5-120x120.jpeg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 473px) 100vw, 473px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							SPRINGTIME IN KEW GARDENS							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">If you were a flower, which one would you be?</h1>
<h3>GISELA, PORTO, PORTUGAL</h3>
</div>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Jonathan and Gisela,</span></p>
<p>I’m writing this very early in the morning from Brisbane. I played an ‘In Conversations’ show last night and sat up talking with people afterwards.</p>
<p>As I take these events around the country, I am meeting audiences who are asking thoughtful, fearless and challenging questions, many of which have resonated deeply with me. So it is with The Red Hand Files. When I started the Files I had a small idea that people were in need of more thoughtful discourse. I felt a similar need. I felt that social media was by its nature undermining both nuance and connectivity. I thought that, for my fans at least, The Red Hand Files could go some way to remedy that. The number and breadth of questions I have received over the last three months has been staggering, indeed, many are not questions at all, but people using the Files to tell their own stories. It is a privilege to read these pieces of writing and it is both a pleasure and an honour to stand on stage before you all.</p>
<p>And now, to your question, Gisela!</p>
<p>If I had to be a flower, I would be a bluebell.</p>
<p>I remember lying under the old Yew tree in Kew Gardens with my wife, Susie, in a vast field of bluebells. It was year 2000 and we would visit the gardens often that spring. It was a magical time, full of excitement and promise. Susie was heavily pregnant with the twins and we could barely contain ourselves, as we lay there in the shade of the ancient tree, with the children growing inside her, as the momentary bluebells looked on.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><em>Now we sit beneath the knotted Yew</em></p>
<p><em>And the bluebells bob around our shoes</em></p>
<p><em>The task of remembering the tell-tale clues</em></p>
<p><em>Goes to my sorrowful wife</em></p>
<p><em>Who is counting the days on her fingers</em></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Much love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<main role="main" aria-label="Content">
	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-419" class="post-419 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #18 / January 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					How did it work out for you – facing the mob in Wangaratta when you did your “In Conversation” event, with no idea of what would happen? You took such a risk. I would love to know how it was for you?				</h1>
				<h3>JENNY, WANGARATTA, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/facing-the-mob-in-wangaratta/" title="How did it work out for you – facing the mob in Wangaratta when you did your “In Conversation” event, with no idea of what would happen? You took such a risk. I would love to know how it was for you?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-copy-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-copy-1.png 767w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-copy-1-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-copy-1-250x248.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-copy-1-700x695.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture1-copy-1-120x119.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 767px) 100vw, 767px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							DAMAGED CHRIST CHILD IN THE WANGARATTA CATHERDRAL							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div>
<p>Dear Jenny,</p>
<p>As I drove into Wangaratta, the town I grew up in, with my eighteen year old son sitting beside me, Ausmuteants blaring through the sound system, I had an uncanny, dizzying feeling that my childhood was no longer in the past, as one would expect, but rolling out in front of me, and the child I thought I could see shimmering in the heat and walking down the road toward me, was, in fact, myself.</p>
<p>It was nearly fifty years ago that I left Wangaratta and I was anxious about a lot of things, but mostly that this town I had conjured up so many times in my songs and novels would be unrecognisable to me now. I was anxious that my imagination might have overridden the truth of the town to fit the narrative purposes of my songs. I was afraid that it would feel as if I were simply in the wrong place – that it would feel unauthentic, a fabrication &#8211; so long have I lived away from the town and so long I have lived inside my songs.</p>
<p>But as we drove around the town and visited the places I knew so well as a child &#8211; the Railway Hotel, the Wangaratta Cathedral, the rusted railway bridge, the High School, the muddy Ovens River, the swimming pool, my house in Mepunga Ave &#8211; I was amazed at how little the town had changed and how close to the truth my songs actually were. It seemed to me, that so many of the songs and stories I had written were simply guides to “the idea of a river, an open space and a small town” in the North East of Victoria.</p>
<p>But still the strange feeling of vertigo persisted. I felt that I had caught up to the vision of the child shimmering on the road in the sun and found that it was my childhood self &#8211; and that child would be the one who would take my hand and lead me back through the old town, who would show me around; but further than that, my child-self would tug at my sleeve, and guide me down to the river and ultimately, in the final hour, take me across it, to the other side, wherever that may be.</p>
<p>When I stood on stage in Wangaratta, I was overcome by the warmth of the audience and their total lack of resentment for some of the unfortunate things I had said about Wangaratta in the past. These were foolish things to say because these comments were not just an affront to the town itself but to the child that inhabited the town, for indeed these two things are one and the same.</p>
<p>When I visited the cathedral, where I had spent every Sunday morning and Tuesday night yawning my way through morning mass and evensong as a chorister, I was overwhelmed &#8211; this holy place had, without me even knowing it, forged so many of my ideas about the world that remain true to me to this day. The Dean of the church had kindly opened it for us. He had come to the church because someone had snapped the head off the plaster baby Jesus in the Christmas Nativity scene. “He’s been decapitated,” said the Dean, quietly. We have made contact with the church to offer a contribution to help restore the infant Jesus&#8217; head to his body. It seems the very least I can do, all things considered.</p>
<p>So, Jenny, to answer your question – to stand before the people of Wangaratta was a special kind of privilege. It felt restorative, like a circle completed.</p>
<p>With love, Nick</p>
</div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-423" src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture2-250x250.png" alt="" width="250" height="250" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture2-250x250.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture2-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture2-700x699.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture2-120x120.png 120w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture2.png 765w" sizes="(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;">THE RAILWAY BRIDGE OVER THE OVENS RIVER, WANGARATTA</p>

Perhaps I am being too cynical and not giving it a chance? Do you have any more advice for a recovering heroin user?">‘What do you think about NA? 	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-414" class="post-414 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #17 / January 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					Hang on a minute. 72 hours to the end of the world, and you contact Rachel to send out an email? One would imagine that, however well you hopefully treat her, she would have the presence of mind to tell you to send your own damn emails. Why doesn&#8217;t Rachel get a break at the end of the world?				</h1>
				<h3>CINDY, AUSTIN, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/send-your-own-damn-emails/" title="Hang on a minute. 72 hours to the end of the world, and you contact Rachel to send out an email? One would imagine that, however well you hopefully treat her, she would have the presence of mind to tell you to send your own damn emails. Why doesn&#8217;t Rachel get a break at the end of the world?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture-1-original-copy.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture-1-original-copy.jpg 915w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture-1-original-copy-150x150.jpg 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture-1-original-copy-250x250.jpg 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture-1-original-copy-768x768.jpg 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture-1-original-copy-700x700.jpg 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Picture-1-original-copy-120x120.jpg 120w" sizes="(max-width: 915px) 100vw, 915px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Cindy,</p>
<p>If you were ever to apply for a job as a personal assistant and in the interview your potential employer asks you the following question –</p>
<p>“If the world was going to end in 72 hours and I asked you to send a short email, what would your reply be?</p>
<p>A) Consider it done.</p>
<p>B) Send your own damn email.”</p>
<p>&#8211; my advice would be to choose option A.</p>
<p>Actually, I asked Rachel, my assistant of twenty years, if, in fact, she would send the email if there was only 72 hours left before the end of the world, and she said no, she wouldn’t, because she’d probably be picking up my dry cleaning.</p>
<p>With Love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

        </li>
                
        <li>
          <h4><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/pet-theory-your-creativity-flourish/">Issue #121</a><br>-</h4>
          <h5><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/pet-theory-your-creativity-flourish/" title="In an interview from 1997 in Los Angeles, you introduced us to your &#8220;pet theory&#8221;: your creativity could only flourish in a state of loss and longing, and that it needed catastrophes in your life. <br> Finally, and this is what resonated with me the most, you stated that you could not get much substance out of living a life which was content. Do you still believe that? <br> A sincere and devoted admirer of yours who sort of struggles in a content life.">‘In an interview from 1997 in Los Angeles, you introduced us to your &#8220;pet theory&#8221;: your creativity could only flourish in a state of loss and longing, and that it needed ...’</a></h5>
        </li>
                
        <li>
          <h4><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-do-you-think-about-na/">Issue #120</a><br>-</h4>
          <h5><a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-do-you-think-about-na/" title="What do you think about NA? 		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-398" class="post-398 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #16 / January 2019</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					What would be a list of 10 of your most favourite pieces of music, by artists other than yourself? And number 11 must be a Gun Club song.				</h1>
				<h3>G, FALLS CHURCH, USA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/10-most-favourite-pieces-music/" title="What would be a list of 10 of your most favourite pieces of music, by artists other than yourself? And number 11 must be a Gun Club song.">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-3.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-3.png 856w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-3-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-3-250x251.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-3-768x770.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-3-700x702.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-3-120x120.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 856px) 100vw, 856px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							HAPPY WITH NINA SIMONE, LONDON. PHOTO: BLEDDYN BUTCHER							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">Can you put together a list of your top five albums and ask Warren Ellis to do the same?</h1>
<h3>WILLIAM, PERTH, AUSTRALIA</h3>
</div>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Dear G and William,</span></p>
<p>In my extended poem, “The Sick Bag Song”, I wrote about Leonard Cohen and the effect that he had on me as a young boy when I first heard him sing.</p>
<p><em>“Leonard Cohen will sing, and the boy will suddenly breathe as if for the first time, and fall inside the laughing man’s voice and hide.</em></p>
<p><em>The boy will grow older, and over time there will be other songs – not many – ten or maybe twenty in a lifespan, that stand apart from the rest of the music he will discover. He will realise that not only are these songs sacred, they are ‘hiding songs’ that deal exclusively in darkness, obfuscation, concealment and secrecy. He will realise that for him the purpose of these songs was to shut off the sun, to draw a long shadow down and protect him from the corrosive glare of the world.”</em></p>
<h1 class="post-title" style="text-align: center;">*</h1>
<p>Occasionally people have asked me what those ‘hiding songs’ were. I have never revealed them in their entirety. Perhaps, I felt a strange ownership over them and that to release them to the world may constitute a form of betrayal. Do you ever feel like that about songs &#8211; that they were designed with you especially in mind, and that no one could ever begin to understand them in the way you do? My ‘hiding songs’ serve as a form of refuge for me and have done so for years. They are songs that I can pull over myself, like a child might pull the bed covers over their head, when the blaze of the world becomes too intense. I can literally hide inside them. They are the essential pillars that hold up the structure of my artistic world. There are hundreds of other favourite songs, of course, and one day maybe I can do a list of some of those, but not today. Today, I give you the ‘hiding songs’.</p>
<p>G and William (and anyone else, for that matter), I’d be interested to know if you have any ‘hiding songs’, and if so what they are. You know where to find me!</p>
<p><strong>10 HIDING SONGS</strong></p>
<p>Avalanche, Leonard Cohen</p>
<p>Katie Cruel, Karen Dalton</p>
<p>On the Beach, Neil Young</p>
<p>Tupelo, John Lee Hooker</p>
<p>T.B. Sheets, Van Morrison</p>
<p>It&#8217;s All Over Now, Baby Blue, Bob Dylan</p>
<p>Plain Gold Ring, Nina Simone</p>
<p>Holocaust, Big Star</p>
<p>Becalmed, Brian Eno</p>
<p>One Fine Morning, Bill Callahan</p>
<h1 class="post-title" style="text-align: center;">*</h1>
<p>William, I called Warren in Paris. He was happy to make you a list of his top five albums.</p>
<p>World Galaxy, Alice Coltrane With Strings</p>
<p>The Rite of Spring, Igor Stravinsky</p>
<p>Another Green World, Brian Eno</p>
<p>I’m New Here, Gil Scott-Heron</p>
<p>The Velvet Underground &amp; Nico</p>
<h1 class="post-title" style="text-align: center;">*</h1>
<p>Oh, and G &#8211; &#8216;Mother of Earth’ by The Gun Club.</p>
<p>Much love, Nick</p>
<p><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-407" src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-2-250x248.png" alt="" width="250" height="248" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-2-250x248.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-2-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-2-700x694.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-2-120x119.png 120w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-2.png 709w" sizes="(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px" /></p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

							<div class="content__gdpr">
								<fieldset class="mc_fieldset gdprRequired mc-field-group" name="interestgroup_field">

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-384" class="post-384 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #15 / December 2018</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					So to continue! You say you would freak the fuck out when you heard that you have only 72 hours to live. I don’t hear you writing anything about your sons and the other band members. Did you forget them?				</h1>
				<h3>CAROLINA, KAMPERLAND, NETHERLANDS</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/only-had-72-hours-band-members/" title="So to continue! You say you would freak the fuck out when you heard that you have only 72 hours to live. I don’t hear you writing anything about your sons and the other band members. Did you forget them?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-1.png 765w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-1-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-1-250x250.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-1-700x700.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-1-120x120.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 765px) 100vw, 765px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Carolina,<br />
Just to be clear, I did in fact mention my sons in the second Freak The Fuck Out answer – Issue #12. I said, “I would gather my family together, hold them tightly, and speak some comforting words…” The family I am referring to is my wife and my sons.</p>
<p>You are, however, correct in pointing out that I omitted to mention my band members and, as I read your question, I felt a pang of shame to think that we were all going to be atomised in 72 hours and I had not attempted to say goodbye to them. In my defence, there are very real problems in contacting The Bad Seeds. Firstly, only George answers the phone when I call. Tommy &amp; Marty rarely go near telephones &#8211; Tommy has full-blown telephobia and the ever-elusive Marty hasn’t, as far as I can tell, unboxed the Apple iPhone XS Max recently bought for him (at great expense) by our management. Larry only does social media, which I don’t know how to do, and to contact Jim, I have to go through his wife, who I like very much, but who isn’t speaking to me at the moment. Warren and I are so spiritually aligned that we communicate telepathically, which is fortunate as he never rings me back when I call, rather he messages me saying he will ‘call back later’, which he rarely, if ever, does. I have a terrible, lurking suspicion that none of The Bad Seeds like me very much. What I should &#8211; or would &#8211; therefore do, is contact my assistant, Rachel, and have her send out a group email. The email would say:</p>
<h1 class="post-title" style="text-align: center;">***</h1>
<p>Dear Bad Seeds,</p>
<p>As we only have 72 hours until our mutual annihilation, I will keep this brief. You are the very best there is. It has been an honour working with you.</p>
<p>With love to you all,</p>
<p>Nick</p>
<p>PS After much thought I have decided to give you all a bonus. It will be deposited into your account within three working days.</p>
<h1 class="post-title" style="text-align: center;">***</h1>
<p>Then, I would go back to my family – my wife, my sons, my dogs, my Brian Eno records – and continue to freak the fuck out!</p>
<p>Much love, Nick</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

<html lang="en-AU" class="no-js">
	<head>
		<meta charset="UTF-8">
		<title>Nick Cave - The Red Hand Files - Issue #14 - There is a photograph. You are wearing checked pants; you have your arm around a woman who appears to be stately and warm, in a very beautiful understated woollen coat. I think it is your mother. May I ask what was the most helpful advice she gave you? What of her words do you hold dear? : The Red Hand Files</title>

		<link href="//www.google-analytics.com" rel="dns-prefetch">
		<link href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/themes/red-hand-files/dist/img/icons/favicon.ico" rel="shortcut icon">
		<link href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/themes/red-hand-files/dist/img/icons/touch.png" rel="apple-touch-icon-precomposed">

	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-372" class="post-372 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #14 / December 2018</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					There is a photograph. You are wearing checked pants; you have your arm around a woman who appears to be stately and warm, in a very beautiful understated woollen coat. I think it is your mother. May I ask what was the most helpful advice she gave you? What of her words do you hold dear?				</h1>
				<h3>CATHERINE, MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/your-mother-most-helpful-advice-gave-you/" title="There is a photograph. You are wearing checked pants; you have your arm around a woman who appears to be stately and warm, in a very beautiful understated woollen coat. I think it is your mother. May I ask what was the most helpful advice she gave you? What of her words do you hold dear?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-1.png 824w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-1-250x288.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-1-768x885.png 768w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-1-700x806.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-1-120x138.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 824px) 100vw, 824px" />							</a>
														<p style="text-align: center;">
							LEAVING HOME FOR LONDON - 1979 (MAYBE)							</p>
												<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<div class="post__title-block">
<h1 class="post-title">Please tell me something that will help me not care when people stare at me because I look different to everybody else?</h1>
<h3>BAM, BRIGHTON, UK</h3>
</div>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Dear Catherine and Bam,</span></p>
<p>My mother gave me much advice over the years on how to live a decent life. Sadly, I didn’t take that much notice of it. Mostly though, she simply allowed me to be myself, to make my own mistakes and to find my own way. She served, and still serves, as a reminder that it is entirely possible to lead an ethical life where we can be kind and careful and welcoming and, most of all, take responsibility for our actions and not complain or blame others for our own misfortunes. She continues to lead a life of great integrity – she is ninety-two &#8211; but it is not without a certain acerbic humour and a wry eye for the absurdities of the world.</p>
<p>But there was one piece of advice my mother gave me some years ago that affected me deeply and was of enormous practical value in my life. I can’t tell you how often I have brought it to mind and acted accordingly, and how much strength and moral fortitude it has afforded me. So often I have read questions in The Red Hand Files from people who feel lost, marginalised, lonely, scared of their creative impulses, freakish, less than, manipulated, silenced, bullied at school and all the rest, and my mother’s words often come to mind.</p>
<p>I had been awarded an honorary doctorate by Monash University in Melbourne and my mother accompanied me to the university to receive it. I was feeling a little intimidated by the whole thing because I was stepping out of my rock ‘n’ roll comfort zone, in-to the academic sphere and the whole affair had me feeling quite uncomfortable. I mentioned this to my mother, and as we stepped out of the car into the university grounds, she said,</p>
<p>“Head high and fuck ‘em all.”</p>
<p>I am passing this crucial piece of maternal wisdom on to you Bam and Catherine &#8211; and to the rest of you out there. It is my mother’s gift to you.</p>
<p>Love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-365" class="post-365 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #13 / December 2018</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					What are your thoughts on Brian Eno’s stance on Israel?				</h1>
				<h3>CHRISTOPHER, MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/what-are-your-thoughts-on-brian-enos-stance-on-israel/" title="What are your thoughts on Brian Eno’s stance on Israel?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-copy.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-copy.png 764w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-copy-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-copy-250x250.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-copy-700x700.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-copy-120x120.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 764px) 100vw, 764px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p>Dear Christopher, </p>
<p>I have received a number of messages broadly relating to this issue, so perhaps this is an opportunity to address this matter by sharing some actual correspondence I had with Brian Eno about it. After announcing my decision to play two shows in Israel at the end of my world tour last year, Brian emailed me in the hope of persuading me to reconsider this decision. Below is my reply, which may go some way to answering your question.<br />
&nbsp;</p>
<h1 class="post-title" style="text-align: center;">***</h1>
<p>Dear Brian,</p>
<p>Clearly the decision for The Bad Seeds to play in Israel is contentious for some people. But to be clear on this: I do not support the current government in Israel, yet do not accept that my decision to play in the country is any kind of tacit support for that government’s policies. Nor do I condone the atrocities that you have described; nor am I ignorant of them. I am aware of the injustices suffered by the Palestinian population, and wish, with all people of good conscience, that their suffering is ended via a comprehensive and just solution, one that involves enormous political will on both sides of the equation.</p>
<p>But I also do not support the Boycott, Divestments and Sanctions movement, as you know. I think the cultural boycott of Israel is cowardly and shameful. In fact, this is partly the reason I am playing Israel – not as support for any particular political entity but as a principled stand against those who wish to bully, shame and silence musicians. I don&#8217;t intend to engage in a detailed discussion as to how the boycott of Israel can be seen to be anti-Semitic at heart and, furthermore, does not work (rather, it risks further entrenching positions in Israel in opposition to those you support), but even the estimable Noam Chomsky considers the BDS as lacking legitimacy and inherently hypocritical. What we actually have here is a fundamental difference of opinion as to what the purpose of music is. </p>
<p>It struck me while writing this how much more powerful a statement you could make if you were to go to Israel and tell the press and the Israeli people how you feel about their current regime, then do a concert on the understanding that the purpose of your music was to speak to the Israeli people&#8217;s better angels. That would have a much greater effect than a boycott. Now imagine if the 1,200 UK artists who signed your list did the same thing. Perhaps the Israelis would respond in a wholly different way than they would to just yet more age-old rejectionism. Ultimately, whatever the rights and wrongs of official Israeli action in the disputed territories, Israel is a real, vibrant, functioning democracy – yes, with Arab members of parliament – and so engaging with Israelis, who vote, may be more helpful than scaring off artists or shutting down means of engagement. </p>
<p>All the best to you,</p>
<p>Nick</p>
<h1 class="post-title" style="text-align: center;">***</h1>
<p>I want to just add that Brian Eno, beyond any other musician, taught my friends and me how to make music. The records he made remain some of the most important and essential recordings I have ever heard. So, if there seems to be a thread of anguish that runs through this letter, this is indeed the case. I am writing to my hero. </p>
<p>Even so, certain questions need to be asked. How far must we have strayed from the transformative nature of music to feel justified in weaponising music and using it to punish ordinary Israeli citizens for the actions of their government. Furthermore, what has brought us to the point where certain musicians feel it is ethically sound to use forms of coercion and intimidation, in the form of ‘open’ letters, on fellow musicians who don’t agree with their point of view? </p>
<p>Occasionally, I wonder if The Bad Seeds did the right thing in playing Israel. I cannot answer that question. I understand and accept the validity of many of the arguments that are presented to me. Indeed, some of my dearest friends in the music industry found my decision very difficult to accept, but there it is, after much consideration the decision was made: I simply could not treat my Israeli fans with the necessary contempt to do Brian Eno’s bidding. </p>
<p>Much love, Nick</p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
	</main>

	<!-- section -->
	<section>

	
		<!-- article -->
		<article id="post-349" class="post-349 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-uncategorised">
			<!-- post title -->
			<div class="post__title-block">
				<h2>Issue #12 / December 2018</h2>
				<h1 class='post-title'>
					In response to Elettra of Berlin (Issue #8), you said you’d &#8220;freak the fuck out&#8221; if the world were about to end in 72 hours. Great answer. But would that be for the whole 72 hours?				</h1>
				<h3>JAMES, SKIPTON, ENGLAND</h3>
			</div>
			<!-- /post title -->
			<div class="article">
				<div>
					<div class="article__sidebar">
						<!-- post thumbnail -->
													<a href="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/freak-out-the-whole-72-hours/" title="In response to Elettra of Berlin (Issue #8), you said you’d &#8220;freak the fuck out&#8221; if the world were about to end in 72 hours. Great answer. But would that be for the whole 72 hours?">
								<img src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1.png 764w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-250x250.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-700x700.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-120x120.png 120w" sizes="(max-width: 764px) 100vw, 764px" />							</a>
													<!-- /post thumbnail -->
						
											</div>
				</div>
				<div>

					<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">Dear James,</span></p>
<p class="Body">Okay, good point. First off, I would investigate the person who was making the claim to see if they were a reliable source of information and not some lunatic on the street with a cardboard sign. If the person making the claim seemed credible, I would look at the reason why the world was going to end. If it was scientific in nature such as an impact event with an asteroid (which would make sense since we had been given 72 hours notice), rather than say, a random nuclear attack (where we would be given no such warning), or AI undermining us to the point of non-existence, or over-population, or all humans losing the will to live at the same time (a distinct possibility), or a catastrophic fungal pandemic, or extreme weather (all of which would happen incrementally, not in exactly 72 hours) then I would go to the appropriate channels and check out the science.</p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">If there was a consensus among scientists, who, after all, are in the business of knowing stuff &#8211; stuff like, for example, climate change, the mother of all apocalyptic fears, where </span>97% <span lang="EN-US">of scientists ascribe the cause to humankind &#8211; I would probably take their word for it and not be so negligent as to deny their projection.</span></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">I would then proceed to do everything I could to stop it. I would make a call to my friend Bono. If even Bono couldn</span>’<span lang="NL">t stop </span><span lang="EN-US">it, and there was simply no hope &#8211; with annihilation absolutely and unambiguously inevitable &#8211; I would gather my family together, hold them tightly and speak some comforting words. </span>I would take their hands and pray quietly for a moment, because collective prayer can have a calming effect, and I would pray to the <em>possibility</em> of a god, and that the afterlife was a Christian one (where my family and I may have a slim chance of getting in) and not a Muslim one (where we wouldn’t) or a Hindu one (where we may all come back as cockroaches) or a Jewish one (which, as far as I can make out, is pretty much bad news for <em>everyone).</em></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="EN-US">I would ring my mother. I would pet the dogs. I would then turn to my wife, look into her lovely eyes, push a strand of hair from her face and quietly tell her that I loved her, have always loved her and would continue to love her till the end of the world. Then, and only then, would I, with great force of meaning and extreme prejudice, </span><em><span lang="EN-US">freak the fuck out.</span></em></p>
<p class="Body"><span lang="NL">Love, Nick</span></p>
<div></div>
<p><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-350" src="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-250x250.png" alt="" width="250" height="250" srcset="https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-250x250.png 250w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-150x150.png 150w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-700x700.png 700w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2-120x120.png 120w, https://www.theredhandfiles.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture2.png 764w" sizes="(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px" /></p>
					<p>&nbsp;</p>
					<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/ask-a-question" class="button">Ask a Question</a></p>
									</div>
			</div>

		</article>
		<!-- /article -->

	
	
	</section>
	<!-- /section -->
